The songs are a common sound of spring and early summer mornings and may be repeated as often as 10 times per minute.

Males and females give a rising whistled  " tu-wee " reminiscent of an Eastern Wood-Pewee. Yellow-bellied Flycatchers sing an abrupt, hoarse  " che-lek " or  " che-bunk " , throwing their head back with every note. Unmated males repeat their short song from high perches, but mated males tend to also sing while foraging in the understory. As the breeding season progresses they sing less frequently.

The Yellow-bellied Sapsucker's signature call is a scratchy, nasal mewing that is often repeated. They also have a squealing call, a repeated  " quee-ah, quee-ah " , that's territorial and often heard in breeding season. And they make a  " waa " call when disturbed or to alert others to danger.

Male Yellow-Billed Cuckoos make a distinctive series of hollow, wooden-sounding  " ka-ka-ka-ka-ka-kow-kow-kowlp-kowlp-kowlp-kowlp " syllables. The whole series is quite slow and gets slower toward the end; calls can last up to about 8 seconds. Both members of nesting pairs give a metallic, rattling call, and a series of  " kow-kow-kow " notes that sounds like a metal door knocker hitting a strike plate. Males and females also make a soft, repeated cooing: unmated males give this song to attract females, and females coo during courtship.
Both sexes give a similar rapid-fire set of harsh calls, very similar to Black-billed Magpie. No song, though courting males deliver a bubbly, warbling set of calls often termed 'babble-song.'

They have a variety of calls, including a distinctive harsh scolding. Females also make a gargling growl when disturbed at the nest. Wintering males and females give a 'chuck' call to defend winter territories. Males have a large repertoire of songs made up of whistles, cackles, mews, catcalls, caw notes, chuckles, rattles, squawks, gurgles, and pops, which they repeat and string together with great variety. Songs of Western birds may be higher in pitch and more rapid than those of eastern birds. They sing in morning and evening (and even at night during the height of the breeding season), either concealed in thickets or exposed on prominent perches within their breeding territories.
Yellow-crowned Night-Herons give a harsh squawk that may be repeated a few times per second. They call when disturbed, and also have call variations specific to the breeding season.

Yellow-eyed Juncos give a metallic chip and a high-pitched  " seep " year-round. In winter, flocks give a quiet twitter with their bills closed. Males sing a 2-3 parted trill from high perches in conifer trees during the breeding season. The song is a fast trill that starts with clear, evenly pitched notes followed by more of a slurred or buzzy trill.

Their calls include frequent  " check " calls used in many situations during the breeding season, screams given by alarmed females, growls given by fighting or mating males, and harsh rattles given by males when predators are about. Males sing a few musical notes followed by a screeching buzz, rather like a heavy door swinging on a very rusty metal hinge. They sing from cattails, bulrushes, fences, shrubs, or small trees in the morning and evening during the breeding season. Females make a chattering sound that may be considered a song.

Yellow-rumped Warblers have two main calls. The more common one, a sharp  " chek " , differs between the myrtle and Audubon's races. Both forms are quite recognizable and are a key call to learn for a bird watcher hoping to start sorting out migrating warblers in fall. Both sexes make this call frequently, both while foraging and while flying. Yellow-rumped Warblers also make a soft  " psit " and a high  " tsee " in flight. Males sing a slow, soft, sweetly whistled warble or trill. The pitch is mostly even but may rise or fall slightly, speeding up as it ends. Songs last 1-3 seconds and consist of up to 21 individual notes.

Males and females make a harsh, scolding chatter during aggressive encounters with other vireos, birds, or predators. The intensity of the scold increases with the level of threat.    Yellow-throated Vireos sing a broken series of burry 2- and 3-syllable phrases as if saying  " three eight " . Between bursts of  " three eight " they pause for a second or longer. In his  " Essential Field Guide Companion " , Pete Dunne describes the song as a vireo with a sore throat. Males sing from the canopy starting during migration and throughout the breeding season, though the intensity of song decreases after obtaining a mate. Red-Eyed Vireos sound similar but lack the burry quality of Yellow-throated Vireos.

Males and female give a loud, sharp  " chip " . Males sing a series of clear notes that roll into each other, dropping slightly in pitch, but sometimes ending with one higher-pitched note. They typically sing from perches in the canopy.
A high-pitched, screaming  " kreeee " or  " kreeee-ah " , similar to call of Red-tailed Hawk. Many other short, yapping calls during the nesting season.
Call on breeding grounds is low wailing cry; in flight sometimes utters rapid quack like Red-throated Diver's.
Usual call a rapid goose-like quacking.
Calls in breeding season include loud wail and yodelling; quacks in flight like other divers.
Both species have similar calls.
NA
Sharp call note: "kell-kell"; squealing note in breeding season.
Rippling trill in breeding season.
Rippling call and other notes in breeding season.
In spring utters a characteristic, far-reaching, whickering trill.
NA
Usually silent, but on breeding grounds various guttural groans and moans can be heard.
The booming call, often heard at dusk in breeding season, has been compared to blowing in a bottle, or a distant foghorn, and may be heard from up to three miles.
Song is a deep croak repeated continually at day and night.
Call, a harsh "kaark".
The call is a characteristic "quock".
Usually silent, but bill-clattering is a characteristic feature of display. During the breeding season coughing and hissing notes may sometimes be heard.
Unlike the White Stork, the Black Stork has various coarse call notes and bill-clattering is less often heard.
Usually silent, but bill clattering may occur if excited. Also utters occasional grunting sounds in summer.
Various trumpeting cries, in flight especially; also a gabble like that of a goose.
Adult's voice is a low grunt, but cygnets are noisier. Wing-beats of flying birds produce a singing note.
Whooper is rather noisy with characteristic deep, bugle-like whooping, which can be heard over long distances.
Call is somewhat like Whooper's but much more musical and pleasant.
Voice is a hoarse honking, not unlike that of Whooper and Bewick's Swans.
Call is a guttural, croaking "rronk".
Call is a series of rapid, repeated short barks.
Call is two-syllabled, staccato, rather high pitched.
It is the wild ancestral form of the Domestic Goose and the call is similar to the familiar honking of this bird.
The call is more highly pitched than that of other large grey geese and consists of a laughing "kow-yow".
The call is higher pitched than that of the White-fronted Goose.
The call is lower and more honking than that of other grey geese.
The call is very similar to that of the Bean Goose, but slightly higher pitched.
The call is harsh and there is also a deep gabbling produced by birds together in flocks.
Duck's voice is loud quack; drake is quieter.
Call is very low and reedy.
Call is short whistle.
Call, a high descending whistle, often reveals presence of flocks.
Call is two or three soft whistles.
Call is a short whistle.
The call of male is a strange crackling sound.
Quacks like a Mallard; also has a low clucking.
The male utters a low croak, the female a low quack which is difficult to hear.
The call is a characteristic "ag-ag-ag", rather like the flight call of divers. Silent outside breeding season.
The call is nasal, Shelduck-like.
Usually silent. Male sometimes utters a soft whistle, female a harsh croak.
A very vocal duck, often first noticed by its yodelling whistles.
Best-known note is conversational "oo-oo" of drakes when courting.
Call consists of low short quacks.
Call consists of low short quacks.
Various unmusical croaks and whistles are sometimes heard.
Usually silent, but at breeding grounds utters loud, high-pitched whistles.
Calls resemble that of Goshawk.
Call is a high-pitched, trilling cry.
Plaintive and harsh "jee" and a weaker but sharper 2-3 syllable call.
Usually silent but in breeding season gives high-pitched, drawn-out mewing call.
Soars like Buzzard; often seen hovering.
At nesting site a rapid call similar to Sparrowhawk's and a mewing cry similar to Buzzard's can be heard.
At nesting site a rapid "leek-kek-leek" can be heard.
Besides Sparrowhawk-like calls, it has distinct "vee-vitt".
Call is buzzard-like
Call is a rapid series of descending high-pitched whistles.
On breeding grounds the nasal, high-pitched whistling call can be heard.
Call is a harsh "keya", sometimes repeated.
Call is a repeated "kick".
Call is a Kestrel-like chattering "ki-ki-ki". Female has similar but lower-pitched chatter and also a much slower, rather plaintive call, "eep-eep".
Call is Kestrel-like, but higher pitched.
Call is more chatteing, not as shrill as Kestrel's.
Call is a series of shrill "keh-leek" notes and also a repeated "kee-kee-kee".
When flushed, gives rapid laughing call.
Voice like Willow Grouse's.
When flushed, utters peculiar, dry croaking, very different from Willow and Red Grouse.
Call is repeated whistling.
Call is chicken-like.
Call is characteristic three-note whistle.
Call consists of fast and slow cackling notes.
Has characteristic call with repeated first note, "chuck, chuck-or".
Rather silent, except during spring courtship, when cocks call "chirrick, chirrick". Also calls when flushed.
The cock's loud, two-syllabled call is followed by the muffled sound of rapidly beating wings.
Call can be heard day and night but most often at dusk. Consists of repetition of liquid, three-syllabled notes: *wet-my-lips* or "quip-ip-ip".
Call is a characteristic resonant "hoo-hoo-hoo", heard particularly often on clear nights at dawn and dusk.
Call is trumpet-like. Voice deeper than Demoiselle Crane's.
Usually silent but has a gruff bark in breeding season.
In the courtship display the male puffs up, raises his tail and occasionally leaps into the air and emits a sharp "irr" note.

Has a large vocabulary of calls which are more penetrating than musical and are most often heard at night, or when birds are disturbed. These include various squeals, grunts, groans, and wails, which often are heard bursting from a dense reed bed at night. Also a sharp "kik-kik-kik", very similar to calls emitted by Little and Baillon's Crakes.
Call is repetition of high-pitched, explosive short "wheet" notes, rather like the cracking of whip.
Call is an unmusical trill somewhat like that of the Garganey drake or Edible Frog.
Usual call is a series of barking notes ending in a trill.
Secretive, but call, which is a repeated "crex-crex", may be kept up for hours in the breeding season, most persistently at night.
Call is trumpet-like.
Calls include a number of harsh, unmusical notes, the most common rendered "creck" and "whittuck".
Usual calls are loud "kowk" and a double "ke-kowk".
Call is of two syllables, distinctly different and deeper than call of Coot.
Very noisy. Call is a shrill, loud "bleep". Song, heard on breeding ground only, is a high-pitched trill ascending in frequency and volume.
The call is a noisy "zeet-zeet-zeet".
The call is a nasal "vee-veet".
Call resembles Lapwings, but is lower pitched.
The call is unlike that of Lapwing consisting of a short whistle and a harsh chatter.
Call is a mellow "choo-ee".
Call is a characteristic high-pitched, two-note whistle: "pee-oo".
Call is a low-pitched "chu-uu-ee".
Call is loud and characteristic *kill-deer*.
Call is plaintive, slurred whistle "whee-oo-ee".
Call is a sad-sounding, melodious, single-note whistle "whoo-ee".
Call is a clear, short, whistled "oodle-oo".
Call is a soft trill.
Call, one to eight fast, low, slurred, whickering notes.
Call is a low, rasping note. In display flight, produces strong vibrating sound wih outer tail-feathers, called 'drumming', as it dives repeatedly at great height.
During display a twittering sound is produced, but also a characteristic accelerating clicking sound.
During spectacular display flight, a call resembling the sound of a galloping horse is produced.
In the breeding season the soft, croaking call, 'roding', of the displaying male is heard at dusk and early in the morning as the bird flies just above the trees.
Usual call is a mellow whistle: "curlee".
Call is a short, mellow whistle, repeated rapidly 6-7 times resembling the call of the female Cuckoo.
Call resembles Curlew's but is higher pitched and shorter.
Call is a loud "wicka" repeated three times.
Call is a harsh, nasal two-note "irrick".
Call is a shrill, piping, often rendered *kitty-wiper*.
Call is a musical, penetrating three-note whistle: "tit-looet".
Call is a high-pitched, three-note whistle: "chip-ip-ip".
Call is a fast repetition of flute-like notes.
Call is a musical, three-note whistle: "tew-hee-hee". Alarm call is a loud rapid "chip-chip-chip".
Call is a musical somewhat drawn-out whistle "tew-it".
Call is a three-note whistle: "tu-tu-tu", more melodious than that of Redshank.
Usual calls consist of a variety of rather mellow whistles and a twittering trill.
Call is a rather low, two-note whistle, seldom heard.
Call is "weet-loo-eet".
Call is a shrill, high-pitched 2-3 note piping.
Call is a low, rather hoarse, single-note whistle.
(...) characteristic sharp, 3-4 note whistle
Call is a soft, 1-3 note whistle.
Call is a single, thin, piping note, or a series of notes.
Best distinguishing feature is the call, a low, mellow three-note whistle.
Call is a mellow Whimbrel-like whistle.
Usual calls are single, rather quiet "wut" or a whistling "thu-thu".
Call is a short "wit", sometimes repeated.
Call is a rapid, low, grating reel.
Call is a soft whistle "chirrup".
Call is a sharp, short, high-pitched note, quite distinct from the trill of Temminck's Stint.
Call is a short, high-pitched trill, very different from the sharp, high-pitched note of the Little Stint.
Call is a rather deep trill, "crrrooit".
Flight call is a sharp, distinctive "plick".
Call is a distinctive high "beep".
Call, a short "kripe", is lower pitched than Least Sandpiper's.
Call is a thin "jeet".
Call is a low "prrrp".
Call is a high-pitched 2-note whistle.
Call is a rather liquid "keep".
Call is a low trill.
Call is soft, melodious "klui-it", hence Dutch name Kluut.
Call is a sharp, repeated "kik".
Call is low and grunting.
Call suggest Turnstone's.
Call consists of low, short, scratchy notes.
Call is Curlew-like but higher pitched.
Call is tern-like.
NA
Call is unmusical and harsh.
Call is tern-like.
Call resembles that of Herring Gull.
Call resembles that of Herring Gull.
Call is low pitched "kow-kow-kow".
Call is loud, clear and bugle-like, only slightly deeper than that of Herring Gull.
Usual call is loud, clear and bugle-like.
Call is higher pitched than that of Herring Gulls.
Call is harsh and weak.
Call is very nasal.
Call is a characteristic "kittiwake".
Call is lower pitched than that of Black-headed Gull.
Call is a very harsh cackling "kwuririp".
Call is a low quacking.
Call is harsh and crow-like.
The call: "kek-kek-kek".
Call is harsh and tern-like.
Call is more melodious and higher pitcher than most gulls. Also variable. Typical is "klaw" or a repeated "a-wo".
Call is nasal.
Call is harsher and consists of two syllables.
Call is a nasal "wide-a-wake".
Nasal 2-3 syllable call is characteristic, "za-za-sa", quite different from Sandwich Tern's call.
Call is a loud, grating "karrik". Very noisy.
Call is a very deep and characteristic "caw-caw-cah".
Call is a harsh "kee-urr".
Calls are like those of Common Tern, but more nasal and rasping.
Calls are distinctive: a soft "chivy" and a less frequent rasping "z-a-a-p".
Call is a rapid series of paired notes.
Call, which is only heard on the breeding grounds, is a high-pitched chattering.
In spring quite often heard giving its characteristic, high-pitched twittering "vee-bee" calls when red gape shows quite conspicuously.
Call, heard on the breeding grounds only, consists of unmusical guttural notes.
Call is a deep "djur-djur-djur".
In flight, which is fast, the characteristic far-reaching call "catar, catar" is often given.
Usually encountered in flocks, which are noisy. Call consists of two or three notes.
Call is similar to that of the domestic pigeon.
Cooing is a monotonous, coughing "oo-hoo-hoo", more similar to that of Rock Dove than Wood Pigeon.
Cooing consists of five syllables, emphasis on the first.
Song is a soft purring coo.
The cooing is characteristic: three syllables with emphasis on the second syllable.
Cooing is rapid and distinctive, almost resembling call of Cuckoo.
Repeated "cuckoo" song of male is diagnostic; female has babbling call.
Call is distinctly different from that of Cuckoo, consisting of four syllables rather than two.
Call is rasping, almost tern-like.
Call is guttural and toneless.
Call consists of three or four coos.
Call is a monotonously repeated "piuww", usually heard at night, occasionally during the day.
Call is a monotonous repetition of soft whistles. In autumn a series of shrill, rising call notes may be heard.
Calls are shrill and sharp.
Call is a fast series of 7-8 whistles rising slightly at the end. 12-15 groups per minute.
Call is a far-ranging, deep "boo-hu".
On breeding grounds a 2-note crow is occasionally heard; otherwise silent.
Call is deep, booming series of "whoos", each lower in pitch than preceding one.

Call is divided into two parts (like Tawny Owl): a deep bisyllabic "huh-ow", then a four second pause followed by five deep, stammering notes, "hoh-hu ho-hoohu". Alternative call is a rapid series of 6-8 deep "hooings".
Generally silent except near nest, where it makes various low hoots, whistles and shrieks.
Usually silent. Territory call is a fast series of deep "po" sounds; also wings are clapped in the air.
Another common call is a rather shrill "kuvvitt".
Does not hoot, but has a soft, ascending, wheezy cry and a shriek. At the nest it gives a toneless hiss, compared to human snoring.
Territory call is a hurried, vibrating, deep bubbling sound; also a hawk-like, "ki-ki-ki...".

Song, which is given at dusk and at night in spring and summer, is an unmistakable churring trill which often leads to the detection of this bird. It is very different from the "cutek" note of the Red-necked Nightjar.
Song, distinctly different from that of Nightjar, is fast repetition of "plumek" notes.
Churring song resembles that of Nightjar.
Call is shrill and screaming.
Call is like that of Swift.
Call is distinctly different from Swift's, consisting of a loud, descending and ascending trill.
Call is a high, ringing repetition of "cheer" notes.
Call is short and penetrating.
Call is a characteristic far-reaching "pruik", often repeated and mostly given in flight.
Call resembles that of Bee-eater but is shriller and not as far-reaching.
Call is a loud, crow-like "kraack".
Call is a characteristic deep "hoo-poo-poo".
Call is a far-reaching laughing cry. Seldom drums.
Call resembles that of Green Woodpecker, but is not as harsh and dies away slowly. Unlike Green Woodpecker, it drums frequently.
Call is a loud, short "kik". Often drums; drumming is very fast and short (0.5 sec.).
In call, drumming and behaviour like Great Spotted Woodpecker.
In mating season it has a distinct slow cry "gait-gait". Does not drum as often as Great Spotted Woodpecker and drumming is weak.
Call is a repetition of high-pitched "kee" notes. Drums frequently, but a little less powerfully than Great Spotted, often weaker in the middle and usually longer (1.5 sec.).
Call is similar to that of Great Spotted Woodpecker. Drumming resembles Three-toed Woodpecker but becomes weaker and faster at the end.
Call is rather similar to that of the Great Spotted Woodpecker. Drumming is stronger, slower and longer (1.5 sec.) than Great Spotted Woodpecker.
Call is a far-reaching ringing "kleo". Drums commonly and extremely loudly, drums lasting two to three seconds accelerating slightly towards the end.
Call is a repetition of nasal crying "gyeeh" notes. Does not drum.
Song, given in flight, contains rasping notes.
The call has been described as a short "tchirrup".
Song, given in high circling flight, is rich and varied with characteristic short notes. The call has been described as a more protracted "prrit".
Call is short and nasal. Song musical, resembling that of Skylark, usually uttered on the wing from a height.
Song is loud, resembling Calandra Lark's.
Song resembles that of Calandra Lark.
Call is a characteristic "dee-dee-doo". Song resembles that of Skylark but is shorter and less melodious. Usually delivered from the ground or from low perch on rock.
(...), from which song resembling that of Crested Lark is given.
Call is melodious "treek-e". Song, usually give from flight high-up, is liquid, varied and sustained.

Call is a musical, liquid "diedelie". Skylark-like song, which is sometimes given from perch but more often in flight, is characterised by interspersed trilling "lu-lu-lu-lu-lu". Sometimes sings at night.
Call consists of faint pipit-like notes. Song, which is given from perch or in flight, is weak, high-pitched and repetitive.
Call is a low, unmusical buzz.
Call is a high-pitched, weak "tchnin", only rarely heard.
Song is long and twittering.
Song resembles that of Swallow.
Flight call sharp and high pitched. Song twittering.
Call note is a characteristic coarse "tzee". Song, which is given from perch or more often in short song-flight with slow descent, is canary-like, ending with a repeated "zeea".
Song, given from perch, is not as varied as that of the Tree Pipit and is higher pitched.
Call is a characteristic hard "pipit", usually repeated three times. Song, given from perch or song-flight, consists of Wood-Warbler-like phrase followed by low warble.
Call is rather harsh "r-reep".
Call is a thin "zeep", very different from that of Tree Pipit and Red-throated Pipit. Song, usually given in song-flight, is weak, ending in a trill.
As in other pipits voice is of great importance in identification. Call is drawn out or of two notes. Song is a repeated "tsili", given in flight or on the ground.
Call is "tseeh", quite different from that of Meadow and Tree Pipit. Song resembles that of Meadow Pipit and is given in flight.
Call and song more metallic than those of Meadow Pipit.
Call and song similar to those of Water Pipit.
Call is loud mellow "tseep".
Call shorter than that of Yellow Wagtail described as a harsh "dzeep".
Call resembles that of Pied and White Wagtail, but is higher pitched and shorter. Song, seldom heard, is twittering.
Flight very undulating. Call is two-syllable "tsweep". Song, which is seldom heard, is twittering.
Voice and behaviour similar to White Wagtail.
Call is grating "chaek". Song, seldom heard, is an attractive warbled medley.
Call is harsh. Song is subdued and monotonous.
Call is harsh. Song is subdued and monotonous.
Call is harsh "chek".
Call notes inlude shrill cries and rattles. Song is subdued with harsh notes interspersed.
The simple song is a flute-like calling of its name: "or-i-ole"; and it utters harsh, cat-like cries.
Song is long, varied, with much mimicry. Call and flight call are squeaky.
Song resembles that of Starling but is more powerful.
Call is trilling "shree".
Call is loud, nasal "pee-ach".
Quite noisy, the call is an unmelodious "skaaak".
Flight is like Magpie's but not as heavy. Call is unmelodious "kree-eek".
Call is fast, harsh chatter.
Call is raucous "grair".
Call is high-pitched "kiah" resembling Jackdaw, and other shrill, unmusical notes.
Calls include loud, weird trills.
Call is rather high-pitched nasal "jack", often repeated.
Call is more nasal but less harsh than Crow's.
Call is a very deep and hoarse croak.
Call is short "zirb". Song, which can be heard even in winter, resembles that of Wren with grating notes.
Call is harsh and grating. Song is rapid succession of very high, clear notes and trills.
Call is a short vibrating trill. Warbling song is given from ground or in song-flight.
Song is short, high-pitched tingling usually from exposed perch.
Call is a short "teck". Song, which starts and ends abruptly, is very loud and consists of repeated variations of "cheeweewee", given from well-hiden perch.

Call is a subdued "tsek". Song resembles that of Grasshopper Warbler but is shorter, deeper and with a much higher frequency. Song is more monotonous than that of River Warbler, which is broken up into short sections. Song often starts slowly. Sings from exposed perch in reeds or bushes.

Call is harsh. Song, which is given from exposed low perch, is trilling, resembling Grasshopper Warbler, but with individual notes clearly separated. Less monotonous, more broken, than that of Grasshopper and Savi's Warbler's. Sings mostly at dusk, even at night.
Call is described as "schick". Song resembles that of Marsh Warbler.
Sharp two-note call.

Call is short "tirk". Song, given mostly at dusk and dawn, from low perch which it leaves at the least disturbance, is a characteristic high-pitched, fast trilling sustained for very long periods, often appearing to vary in volume as the bird turns its head. Savi's Warbler has somewhat similar song, but it is shorter, deeper in tone and of higher frequency. Song of River Warbler is not as monotonous as it is broken up into short sections.
Song is rapid and varied, resembling that of Sedge Warbler, but includes Nightingale-like "too-too-too-too" notes, which are not present in song of Sedge Warbler.
Song, which is delivered from perch or almost vertical songflight, is varied (more so than that of Reed Warbler), repetitive, rapid, and interspersed with many harsh notes.
Song consists of weak repeated "zit" uttered in flight.

Song resembles Marsh Warbler's but is even more musical and often given from high perch. It is delivered at a more leisurely pace than that of Marsh Warbler. Like the Marsh Warbler it is an expert mimic.

Song is varied and musical, with repetition of same notes several times, but contains harsh chattering notes. It is not as rapid and varied as that of the Sedge Warbler. Like others of the Acrocephalus group it imitates other bird-songs. Sings normally from perch.
Song loud and strident with characteristic "car" and "cier" notes. Sings from exposed perch on reed.
Call is short metallic "teck". Song is varied and sustained but includes many discordant notes.
Song is faster, with fewer discordant notes than that of Icterine.
Song is loud and slow, resembling that of Great Reed Warbler, and is thrush-like in quality.
Song resembles that of Sedge Warbler, rapid with grating notes.
Song resembles that of Sedge Warbler.
Call is grating "tack" resembling that of Garden Warbler, as does song which is given in short song-flight. The characteristic grating call is included in the song.

Call is sharp "tack". Song is loud, thrush-like in the southeastern European subspecies S.h. crassirostris. In the south-western European subspecies S.h. hortensis the song is much more monotonous, consisting of alternating high and low notes.
Song is musical, mellow and liquid, resembling that of Blackcap but longer and more subdued. Call is sharp "tack".
Song is a short, mellow musical warble of rising strength, less subdued and uniformly liquid than that of Garden Warbler. Call is short mechanical "tack".
Call is rasping "tze". Song, which is usually given from covered perch, is a fast, short, rather high-pitched warble. Usually sings longer into the summer than most warblers.
Call is a short "tack". Song, which is given from hidden perch or while moving about, consists of two parts. First a subdued warble, then a fast, rattling repetition of "chik-ke" notes.

Call is a loud "chat" repeated several times. Song resembles that of Sardinian Warbler but is not as hurried, although faster than that of the Dartford Warbler. It is delivered from perch or very high song-flight somewhat similar to that of Tree Pipit but more twisting.
Call consists of loud chattering notes. Song, which is usually given in Whitethroat-like song-flight, is long, hurried and musical, interspersed with chattering notes.
Call is sharp repeated "tart". Song resembles that of Whitethroat but is more musical and variable.
Call is short, sharp "teck". Song, often given in song-flight, is very musical, resembling that of Whitethroat without the harsh notes. Not as fast as that of Sardinian Warbler.
Call is short trill. Song is a low series of repeated "tee" notes.
Call is rattling. Song is a short high-pitched, rather monotonous and deliberate warble given from exposed perch or long song-flight.

Call consists of hard and loud "chir" and "tuck" notes. Song resembles that of Whitethroat but is feebler and includes fewer rasping notes. It consists of short phrases interrupted by pauses of varying length. Can be heard singing throughout the year. Song is not as rapid as that of Sardinian Warbler. Often given in short song-flight.
Call is short "tick". Song, which is given in short song-flight, does not resemble that of Dartford Warbler, being more mellow, weaker and slurred.
Call is a sharp "tack". Song consists of clear flute-like ascending notes given in an even rhythm. Given from open perch or song-flight. Sings persistently.
Call is plaintive "fooeed". Song is a musical, liquid and soft, descending warble.
Call is plaintive "hooeed". Song is rather monotonous repeated "chiff-chaff", combined in various ways, sometimes with grating introductory notes.

Call is liquid "diu". Song, often given in song-flight, is characteristic series of "sip" notes repeated at an accelerating rate. Second song, often combined with the trill, is a series of lengthened call-notes.
Song resembles Willow Warbler's. Call is not as mellow as Willow Warbler's.
Call is described as "tak".
Call is a rather plaintive "hoo-eet". Song resembles trill of Wood Warbler but is not accelerated. It consists of two different phrases of different pitch and length.
Call resembles that of Willow Warbler but is more high-pitched and sharp, sometimes consisting of two syllables: "weeesp".
Call is metallic "zick". Song is short, high trill.
Call is a high-pitched "tsi-lee". Song is short and loud, starting with a few calls, then merging with a trill followed by a short high-pitched warble.
Call is a high-pitched "tweet", quite unlike any call of Goldcrest or Firecrest.
Call is extremely thin and high-pitched. Song is of similar quality ending in short warble.
Call is less high-pitched than that of Goldcrest and song is a monotonous, accelerating repetition of "zis" notes.
Call a short "wit", emphasised when alarmed. Song rather unmelodious but variable stream of "cher" notes.
Song is a repeated "zoet". Call is a hard "teck".
Call is chattering but soft. Song is loud and trilling reminiscent of Willow Warbler's.
Call is a sharp "zit". Song is a repetition of three or four call notes, mainly heard soon after arrival in spring.
Call is a hard "tack". Song, given from perch or short song-flight, is a short warble of lark-like quality.
Call is loud, metallic, piping "wheet". Song contains whistling notes. Often imitates other birds.
Call is hard "tack". Song is lark-like with whistling notes, given in phrases of varying length, usually from perch or song-fligh.

Call consists of hard "tack", usually followed by a whistling note. Song, which is given from perch or song-flight and rather more often than Wheatear's, resembles Wheatear's but is louder and higher pitched. Sometimes imitates the song of other species.
Call is hoarse whistle.
Call is a high-pitched "pee-pee-pee-pee". Song is rich, short warble resembling that of Blue Rock Thrush but not as loud.
Call starts with a musical "due", continuing with hard "teck, teck". Song, which is given from perch or song-flight, is a short, high-pitched warble, often with some notes imitating other birds.
Call consists of "teck" notes. Song, which is given from perch or song-flight, consists of short, repeated, rather high-pitched notes.
Call is a short "tack". Song, which is given from open perch or in song-flight, is a musical, fluting warble, but is very variable.
Call is a hard "tick". Song is loud, musical and thrush-like. It is usually given from perch on rock or song flight.
Call is plaintive "fu-et". Song is short, melodious Robin-like warble ending in a short twitter.
Call is a series of "tic" notes. Song, usually given from perch on building or rock, is a short, fast, simple edition of that of Redstart, often ending with a peculiar rattle.
Call is a short "tack". Song, often given in song-flight, is varied, gentle, musical warbling, rather high-pitched.
Call is series of "tic" notes. Song, given from low perch, is series of fast, rather high-pitched, warbling notes, usually starting subdued.
Call is  short "teck teck". Song is very loud, musical and thrush-like.
Call is a liquid "hu-eet". Song is very loud and musical with characteristic deep "jug" notes and drawn-out "pin"'s. Sings from depth of thickets, often at night.
Song resmbles that of Nightingale and is even louder, but less musical. Sings from well-hidden perch, often at night.
Song is loud and musical.
Call is a rather nasal "vee-a".
Call is a high-pitched "whit".
Call resembles that of Song Thrush.
Call resembles that of Fieldfare.
Call resembles that of Fieldfare.
Song, given from exposed perch, is usually a ringing "tew tew tew", but sometimes resembles that of Sog Thrush, though more monotonous and interspersed with short chuckling.
Call is repeated "chack". Song is a musical, fluting warble. Sings from open perch at dusk and dawn.
Song resembles that of Song Thrush's.
Call resembles that of Song Thrush.
Behaviour and voice resemble those of Blackbird.
Call is penetrating, prolonged high-pitched "zee-up". Call is short repetition of flute-like notes followed by low, rather unmusical warble, but is very variable.
Call is a thin, short "seep". Song is flute-like and varied, tending to repeat short sections.
Call is characteristic dry rattling chatter with pauses between bursts. Song resembles Blackbird's but is briefer and less flute-like.
Call is loud "schack, schack". Song is twittering and often given in flight.
Call piping.
Typical calls are loud "pitchu" and repeated, scolding "tzee". Usual song, a repeated "tschuppi".
Call is a repeated nasal "tchay". Usual song is drawn-out "tew tew tew", but there is also an unexpected warbling song, seldom heard in some areas.
Call resembles that of Great Tit.
Call resembles that of Willow Tit but is even more drawn out.
Call is characteristic purring trill.
Call varied, but most commonly a high-pitched "zee", often repeated several times and sometimes introducing trilling song.
Call "tseerr". Song is loud and trilling.
Call is a thin "tset", more plaintive than that of other tits. Song is a repeated "weetse".
Calls numerous, and usually stronger than those of other tits. Song is a very characteristic penetrating, metallic series of "zee-de" notes.
Call is a repeated trilling "tsimp" and thin "see-see-see". Song, rarely heard, is a mixture of these notes.
Call is a hard "tink-tink" like stones knocked together. Song twittering.
Call is a drawn-out, sweet "zee-eh". Song is twittering, but it is quiet and only heard for a short time.
Calls are tit-like. Typical song is a characteristic, repeated, musical "tuueh".
Call is much more nasal and quieter than that of Nuthatch. Song consists of two phrases of different pitch.
It has a large variety of calls. Song is a loud, descending trill.
Call is a soft "twit".
Call is thin and piping. Song is a repeated, accelerated and rising, high-pitched "zee-zee-zee-tui".
Call is a single very high note. Song is high, faint and accelerated.
Call is a firm "zeet". Song is more plaintive than that of Treecreeper, and may be delivered from exposed perch.
Calls and song consist of monotonous chirps.
Calls resemble that of House Sparrow's but richer.
Calls resemble House Sparrow's but are higher-pitched and sharper.
Many calls resemble House Sparrow's but has characteristic "dui-ee" call.
Song, given from rather exposed perch, is melodious, short rattling with many geographic variations. Flight call is a short "juep juep", and usual call a ringing "pink".
Song is a rather monotonous repetition of Greenfinch-like calls, given from an exposed perch. Flight call is nasal "tjaek, tjaek" or "chup-chup".
Song, not well developed, is low, piping warble, but will learn to sing in captivity. Call is soft, melancholy "peu, peu".
Song is low and twittering, rarely heard. Call is metallic "tpik".
Call is a plaintive but characteristic "sit". Song, often given in song-flight, resmbles that of Serin.
Call is a varied twittering "chirlit". Song, which is given from high open perch or in song-flight, is a jingling, sibilant twitter. Very vocal.
Calls include a rapid trilling "chick, chick, chick", and more nasal "twee-ee". Song, which is given from high open perch or in butterfly-like song-flight, is a twittering mixture of calls.
Wheezy call diagnostic. Song, delivered from high perch  or in song-flight, is twittering.
Call is characteristic, liquid "deedelit", often repeated. Song, delivered from an exposed perch, is a similarly liquid twittering.
Call "tsweet"; twitters in flight. Song, usually given from open perch, is a pleasant, varied twitter.
Call is a nasal, metallic "tweeh". Song, delivered from perch or in song flight, resembles that of Linnet but is slower and harder.
Call is a hoarse "chi-chi-chit". Song, given from perch or in song-flight, is a trilling twitter.
Habits and voice as those of Redpoll.
Call is short and nasal.
Call is soft repeated "screet". Song is piping and trilling. Call is a loud whistle.
Call consists of three high whistles. Song is a loud warble.
Call is unmistakable "kip, kip, kip" given with great emphasis. Song is twittering, with characteristic calls interspersed.
Its call is louder and deeper than that of the Crossbill and it has a characteristic alarm call: "toop, toop", which is lacking in the Crossbill.
Call deeper and louder than Crossbill's.
Call consists of three to four redpoll-like notes, higher and decidedly different from call of Crossbill. Song is long and canary-like.
Call is short and harsh "tsrip". Characteristic song, which is usually given from exposed perch (often from wires), is monotonous; jingling.
Call is a sharp "tick". Song is short and melodious, of same quality as Robin's.
Call is a short, sharp "tick". Song varied, but usually rather short with a Dunnock-like quality.
Call is a thin, sharp "zeet". Song, which is usually given rom high, open perch, is a high-pitched series of "zee" notes, somewhat varied in sequence.
Call is a high-pitched soft "tsee". Song resembles that of Yellowhammer but has 'ringing' quality and is much slower. The last notes are of a lower pitch than the preceding ones.
Call is harder and sharper than Ortolan's and more penetrating. Song is a short twitter resembling that of Ortolan.
Call is a series of harsh notes. Song is a short, fast, monotonous warble.
Call resembles that of Yellowhammer, of which it may be a subspecies. Song somewhat similar to that of Chaffinch with an ascending pitch.
Song is simple, bunting-like.
Call is a loud "zeek". Song, which is usually given from open perch, is short and monotonous "chi-chi-chi-chitty".
Call is sharp "tjip". Song, uttered from exposed perch, is monotonous *little bit of bread and no———cheese*.
Call is short "tick". Song resembles Ortolan's but is louder and faster.
Call is repeated "sip". Song, given from exposed perch, is vibrating repetition of metallic notes.
Call is short "sit". Song starts with a few similar short notes ending in short, pleasant warble. Usually given from exposed perch.
Call is short trill. Song, usually given in song-flight, has same quality as Skylark's, but is shorter.
Call is short descending whistle: "seeoo". Song, given from rocky perch or song-flight, is a loud, short, lark-like warble.
Call is rather harsh "zjeeb". Song, given from rocky perch or song-flight is twittering.
Utters loud, bugling "ung-uk" calls.
Utters various honking, bugling, yelping calls. More musical than Whooper.
Generally silent but utters grunting calls on occasions, and loud hissing when alarmed near nest. Wingbeats produce a throbbing whine.
A nasal, trumpeting cackle.
Nasal, trumpeting cackles, interspersed with diagnostic "wink-wink" calls.
In flight, utters barking, rather musical 'yodelling' calls.
Loud, honking calls, exactly like the familiar calls of the farmyard geese.
Loud, disyllabic trumpeting calls in flight.
Flocks utter loud, barking calls.
Extremely vocal, uttering a nasal "krrrut".
Likened to a braying donkey.
Courting male utters a whistling call, while female's call is a cackling "gagaga..."
Mainly silent.
Male utters  distinctive "wheeeoo" whistling call, an evocative sound of estuaries and wetlands in winter.
Male utters a croaking call and female utters a nasal Mallard-like "quack".
Male utters a range of whistles and nasal calls. Female utters familiar quacking calls.
Male utters a ringing whistle while female utters a soft quack.
Male utters a diagnostic rattling call, while female occasionally utters a very soft quack.
Male utters a whistling call, while female's call is grating and harsh.
Male utters a sharp "tuk-tuk", while female utters a soft quack with its bill.
Mostly silent.
Male utters a soft peeping call.
Generally silent.
Male utters characteristic and endearing, cooing "ah-whooo", while throwing head back in a distinctive manner. Female utters a variety of deep, throaty calls.
Male utters a characteristic nasal "ow-owlee".
Mostly silent, although displaying males utter piping calls.
Mainly silent.
Displaying male utters squeaky calls and a Garganey-like rattle.
Silent.
Mostly silent, although displaying males sometimes utter soft grunting calls.
Displaying males utter ringing calls.
Utters a nasal call that is sometimes described as *go-back, go-back, go-back*.
Rattling "kur-kurrrr" call.
Displaying males utter a bubbling, cooing call.
Male utters a bizarre sequence of clicking sounds followed by a noise likened to a cork being pulled from a bottle.
Song is a diagnostic, liquid, trisyllabic "whit-we-whit" phrase.
Territorial male utters a loud, shrieking "coo-cukk" call, which is followed by a bout of vigorous wingbeating. In alarm, a loud "ke-tuk, ke-tuk, ke-tuk" is uttered as the bird flies away.
Utters a loud "ke che-che, ke che-che, ke che-che..." call.
Utters a harsh, choked "kierr-ikk" call.
On breeding grounds, utters a goose-like "kaa-kaa-kaa" in flight. Silent in winter.
On its breeding territory, utters croaking and wailing calls. Silent in winter.
Wailing, evocative 'song', uttered on breeding territory, is seldom heard in Britain. Silent in winter.
Silent at sea but at breeding colonies utters strange gurgling and purring calls from nesting burrows.
Silent at sea, but at breeding colonies birds utter a bizarre-sounding gurgling rattle, likened to a pixie chuckling and being sick!
Silent at sea, but nesting birds at breeding colonies utter weird, strangled coughing calls after dark.
Various gurgling cackles and grunts are uttered at colonies. Otherwise silent
Utters nasal and guttural calls at breeding colonies but otherwise silent.
Utters various harsh grunting calls at breeding colonies but otherwise silent.
Silent at sea but nesting birds utter harsh, grating calls.
Territorial males utter deep, booming "whummp" calls in spring, mostly at night.
Utters a harsh and distinctive "krrarnk", typically in flight.
Generally silent, but coarse, grating calls are sometimes uttered between rivals.
Generally silent.
Utters a characteristic whinnying call.
During the breeding season utters a range of wailing, croaking calls.
During the breeding season, utters various wailing and grunting calls; otherwise silent.
Territorial calls include various rattling trills and squeals.
Calls include various whistles an squeaks; silent in winter.
Utters various mournful, whistling calls.
Mainly silent, but displaying birds sometimes utter thin, piping, whistling calls.
Mainly silent.
Mainly silent.
Utters shrill calls in flight, not unlike somebody whistling for their dog.
Mainly silent.
Distinctive mewing "pee-ay" call often attracts attention, even with distant birds.
Mainly silent.
Mainly silent.
Utters loud, mournful whistling calls.
Utters a harsh "kie-kie-kie" during the breeding season; otherwise silent.
Utters a shrill "kew-kew-kew" in alarm.
Utters a shrill and insistent "kee-kee-kee...".
Mainly silent, although a shrill "kee-kee-kee..." is uttered in alarm near the nest.
Utters a shrill "kiu-kiu-kiu..." in alarm.
Loud and distinctive "kek-kek-kek...".
Utters a piercing pig-like squeal, choking calls and distinctive "kip-kip-kip" notes, typically from cover.
Male's territorial call is a repetitive whiplash-like "whit", uttered after dark.
Territorial male utters a ceaseless "crek-crek, crek-crek..." throughout the night and sometimes in daylight hours too.
Utters a loud, far-carrying "kurrrk".
Utters a loud, distinctive "kwoot" call.
Utters a loud, trumpeted, rolling "krrruu".
Utters a rolling "tuk-ut-ut" in flight.
Utters a loud, piping "kleep" call.
Utters a ringing "klueet-klueet..." call.
Utters strange Curlew-like "curleee" wailing calls, mostly at dusk and throughout the night.
Utters a soft "pierrr" call.
Utters a "peeoo" flight call and has a plaintive "pu-pEeoo" song.
Utters a diagnostic trisyllabic "pee-oo-ee" call.
Utters a loud, short "pew" call.
Utters a soft, disyllabic "tuu-eep" call.
Utters a distinctive "pee-wit" call.
Utters a sharp "knut" call.
Utters a sharp "plit" call.
Utters a sharp "kwit" call in flight.
Utters a shrill "stip" call.
Utters a trilling call.
Utters a soft "prrrp" call.
Utters a "preeit" call. 'Song' of displaying birds comprises a series of whistling calls.
Mainly silent.
Male utters soft duck-like calls and explosive squeaks in a crepuscular display flight (known as roding).
Utters 1 or 2 sneeze-like "kreech" calls when flushed. Males perform a 'drumming' display in breeding season, when a humming sound is produced by vibrating the tail feathers.
Mainly silent.
Utters a "kwe-we-we" call in flight.
Utters a sharp "kve-wee" call in flight.
Distinctive bubbling call typically comprises 7 notes that descend slightly in pitch from start to finish. Song is confusingly similar to that of a Curlew.
Utters a characteristic "curlew" call and delivers a bubbling song on breeding grounds.
Utters a trisyllabic "chlueet-wit-wit" flight call.
Utters a distinctive "chiff-iff-iff" flight call.
Utters a whistling "tswee-wee-ee" call in flight
Utters a distinctive "tchu-tchu-tchu" call.
Utters a diagnostic "tchewit" call in flight.
Utters a yelping "tiu-uu" alarm call. Song is musical and yodeling.
Occasionally utters a sharp "kip" call.
Utters a sharp "pit" flight call.
Silent in the region.
Utters nasal calls near the nest.
Silent in the region.
Mainly silent.
Silent in the region.
Utters a diagnostic "kittee-wake, kittee-wake" call at breeding colonies.
Utters raucous calls that include a nasal "kaurrr".
Call is a distinctive "cow-cow".
Utters a sharp "kyeck" call.
Calls include a mewing "keeow".
Utters a distinctive "kyaoo" and an anxious "ga-ka-ka".
Utters a deep "kaa-ga-ga" call.
Utters a distinctive "kyaoo" and an anxious "ga-ka-ka".
Similar to that of Herring Gull but perhaps more nasal.
Utters a "kyaoo" and an anxious "ga-ka-ka".
Utters a distinctive "kyaoo" and an anxious "ga-ka-ka".
Utters a raucous "cree-ick" call.
Mainly silent.
Utters a harsh "che-urrick" call.
Utters a disyllabic "chew-vik" call.
Utters various harsh calls, including "kreeear".
Utters a harsh "krt-krt-krt" call near the nest.
Utters nasal, growling calls at breeding colonies.
Mostly silent but sometimes utters croaking calls near the nest.
Utters high-pitched whistling calls.
Silent in the region.
Utters strange groaning calls at the nest.
Utters a range of cooing calls.
During the breeding season, utters a diagnostic and repetitive "oo-u-look" call.
Sings a series of "oo-OO-oo, oo-oo" phrases.
Utters a repetitive 'song' that comprises a much repeated "oo-oo-oo" phrase.
Song is a diagnostic purring "coo".
Vocal, often announcing its presence (including in flight) with loud, squawking calls.
Utters a blood-curdling call at night.
Calls include a strange cat-like "kiu", uttered repeatedly and agitatedly in early evening. Has a distinctive undulating flight.
Utters a sharp "kew-wick" and the well-known hooting calls; most vocal in late winter and early spring when territorial boundaries are under dispute.
Mainly silent but a series of deep hoots is sometimes heard in spring.
Displaying birds will sometimes utter deep hoots; otherwise silent.
Male utters a distinctive "cuck-oo" song during the first 6 weeks or so after its arrival; female has a bubbling call.
Male utters a distinctive churring song after dark for hours on end.
Loud, shrill, screaming calls are uttered by parties of birds as they chase one another overhead at speed.
Utters a distinctive thin, high-pitched "tist-tseee" call in flight.
Mostly silent but territorial birds utter loud, piping, raptor-like "pee-pee-pee" calls.
Its laughing call (sometimes referred to as 'yaffling') is distinctive and the 'song' comprises a dozen or so yelping, call-like notes.
All birds utter a loud "tchick" alarm call. In spring, males 'drum' loudly to proclaim territorial ownership.

Male utters a loud, piping, raptor-like "kee-kee-kee" call in spring. Drumming is rapid but rather faint, and is also higher-pitched and longer than that of Great Spotted, averaging 24 strikes per drum (13 for Great Spotted).
Utters a harsh "tchek" call when agitated.
Utters a harsh, trilling call.
Utters a distinctive "chyah" call; with standing agitated manner.
Utters a characteristic "chack" call.
Utters a loud, rattling alarm call.
Utters a loud, harsh scream.
Utters a grating "caw-caw-caw..." call.
Utters a loud, deep "cronk" call. This often alerts observers to the presence of distant flying birds.
Utters a harsh, trumpeting, slightly slurred "creeaa-creeaa-creeaa" call.
Utters a harsh, trumpeting, slightly slurred "creeaa-creeaa-creeaa" call.
Song is a rich, fluty, tropical-sounding "wee-lo-weeow", with variations on the theme. Also utters various harsh disyllabic calls; some are Jay-like or cat-like.
Call is familiar, chattering "tser err-err-err". Song contains whistling and trilling elements.
Utters a harsh "tche-tche-tche" alarm call. Song is a striking variation on a "teecha-teecha-teecha" theme.
Utters a high, trilling call. Song is a rapid, almost warbler-like series of call-like notes and whistles.
Utters a distinctive and nasal "si-si tchay-tchay-tchay" call. Song is rather musical and warbling.
Utters a loud, sneezing "pitchoo" call. Song is a loud and repeated "chip-chip-chip...".
Utters a diagnostic high-pitched "ping" call. Soft, rasping song is seldom heard.
Utters a rattling "tsrr" contact call and a thin "tsee-tsee-tsee". Soft, twittering song is easily overlooked.
Utters a thin call. Song is a repeated "teechu-teechu-teechu-teechu...", higher-pitched, more rapid and weaker than that of Great Tit.
Flight call is a thin "see-seer".
Song is a series of fluty, yodelling "deet-luee", reminiscent of a snatched phrase from the song.
Song, most often delivered in flight, is a rapid and varied mixture of trilling and whistling notes; it sometimes includes elements of mimicry. Call is a rolling "chrrrp".
Utters a range of rasping "jsee-jsee-jsee" calls.
Utters a distinctive "prrrt" call in flight. Twittering song is often delivered from overhead wires in the vicinity of its nest.
Utters a sharp "vit" call in flight. Male sings a twittering 'sparrow-like' song, often while sitting on overhead wires near the nest site.
Very vocal. Utters a loud, rattling alarm call and its song is loud and warbling, ending in a trill.
Utters a thin, high-pitched "tsee-tsee-tsee". Song comprises a series of high-pitched phrases and ends in a flourish.
Utters a thin "tsuu-tsee-tsee" call. Song comprises a series of thin, high-pitched notes and ends abruptly.

Usual call is a loud "pluut" but often also a rattling "plurrrr". Song is an explosive "chee, chippi-chippi-chippi". Most vocal in spring, but snatches of song are sometimes heard at other times of year.
Utters a sharp "tsip" call. Its song, which has been likened to a coin spinning on a plate, starts with ringing notes and accelerates into a silvery trill.

Utters a disyllabic "hueet" call, similar to that of Chiffchaff. Song comprises a tinkling, descending phrase that ends in a slight flourish; it is endlessly repeated by newly arrived birds in spring.

Call is a soft "huitt", shorter and harsher than Willow Warbler's "hueet". Song is a continually repeated "chiff-chaff" or "tsip-tsap", heard most frequently in early spring but sometimes uttered in snatches by  migrants in late summer.

Call is a sharp "chek-chek". Song is rich and warbling; could be confused with that of Blackcap but is even more musical, some phrases having a thrush-like quality, often bubbling on uninterrupted for long periods.

Utters a sharp "tchek" alarm call. Song is a rich and musical warble; it is similar to that of Garden Warbler but lacks the thrush-like tones, usually contains jaunty 'dancing' phrases, has discernible finish and doesn't bubble along.
Utters a harsh "chek" alarm call. Song comprises a distinctive tuneless rattle, sung on one note, and usually preceded by a short warbling phrase.
Utters a harsh "check" alarm call. Song, sung from an exposed perch or in flight, is a rapid and scratchy warble delivered in a distinct phrase.
Distinctive "tchrr-tche" call is often the first clue to the species' presence in an area. Song is a rapid, scratchy warble.

Utters a sharp "tssvet" call. Song is reeling and sung continuously for minutes on end; some liken it to the 'song' of a bush-cricket, while to others it is mechanical-sounding. Sings mainly at night.
Utters a sharp "chek" alarm call. Song comprises a series of rasping and grating phrases interspersed with trills and whistles.

Utters a sharp "tche" call. Rhythmic song contains grating and chattering phrases, some of which are repeated 2 or 3 times, plus some elements of mimicry. Very much the rhythm and blues player to Sedge Warbler's jazz musician!
Utters an insistent and loud "zwiit", repeated regularly if bird is agitated. Song typically comprises a series of loud "pee-pee-pee" notes.
Utters a thin, high-pitched "tseert" call. Short song comprises a series of high-pitched notes and ends in a trill.
Utters a trilling call.
Utters various clicks and whistles. Song includes mimicry of other birds and man-made sounds.
Utters a harsh "tchuck" alarm call. Song comprises of short bursts of fluty phrases.
Utters a harsh and repeated "tchak" alarm call, often at dusk or if it is disturbed by a prowling cat. Male is an excellent songster with a rich and varied repertoire.
Utters a thin "tik" call in flight. Song is loud and musical, and comprises phrases that are repeated 2 or 3 times.
Utters a loud and distinctive rattling alarm call. Its loud song is Blackbird-like but contains brief phrases and long pauses.
Utters a harsh "chack-chack-chack" call; night-migrating flocks can be detected by these calls. Song (seldom heard here) comprises short bursts of subdued fluty phrases.
Utters a thin, high-pitched "tseerp" in flight; often heard on autumn nights as migrating flocks pass overhead. Song (seldom heard here) comprises short bursts of whistling and fluty phrases.
Utters a thin, buzzy "tsee" call. Song is simple and includes thin, call-like notes.
Utters a sharp "plit" call repeatedly when alarmed. Song is sweet and ringing.
Utters a shrill "striitz" call.
Utters a sharp and distinctive "chak" alarm call, like 2 pebbles being knocked together. Song is fast and warbling.
Most vocal in spring but its rather plaintive, melancholy song can be heard in almost any month. Alarm call is a sharp "ic".

Song is rich and varied, and includes fluty whistles and clicking sound; typically starts with a rich, whistling "tu-tu-tu-tu", before embarking on its more complex repertoire. Call is a frog-like croak.
Utters a whistling "svit", or "svit-it-it"call. Song comprises various whistles and curious crackling, static-like phrases.
Utters a soft "huiit-tut-tut" call and a sharp ticking when alarmed. Song is tuneful but melancholy.
Utters a whistling "whic-tuc" alarm call. Song is rapid and warbling.
Utters a harsh "tchak" call, like 2 pebbles being knocked together. Rapid, warbling song is rather Whitethroat-like.
Utters a range of chirping calls.
Utters House Sparrow-like chirps, but also a sharp "tik-tik" in flight.
Song is energetic and warbler-like; alarm call is a thin, piping "tseer".
Utters a loud "chissick" call.
Utters a distinctive "tsree-ee" call.
Utters a sharp "tip-tip" call in flight.

Flight call is a buzzing "spzzt". Song (delivered in flight but starting from a tree perch) comprises an accelerating trill that ends with thin, drawn-out notes as the bird parachutes down, usually to a different tree-top perch.
Utters a "pseet-pseet-pseet" and has a descending song delivered in flight, but that typically starts and ends on the ground.
Utters a single "pseet" call, and has a Meadow Pipit-like song that is delivered in flight but starts and ends on a cliff-side rocky outcrop.
Utters a single "pseet" call.
Utters a distinct "pink pink" call. Song comprises a descending trill with a characteristic final flourish.
Calls include a harsh, nasal "jseeerrp". Song (seldom heard here) comprises a series of buzzing notes.
Utters a sharp "jrrrup" call in flight. Song either comprises well-spaced wheezy "weeeish" phrases or a series of rapid, trilling whistles, sometimes delivered in flight.
Utters a tinkling, trisyllabic call. Song is twittering and rapid, containing call-like elements.
Utters a distinctive "tetter-tett" call. Male's twittering, warbling song is usually delivered from a prominent perch.
Utters a characteristic, sharp, nasal, twanging "tveeht" call. Song comprises a series of trilling and rattling notes.
Utters disyllabic whistling or twittering "speeoo" calls. Song comprises a series of twittering, almost warbling, phrases.
Utters a distinctive monosyllabic soft, piping "pew" call, sometimes delivered in a duet by a pair. The quiet song, which is seldom heard, comprises slow, fluty notes.
Utters a rattling "chek-chek-chek" call in flight. Song comprises a series of wheezing and rattling notes.
Utters a rattling "chek-chek-chek" call in flight. Song comprises a series of wheezing and rattling notes.
Utters a sharp "kip-kip-kip" flight call.
Utters a sharp "kip-kip-kip" flight call, similar to, but slightly deeper than, that of Common Crossbill.
Utters a sharp, almost Robin-like "tsic" call. Song is quiet and subdued, and is seldom heard.
Utters a thin "seeu" call. Song is simple, chinking and repetitive.
Utters a rolling "prrrt" call in flight. Song is twittering but tone is clearly bunting-like.
Utters a distinctive rattling "tiddlip-tew" call in flight.
Utters a rasping "zit" call. Song is often rendered as *a little bit of bread and no cheese*.
Utters a sharp "tziip" call. Song is a rather tuneless rattle, reminiscent of that of Lesser Whitethroat.
Utters a "tsit" call. Jingling song has been likened to jangling keys, and is usually sung from a fencepost or overhead wire.
Utters barking calls in flight.
Utters a barking, honking "whook".
Utters a honking "hronk".
Utters a nasal, honking "kruut".
Utters a shrill, nasal "kik-yuuk".
Utters a nasal, gargling, trilling, "gyrrrrr" and a sharp "kyerr".
Male utters a gulping "kwerp" call.
Male utters a ringing whistle while female utters a soft quack.
Utters a squeaky trill, and a shrill "kwit".
Male utters a distinctive "whee-ooo" whistling call.
Male utters whistles and nasal calls, while female utters quacking calls; both are similar to Mallard.
Mostly silent.

Utters a sharp "skeeeok" call in flight.
Call is a sharp "kwekek", usually uttered in flight. Song is a monotonous, gruff croak, uttered mostly at night.
Utters a barking "quaak" call in flight.
Utters a quacking "kwaak".
Utters a soft, croaking call in flight.

Utters a whistling, whinnying call, similar to that of Red Kite but more shrill.

Utters a partridge-like "tche-tche-tchee", quite unlike that of Kestrel. However, vagrants here are usually silent.

Territorial males have a 'croaking' song that is remarkably similar to the call of a Marsh Frog (Pelophylax ridibundus).
Male's song (sung at night) is a repeated, yapping "kwip" that gradually accelerates and lowers in pitch.

Utters a soft "tchu-eep" call (vaguely like that of a Spotted Redshank, Tringa erythropus).
Utters a shrill, piping "kiu-dee" or "tee-dee-dee".
Utters a soft "bruip" call.
Utters a soft "trrrk" call.
Utters a trilling "trrrr" call.

Utters a mournful, disyllabic "chlu-ee".

Call is a bubbling "quilip-ip-ip".
Utters a sneezing "ske-erch" call in alarm.
Vagrants here are usually silent. However, spring vagrants have been known to display, accompanied by a "chipp-a, chipp-a..." song.
Utters a rattling "tu-dlu" call, vaguely reminiscent of a Turnstone (Arenaria interpres).
Utters a shrill "kyeep" call.

Call is a series of 7 whistling notes.
Call is a high-pitched, trilling "brrrtt".
Call comprises a series of shrill "pee-pee-pee" whistling notes.
Call is a sharp "weet" or "peet-weet-weet..."
Utters a shrill "teweet-wheet" when flushed.
Utters a sharp "kyu-kyu" call.

Call is nasal and higher-pitched than other gulls.

Call is a rolling, trilling "prr-rrt", similar to, but slightly higher-pitched than that of European Bee-eater.
Utters a bubbling "pruuupp" call, often in flight.
Utters a diagnostic "hoo-poo-poo" call.

Call is a high-pitched, thin, whistling "tsiuu".
Utters a rolling "schrrrip" call, similar to that of a Skylark (Alauda arvensis) but more buzzy.
Utters a rolling, twittering "trrrrp" call.

Utters a sharp "chrrrp-chrrrp" call.
Call comprises a series of long, thin, whistling "weeeeeluu" notes.

Calls include various soft, twittering notes.
Vagrants here are mostly silent but have been heard to utter a harsh "chett" call.
Call is a disyllabic "hu-eet".
Call (best distinction from Western) is a single-note "tchip".
Call is a disyllabic , wagtail-like "tsiu-lii".
Call is a rather metallic, buzzing "przzz".
Vagrants are very vocal and utter an unmistakable drawn-out, disyllabic "tseu-eet". They also occasionally utter a monosyllabic "tsveet" call, very reminiscent of that of Coal Tit (Periparus ater).
Classic call is a shrill, monosyllabic "tsweet". Not all vagrants call; repertoire of some birds includes calls similar to Yellow-browed.
Vagrants are mostly silent but occasionally utter a soft "tchuee"call.
Call is a soft "chip".
Call is a sharp "tchek", similar to that of a Lesser Whitethroat (Sylvia curruca). Vagrants are usually vocal, often being detected initially by their call.
Forages among foliage, like a Chiffchaff.

Song has been likened to a mixture of those of Chiffchaf and Willow Warbler (P. trochilus): comprises Chiffchaff-like notes repeated more rapidly, with interspersed accelerated sections and whistling "chip-chip-chip-chuwee-chuwee-chuwee" notes. Call is a downslurred, piping "wee-eu".
Utters a rattling "tchrrrr" alarm call.
Call is a tongue-clicking "tzeck", like that of a Blackcap (S. atricapilla).
Call is a rolling, chattering "chrrrrr".
Utters a harsh "tcheck" call.
Call is a buzzing "drrrr".
Call is a "tzeck", like that of Blackcap (S. atricapilla). Song is a rapid series of chattering and warbling notes.
Calls include a churring "drr-rrr-rrr..." and a sharp "tzeck". Song is a rapid series of warbling and churring rattles, and whistling notes.
Utters a sharp, tongue-clicking "tcheck" alarm call.
Utters a sharp, tongue-clicking "tcheck" alarm call.
Call is a tongue-clicking "tchek".
Utters a sharp "tchak" note.
Call is a tongue-clicking "tchrrk".
Call is a tongue-clicking "tchik".
Call is a sharp "tchak". Song recalls a cross between that of Reed Warbler (Acrocephalus scirpaceus) and a Blackcap (Sylvia atricapilla).
Utters a sharp "tchet" or rattling "tee-ter-tlueet". Song is a rapid, fluty warble, with a rather 'nasal' tone; often includes elements of mimicry.
Utters a sharp "tchet" call. Song is a series of very rapid warbling phrases, less 'nasal' in tone than that of Icterine.
Calls include a soft "tchick", but vagrants here are typically silent.
Calls include a soft "tchick", but vagrants here are typically silent.
Song is a mechanical-sounding, endlessly repeated series of "tze-tze-tze..." notes. Call is a slightly buzzing "zrrr".
Song is an endless, rather mechanical-sounding rattle, reminiscent of a bush-cricket's 'song'; it is too high-pitched for many people to be able to hear. Call is a sharp "kvit".
Call is a shrill "tchip". Song is an endlessly repeated "tzip-tzip-tzip...", delivered in undulating (yoyo-like) flight.
Call is a tongue-clicking "tchak"
Call is a soft "tche". Song is a rapid series of warbling phrases containing mimicry of other bird songs.
Call is a tongue-clicking "tzeck", like a Blackcap (Sylvia atricapilla). Song (sung after dark) is a slowly delivered series of repeated phrases with much mimicry of other species.
Utters a sharp "tche" call. Song is rich and varied, and includes amazing mimicry of both other European songbirds and species from its African wintering grounds.
Call is a sharp "tchik". Song is slower and much louder than that of Reed, with a croaking, almost frog-like quality.
Utters piercing "tzeee" call notes.
Vagrants are silent.
Utters a rather piercing "zeeht" call, quite unlike that of a Treecreeper. Song is shorter and more piercing than that of Treecreeper.
Call is a muted "tchuck-tchuck".
Call is a sharp "quiirp".
Call is a rather nasal "piuup".
Call is a sharp "veer".
Calls include a sharp "puup", and a high, thin trill given in flight.
Call is a thin, Redwing-like "tsseer".
Calls include a "tchack-chack", like Fieldfare (T. pilaris).
Calls include a sharp "tchep-tchep-tchep..." and a shrill, buzzing "kveer".
Call is a shrill "tziit".
Vagrants here are silent.
Utters various Starling-like squawking and chattering calls.
Utters a whistling alarm call.
Vagrants here are mostly silent.
Utters a sharp "tchu".
Vagrants here are mostly silent.
Utters a thin, high-pitched, whistling "tsi-uu".
Utters a whistling alarm call. Song is less musical than that of Nightingale, but louder and with more 'throaty' whistles and more pronounced clicking trills.
Utters a sharp "tchick" call.
Calls include a soft, disyllabic "tchu-itt".
Utters a sharp "tik" call repeatedly when alarmed. Song comprises a series of whistling notes.
Utters a rattling call like that of Wren (Troglodytes troglodytes).
Loud buzzing call is quite different from Red-breasted's rattling call.
Utters a thin "tzii" call.
Calls include a shrill "wee-chuk", the last note like 2 stones being knocked together.
Calls include a flutey "tiu-tee"and a vibrant "wee-tchuk-tchuk", the latter notes like 2 stones being knocked together.
Utters a soft "huiit" call and a sharp ticking when alarmed.
Utters a whistling "svit", or "svit-it-it" call.
Utters a harsh "tchak" call, like 2 pebbles being knocked together.
Utters a loud buzzing call, and a whistling "wee-tchik", the last note like 2 stones being knocked together.
Calls include a chirruping buzz, and a shrill, whistling "tchweerp".
Calls include a sharp "tsik" and a whistling "tsee-a".
Calls include a sharp "tchiup".
Most sspp. utter a distinctive "tsree-ee" call. Call of Black-headed is a more rasping "brrzee-ee".
Flight call is a thin, buzzing "sreee".
Flight call is a diagnostic loud "pschreep", like that of a House Sparrow (Passer domesticus).
Calls include a shrill "tsche-erp" like that of Yellow Wagtail, and a "tchirrp" like that of House Sparrow (Passer domesticus).
Flight call is a loud "schreep", subtly softer than Richard's. Also utters a Yellow Wagtail-like "speeoo" call.
A buzzing, rattling "dzee".
Call is a thin "tseep".
Flight call is a thin, high-pitched "pssee".
Utters a single-note "pseet" call; tone recalls Meadow Pipit.
Utters a slightly trilling "drrrp" call.
Chirping calls are subtly higher-pitched than House Sparrow.
Utters a strange nasal bugling call, "neeerp", rather like a toy trumpet.

Calls include a silvery "diddle-iddle-lip" trill and a buzzing "de-drree". Song is a rapid jingling, recalling a speeded-up Corn Bunting (Emberiza calandra) song. Spring males sometimes sing from tall trees.
Utters a rattling "chek-chek-chek" call in flight.
Calls include a sharp "tchip-thip" and a nasal trumpeting note. Song is a series of vibrating trills and whistles.
Call is a loud "tchip-tchip". Song is a series of vibrating trills and whistles.
Call is a whistling "piew".
Utters a "tchu-ee" call like that of a Greenfinch (Chloris chloris). Song is a whistling "weed-ya, weed-ya, viu".
Call is a sharp "piik".
Utters a tongue-smacking "tchh-brrr" call.
Call is a thin "stip".
Call is a flat "cheerp".
Call is a sharp "pink".
Call is a sharp "cheenk".
Call is a tongue-smacking "tchht".
Call is a thin "tsi".
Utters a shrill, almost sparrow-like "tchiup". Song is a sweet-sounding "tswe-tswe-tswe-tswee" (likened by some to the start of Beethoven's 5th Symphony).
Calls include a thin "tsee", a tongue-clicking "tchiup" and a liquid "plett". Song is a rather rasping "tswe-tswe-tswe-tchue" (its tone is reminiscent of the song of a Yellowhammer, E. citrinella).
Call is a thin, shrill "tzik".
Call is a thin "tsip".
Call is a sharp "tzik".
Call is a sharp "tsick".
Calls include a thin "tzip".
Rasping "sziff" call is similar to that of Yellowhammer.
Song is a trilling mix of rasping, fluty notes, descending in pitch from start to finish. Calls include a shrill "tchiurp".
Calls include a sparrow-like "tchiurp".
Call is a rather harsh "tchukt". In flight, utters a distinctive "pink" call.
Call is a rattling "krrrk".
Utters a rattling call.
Call is a sharp "tsik".
Call is a thin, sharp "tzip".
Call is a sharp "tchak".
Call is a tongue-smacking "tchht".
Call is a tongue-smacking "tchet".
Call is a sharp "tzip".
Call is a thin "chip".
Call is a sharp "tsik".
Call is a sharp "tchup".
Call is a sharp "chip".
Call is a soft "tchep".
Cackling calls, breeding season only.
Loud wailing calls in breeding season.
Guttural croaks and honks in summer.
Far-carrying whinnying, usually when breeding.
Loud wails, and cackles.
Cackles and croons on breeding ledges.
Harsh honks and grating calls at colony.
Deep grunts at colony.
Harsh grunts at colony.
Distinctive 'foghorn' booming in breeding season.
Honks and shrieks in breeding season.
Amazing cacophony of honks and shrieks at nest, elsewhere typically frank if disturbed.
Rarely vocal: grunts and hisses at nest.
Rarely vocal: grunts at nest.
Goose-like honks and cackles.
Often silent, hisses, grunts in breeding territory.
Vocal; bugle-like whooping calls.
Vocal; distinctive "wink-wink-wink".
Vocal; high-pitched, musical yelping.
Vocal; cackling and gabbling calls indicate its ancestry of the farmyard goose
Strident "aah-honk".
Vocal; grumbling "rrruk".
Whistles and barking "ack-ack".
Drake has characteristic piercing whistle; duck a soft, low purr.
Rare; drake whistles softly, duck quacks.
Drake has distinctive bell-like call and harsh "krit"; duck a harsh quack.
Drake whistles quietly; duck quacks harshly.
Drake "tuk-tuk"; duck a quiet quack.
Drake has a distinctive crackling rattle; duck a short quack.
Rare; drake whistles, duck growls.
Rarely vocal; drake uses low whistle, duck a double quack.
Rarely vocal; drake uses soft whistle, duck a growl.
Croons and growls on breeding grounds.
Rarely vocal; nasal quacks or low growls.
Noisy; high-pitched goose-like honks.
Vocal; drake uses loud moaning crooning, duck harsh "corrr".
Harsh "kurr".
Rarely vocal; duck uses hoarse growl in flight.
Grunts while courting.
Normally silent.
NA
Rapid squeaky "kee-kee" or "kee-aa".
Chattering "kee-kee-kee", but rarely vocal.
Rarely heard "kee-yah".
Repetitive buzzard-like "tee-tee-teear".
Shrill "keck-keck-keck".
Chattering "kek-kek-kek" or "geck".
Sharp, fast "keck-keck-keck".
Distinctive far-carrying cat-like mewing.
Rarely vocal; "kaah".
Harsh "keck-keck".
Rarely vocal; whistling "tchew".
Shrill "kee-kee-kee", usually when breeding.
Chattering "kee-kee-kee".
Sharp "kew" and repetitive "ki-ki-ki".
Loud and distinctive *go-back-urrr*.
Croaking "arr-arr-kar-kar-kar".
Cacophonic croons and bubblings at lek.
Ventriloquial *wet-my-lips* call.
Distinctive "chuck, cuck-arr".
Distinctive, rusty "kirrrr-ick".
Ringing, far-carrying "kok-kok", followed by explosive wing claps.
Often noisy; pig-like grunts and squeals.
Loud, grating "crek-crek", heard early morning and late evening.
Fabulous wild trumpeting in flight, whooping calls on breeding grounds.
Varied ringing calls, including "whittuck".
Metallic and strident "kook" or "kowk".
Whining "coor-lee".
Strident pipings and "kleep" calls.
Vocal; strident yelping "kyip".
Vocal; distinctive "kloo-oot" and "kloo-eet".
Melodious "choo-wit", soft "wit-wit-wit".
Melodious "too-lee"; trilling song near nest.
Quiet, piping "tee-you"; trills near nest.
Sad but melodious "tloo-eee".
Plaintive "tee-loo-eee".
Very distinctive "pee-wit".
Occasional but distinctive grunt.
Repeated short sharp "quick".
Terse "chiff".
Distinctive trilling "chirrup".
Normally silent, occasional "wit-wit".
Purring trill in flight; nasal "shreeep" call.
Usually silent, but in evening calls a frog-like "orrrt-orrrt" and a sneezing high-pitched "tswick".
Usually silent.
Repeated "tick-er" in breeding season, harsh scarp when flushed. Tail feathers produce vibrant 'drumming' noise in diving display flight.
Usually silent, sometimes "chuk-uk".
Noisy "wicka-wicka-wicka" when breeding.
Rare; harsh "kirrick" when breeding.
Far-carrying piping whistle, several times in rapid succession: "pee-pee-pee-pee-pee-pee-pee".
"Coor-lee" at all times; bubbling song in display flight over breeding territory.
Explosive "chew-it".
Stridently vociferous 'sentinel of the marshes', shrieking calls and melodious variants on "tu-lee-lee".
Characteristically trisyllabic "tu-tu-tu".
"Tloot-weet-wit" on take-off; trilling song.
Distinctive staccato "tuk-uk-tuk".
Trilling "twee-wee-wee" call; high-pitched song based on "tittyweety" phrases.
"Chiff-if-if" on take-off; yodelling song.
A throaty, clucking "check" or "tyit".
Yelping "keeer" and laughing "kwaar"calls.
Harsh "kee-aar" over colonies.
At colony only, barking "tuk" or "uk-uk-uk", nasal "skeer".
Powerful throaty "kay-ow" and laughing cries.
Noisy, familiar laughing "kay-ow" or "yah-yah-yah" and mewing calls.
Gruff, powerful "kow-kow-kow".
High-pitched "key-yaa" and nasal "gah-gah-gah".
Noisy at colonies, diagnostic "kitti-wake".
High-pitched "kar-eee" and "kek-kek-kek".
Distincive and loud "kay-reck" or "kirr-ick".
Swift "kirri-kirri-kirri"; harsh "kee-aarh" with emphasis on second syllable.
Short sharp "kee-aah".
High-pitched "kitick", hurried "kirri-kirri-kirrick".
Rarely heard "krit" or "kreek".
Grumbling growls and croons on ledges, silent elsewhere.
Low growls.
Low growls.
Cuck-oo and variants, throaty chuckle; female uses bubbling trill.
Far-carrying monotonous and prolonged purring.
Monotonously repetitive "coo-coo-coo-coo".
Booming "coo-oo" or "coo-roo-oo".
Distinctive dry "aaah" in flight; song strident and persistent "coo-coo-coo".
Usually quiet; snoring noises near nest, occasional strident shriek elsewhere.
Distincive rapid series of short whistles.
Penetrating yelps and "poop" whistles.
Well-known trembling "whoo-hoo-hoooo" and sharp "kew-wit".
Repetitive deep "poop" calls when breeding.
Normally silent.
Repetitive abrupt whistle.
Listen for extended "churr"ing, with wing-claps in display flight. Best heard at dusk.
Distinctive shrill high-pitched scream.
Surprisingly loud, far-carrying and distinctive musical trill.
Extended musical twittering; sharp chirrup of alarm indicates presence of a raptor.
Soft rattling trill, sharp chirrup of alarm.
Harsh chirrup; unmusical twittering.
Distinctive shrill "tseet" or "chee-tee".
Listen for distinctive bell-like trilling "prrewit", often audible when birds are out of sight.
Soft, but penetrating, repeated "poo".
Persistent laughing "kee-kee-kee".
Distinctive ringing laugh "yah-yah-yah".
Harsh, far-carrying "klee-oh". Drums frequently, loud and slow rhythm.
Explosive "chack"; drums frequently.
Usually distinctive high-pitched, repetitive "kee-kee-kee". Extended high-pitched drumming frequent when breeding.
"Doo-dee-doo"; varied melodious song with mimicry, usually from ground or a post.
Listen for distinctive flight call "tee-lo-ee"; melodious song (in spiralling song flight) based on "loo-loo-yaa" phrases.
Flight call a liquid chirrup; varied musical song rich in mimicry, usually while hovering or circling high.
Distinctive "teees" flight call. Descending trilling song, ending in repeated "see-ar" notes, in parachute song flight.
Flight call a thin "tisseep" or "tseep"; song an accelerating descending trill, weaker than Tree Pipit.
Characteristic broad "tseep" flight call; song repetitive, reeling "seely-seely-seely".
Strident "zeep"; loud descending trill song in parachute display flight.
"Tseep" flight call; twittering song.
Characteristic "chee-seek" call; trilling song resembles Blue Tit.
Soft disyllabic "swee-eep"; twittering song.
Characteristic bell-like trill.
Loud, distinctive "zit" or "zit-zit" call; both sexes produce warbling song.
Scolding "churr" call; amazingly loud boisterously musical song.
Strident piping "seek" call; brief but melodious snatches of song.
Fluid "hoo-eet" call; song rich and varied, long and melodious; listen for opening "pee-ooo" notes.
Sharp "tack" call; extended high-pitched melodious warbling song.
Sharp "tick" call; high-pitched warbling song.
Fluting "too-eet" call; brief, scratchy, but melodious song, ending in a rattle.
Sharp "tack" call; brief rattling fast warbling song.
Harsh "teck" call; brief high-pitched warble of song, usually produced in song-flight.
Frequent "tchack" call; brief high-pitched scratchy warble song, often in song-flight.
Harsh "tack"; brief scratchy warble of song, often produced in flight.
"Tchack" call; brief high-pitched scratchy warbling song.
"Chack" or "chack-chack" calls; song loud, simple, but melodious "chew-you, chew-you".
Penetrating "pink" or "chink" calls; extended fluting and melodious song. Chooses prominent song-posts.
Sharp "tchick" call; loud musical song, often from prominent song-post.
Distinctive loud "chack-chack-chack" calls; song a scratchy poorly-formed warble.
Thin "seep" call; song usually a series of musical notes characteristically each repeated two or three times. Perched prominently to sing.
Extended "see-eep" flight call, especially migration. Song, fluting notes in slow tempo.
Extended and angry-sounding churring rattle. Song melodious, simple and measured, often in early spring, uses prominent perches.
Very distinctive, explosive "chink, cher-chink" notes and tack calls.
Characteristic high-pitched extended trill, often lasting for minutes, similar to an unreeling fishing line.
