Reeling "churr" similar to Grasshopper Warbler, but lower-pitched and in shorter bursts. Ventriloquial, sings from reed stems.
Vocal; rapid metallic repetitive jingling, twangy and chattering notes. "Tuck" alarm call.

"Churr" of alarm. Song extended, repetitive, more musical than Sedge Warbler. Similar Marsh Warbler (A. palustris) of central, N and NE Europe best identified by fluid musical song with much mimicry; often in bushy habitat.
Noisy; repetitive grating and metallic "gurk-gurk-gurk", "karra-karra-karra" etc. Sings from reed stems.
Hard "tack" call; extended jingling song.
Loud "chuck" or "churr"; brief soft scratchy warbling song.
Scolding chattering call; song a mixture of scratchy and melodious phrases, usually in bouncing song flight over scrub.
Sharp "tchack" call; song in SW race repetitive, coarse and unmelodious, in SE race loud, fluting and melodious.
Abrupt "tack" call; distinctive song: a brief warble followed by a repetitive single-note rattle similar to Yellowhammer.
Harsh "tzchack" call; distinctive song, produced in song flight above vegetation: a rapid but cheerfully scratchy warble.
Abrupt "tack" call; distinctive song: an extended melodious warble, sometimes considered second only to Nightingale.
Abrupt "tack" call; distinctive song: a melodious warble, briefer than Garden Warbler, usually ending with a phrase rising in pitch.
Soft plaintive "who-eet" call; song a slow, measured trill.
Call "peeu" or "deeoo"; distinctive song: opens with a couple of "pee-oo" notes accelerates into a cascading torrent of "sip" note, often during song flight.
"Hoo-eet" call; song an unmistakable series of explosive "chiff" and "chaff" notes.
"Hoo-eet" call; song distinctive, a melodious, sparkling, descending, warbling trill ending in a flourish.
Very high-pitched "tseee" call; song a series of high-pitched descending "see" notes ending in a flourish.
Very shrill, high-pitched "tzee" call; song a monotonous accelerating series of "see" notes, lacking final flourish of Goldcrest.
Listen for distinctive "zzit" call; short squeaky song.
Brisk "witt" call; brief, unmelodious rattling song.
Noisy: thin "see-see-see" and low "tupp" calls between flock members. Rarely-heard jangling song.
Listen for frequent characteristic "ping" calls. Rarely-heard song an undistinguished rattle.
Explosive "pit-choo" call; song a bell-like "pitchawee-oo".
Repetitive "dee", "chay" or "eez" notes in call; song a musical warble.
Call characteristic purring "chirr"; song a high-pitched, repeated series of "tsee" notes.
High-pitched "zeet" call; song a distinctive repeated series of "wheat-zee" phrases.
"See-see-see-sit" call; song an accelerating trill after "see-see-see" notes.
Vocal, calls very varied: "chink" most common. Song also varied, characteristic *teacher-teacher* and *see-saw* phrases.
Distinctive ringing "chwit"; whistling "too-wee, too-wee" song.
Sharp, shrill "zeee" call; song distinctive descending trill with final flourish.
Very characteristic fluting "wheela-wee-oo"and "too-loo-ee" calls.
Vocal; harsh "skaark" call; rarely heard soft chattering song.
Harsh "chack" call; unexpected melodious warbling song.
Harsh "chek" call; jangling song.
Vocal; harsh "skaark" and growling calls; jangling squeaky song.
Harsh "chack" calls and chuckles; rarely heard quiet musical warbling song.
Vocal; far-carrying "chee-up" or "skreee".
Metallic "jack", also high-pitched "keeaa".
Vocal; raucous "kaar".
Deep harsh "korr".
Gruff "pruuk" and resonant "gronk".
Vocal; harsh shrieking calls, song full of chattering notes and mimicry of other birds.
Harsh "chirrup"; often repetitive.
Distinctively liquid "tek" and "tchup" calls.
Ringing "pink" call; song a powerful cascade of rich nodes ending in a flourish.
Drawn-out "chwaay" flight call; simple slow repetitive song based on "twee" notes.
"Churr-lit" flight call and distinctive but monotonous jingling song.
Drawn-out "dweeee" call; purring song in display flight with exaggerated wingbeats.
Sharp "dee-dee-lit" call; prolonged tinkling jingle of a song.
Flight call extended "chwee-ooo"; prolonged twittering song.
Loud sweet call; twittering song.
Nasal "chway" or "chweet"; musical jingling song.
"Chee-chee-chit" call; purring trill of song as circles high over trees.
Metallic "jip" or "jup" call; abrupt twittering song.
Whistling "peeeuu". Song a very quiet warble.
Explosive Robin-like "zik" call. Song a rarely-heard twittering warble.
Plaintive "sweet" and "tew" calls; fast-moving Skylark-like song.
Abrupt "twick" call; familiar song, a rattle of "zit" notes ending in a drawn-out wheezing "tzeeee".
High-pitched soft "tsip" call; song a monotonous rattle of "zit" notes, lacking final "tzeee" of Yellowhammer.
"Pwit", "tlip" or "chew" flight calls; slow rasping song of several "zeeu" notes.
"Seep" and measured "see-you" calls; song a short, harsh and disjointed jangle.
"Tsip" or "quit" call; song unmistakable grating metallic harsh jangle, from prominent perch.
A loud, deep and gruff croak, often uttered in flight.
A high-pitched, repetitive "kew-kew-kew-kew-kew", mainly uttered during the breeding season.
A far-carrying, high-pitched and repetitive "kee-kee-kee", often uttered in flight.
A range of clucking calls, including a repetitive "ki-ki-ki-kik".
A range of noisy calls, especially when in groups.
A familiar, three noted cooing sound.
A soft pair of notes, repeated several times. Less raucous than its relatives.
A distinctive, monotonous, five-note call: "coo-COO-coo, coo-coo" - with the stress on the second syllable. One of the most familiar sounds of our towns and suburbs.
A distinctive, though rather monotonous, three-noted call, "coo-COO-coo", with the stress on the middle syllable.
A loud, high-pitched screech, usually uttered as a contact call in flight. Can also utter a repeated call reminiscent of that of the Green Woodpecker.
Distinctive, haunting, hooting call, and piercing "kee-wick", with stress on second note.
Distinctive screaming, which in the past earned them the nickname of 'devil bird'. Most obvious at dusk.
A high-pitched whistling call.
A loud, powerful series of high-pitched notes, reminiscent of a laughing sound, and giving the species the country name of 'Yaffle'. Said to call more just before the rain!
Loud, far carrying drumming in spring; also distinctive, resonant "chip" call, which often draws your attention to its presence high in a tree.
Quiet, gentle drumming. High-pitched repetitive call - a weak "kee-kee-kee-kee".
Series of chattering notes, usually given in flight. Also a high-pitched "chit".
A rapid series of high-pitched, twittering sounds; also a sharp, loud "prrrit" call.
A loud, piercing two-note call, similar to Pied Wagtail's, but sharper and more metallic in sound.
A loud, distinctive two note call, usually written "chis-ick", with the emphasis on the second syllable.
A quiet, delicate trilling call, often uttered by several birds at once.
Extraordinarily loud and piercing song: full of trills and ending with a rapid series of notes. Call a loud "tic".
Rather monotonous song; a soft warble with no clear beginning or end.
Beautiful, plaintive song; sung in sweet phrases. Robins sing all year round as they defend autumn and winter territories. Variety of calls including sharp "tic".
Distinctive, tuneful song, with rich tone and clear phrases. Variety of calls, such as the chattering alarm when flushed.
A loud, harsh and repetitive "chack" call, often given in flight.
Rich, tuneful and melodic song, with clear groups and phrases, usually in threes.
A thin, high-pitched call, generally given in flight. Listen out for migrating redwings during clear autumn nights as they pass overhead, often in quite large flocks.
Song like a cross between Song Thrush and Blackbird, with the repetition of the former and rich tone of the latter. Harsh rattling call, usually given in flight.
A variety of vocalisations, including a fast, chattering warble and several harsh calls.
Song very easily confused with that of the Blackcap, its close relative. With practice, can be told apart by faster pace and less fluty tone.
Distinctive, fluty song, reminiscent of Blackbird in tone but at a higher pitch. Call a hard "tac".
The famous repeated phrase of two notes: "chiff" and "chaff"! Also distinctive "hoo-eeet" call.
Thin, high-pitched "see-see-see" call often the first indication of its presence. Song a distinctive, high-pitched phrase, with a rapid rhythm on three repeated notes.
Series of high pitched squeaky notes, delivered from a perch on a branch.
Distinctive high-pitched contact call, repeated to keep in touch with other members of its flock.
Song a repeated phrase of notes rather like Blue Tit. Call an explosive "pit-choo" - often the best indication of its presence.
Rhythmic song rather like gentle version of Great Tit. Calls a series of thin, high-pitched squeaks, inaudible to some human ears.
A variety of chattering calls and song, with trills and scolding sounds, often used in contact calls with other members of a flock.
The repetitive and strident *tea-cher, tea-cher* is its best known sound; along with a bewilderingly wide variety of other calls.
Loud, echoing "pee-uu" call, often the best way to detect the bird's presence, especially in spring.
A thin, very high-pitched trill, easily overlooked. Call a high pitched "tsee".
A harsh screech; also a mewing call rather like that of the Buzzard.
A loud, harsh and familiar rattle, like a child imitating a machine gun!
A distinctive "chak", often followed by a gentler second note, usually uttered in flight.
A harsh cawing sound, often uttered in flight.
Starlings are great mimics, able to imitate many other birds as well as artificial sounds such as mobile phones and car alarms!
A characteristic chirping - a familiar sound of built-up areas.
A distinctive song, described as sounding like a fast bowler running up to make a delivery! Variety of calls including "pink".
Two calls: a gentle "chuck-chuck", and a harsher, squeaky "wee-eek".
A variety of wheezing and twittering calls. Song a combination of trills, whistles and twitters rather like that of a Canary.
Musical twittering songs and calls, with trills, creating a delightful sound.
Song a rapid series of twitters, trills and wheezy notes, rather like that of Greenfinch. Also a number of "wheey" calls.

The Linnet's song is a delightful, melodious series of twitters and whistles, which made it deservedly popular as a Victorian cagebird. Call a soft twitter, often uttered in flight as it passes overhead.
Song a selection of rapid, staccato notes like typewriter keys; also gives a range of trills and whistling calls, often in flight.
A gentle, piping "piu". Song an extended version of this, with additional wheezing and piping notes.
Best located by its very loud flight call: an explosive "zik".
Song unmistakable: the famous *a little bit of bread and no cheeeeese*!
A monotonous, flatly toned call and song, consisting of the same note repeated at brief intervals, in a hesitant and rather bored manner!
Variety of loud, nasal calls, often given in display.
Rapid, staccato call - sounds like high pitched laughing.
Throaty calls uttered at nest site; otherwise mainly silent.
Generally silent - apart from hissing if approached!
Loud, deep honking call, often uttered in flight.
A loud, raucous honking - the classic goose sound!
Weird range of quacks, hisses and trumpeting calls. Generally silent while feeding.
Female has familiar quack. Male's call a quieter grunt or wheeze.
Fairly quiet - occasional soft quacks.
Male gives distinctive and evocative whistling call, often in flight.
Male has deep croak; female a more chattering quack.
Male gives high-pitched whistle.
Fairly quiet - various calls when breeding.
Calls mostly weak and hard to hear at any distance.
Various whistling calls, generally used in courtship.
Mainly silent, but during display male utters rattling sounds.
A plaintive, far carrying mewing call, usually given in flight.
Rarely calls apart from near nest.
Rapid, repeated "kew kew kew" call.
Loud, far-carrying croaking call.
A series of odd but distinctive single note calls.
A mewing call that gives it the alternative name 'Mew Gull'.
The classic honking 'seagull' call.
Similar to Herring Gull, but slightly deeper in tone.
Loud, high-pitched screech.
Unmistakable outpouring of rich, powerful song, which seems to go on forever.
A harsh twittering series of notes, delivered in flight.
Call a long, drawn out "tsweep".
Call a thin "seep", often given in flight; song a jumbled series of notes often delivered in parachuting song flight.
A beautiful, rather plaintive song, with a series of notes descending in scale.
Usually silent, apart from loud bill clattering when pair meets at nest.
A distinctive, far-carrying and repetitive "poo, poo, poo" which gives the species its name.
Repeated "kee-kee-kee", rather like a Kestrel.
Varied song full of long, fluty notes, and including mimicry of many other species.
A stunning and varied collection of remarkable sounds - must be heard to be appreciated!
Quiet, fairly rapid warble, reminiscent of ball bearings being clattered together.
Song a series of high-pitched repeated notes, lacking rhythm of Goldcrest. Call, a high-pitched "zit".
Similar to Treecreeper, but louder and more forceful.
A lyrical and fluty series of four notes: "we-la-wee-oo" - once heard, never forgotten.
Loud, raucous cawing sound, usually uttered in flight.
A distinctive jangling sound, quite like that of Corn Bunting.
A deep, barking "kwow"; in flight, "ga-ga-ga", like a goose.
A repeated, quacking "kwuck"; also a high, thin wail.
A deep "har-arr" or "er-wick", mainly during the courtship period.
Whistling notes that sound like "poo-eep".
A trilling "whit, whit".
At the breeding grounds, rasping, buzzing and grunting sounds such as "hikav", "ti-ti-tihk-ti-ti-tihk", "arrr-r-r-r".
Various crooning and crowing notes.
A hoarse, chuckling "ag-ag-ag-arrr".
Usually a barking sound "arrah" and similar noises.
Various guttural groans.
Usual note a loud, rasping croak.
Bellowing notes such as "wo-wo-wo", "kh-kh-kh".
Numerous croaking and retching notes.
Calls sound like "rrank".
A croaking "kark".
A far-reaching cry that sounds like "guark".
A variety of short, croaking notes.
A deep "woomp", sometimes also "aark".
Clapping of the bill; the young make mewing sounds.
Hissing sounds resembling "feeoo".
Deep, hoarse notes and also bill-clapping.
Resembles the cackling of geese. In flight, "ar-honk".
A hissing sound.
Loud, whooping sounds, reminiscent of bugles.
Musical notes reminiscent of bugles.
Low, honking notes such as "ung-unk".
High-pitched notes such as "lyo-lyok", "kow-lyow" and the like.
Male: a high-pitched "kyn-yn" or "kyn-yn-yn". Female: only "kow-yow".
The familiar "aahng-ung-ung".
A hoarse honking that sounds like "aa-honk".
Usually rapid, repeated barks.
Guttural sounds such as "rronk" or "rruk".
A characteristic, rapid call: "ak-ak-ak" or "ark, ark".
The male utters whistling notes that sound like "weeh-ooh"; the female a low, purring note.
The male utters whistling notes; the female's cry sounds like "kaaak-kaaak-kak-kak-kak".
The male's note is a ringing "krrit", the female utters a rapid, harsh quack.
The male utters a rattling noise, the female quacks.
The male's note is a whistling "yeeb"; the female quacks loudly.
The male utters a low whistle, the female a low quack.
The male's note is a deep "tuk-tuk"; the female's sounds like "woak"; neither is heard frequently.
A loud "whooo-eek" (female); a wheezy rising "jeeee" (male).
The male's call is a thin, hoarse note, the female makes a quacking or rasping sound.
The male's call consists of whistling notes: the female makes a harsh, growling noise.
The male utters short, whistling courtship notes; the female has a hoarse "arrr".
The male males a whistling note, the female's call is a low "karr-karr".
The male's call is a ringing "coo-roo-uh"; the female's a quacking "korr-r".
Male, a ringing call. Female, various rasping sounds.
The male's call is a whistling note "kiu" or "whur-er"; the female makes harsh, rasping sounds.
The male utters sounds like "qui-rrik", when courting "rrrr"; the female usually makes a low-pitched "grarr grarr".
Male has a rasping, disyllabic courtship note; the female's is generally "rock-rock-rock".
The male makes low-pitched, croaking sounds; the female's call sounds like "karr".
A hoarse, wheezing sound.
Usually only a hissing sound, sometimes also a wheezing sound.
A hissing or croaking sound.
Hoarse croaking or wheezing sounds.
A noisy "kya", and a few whistling notes.
A long, plaintive "pee-o".
Beside the nest, a repeated "liik-leek-leek"; when alarmed, "kew kew", also a soft, "keeow".
A lengthy "gig-gig-gig"; the young utter a piping "kee".
A trilling "hi-hi-heea".
A trilling "hihihihee".
A clear "kri, kri, kri", also a low-pitched "kra".
Clear call that sounds like "cac-cac-cac".
A high-pitched "kee-er" and also fast-repeated "kikiki".
During courtship the male's call is a ringing "quee-a"; the female makes a whistling "hieeh".
During the courtship flight the male's note sounds like "ke-ke-ke"; the female's call is a high-pitched "pee-e".
Like that of the hen harrier; in gliding flight "kek-kek-kek".
A short, cheeping whistle.
A short "keu" or "ket" or lengthy "kikiki".
A loud, clear sound resembling "kek-kek-kek", uttered repeatedly and a short "kiack".
High-pitched barking sounds.
Resembles that of the kestrel and sounds like "kikikiki". The female utters a slow "eep-eep".
A note that resembles the wryneck's and sounds like "kikikiki".
A clear "kee-kee-kee" and a more musical double note, "kee-lee".
A grating "krrr-ic" or "kar-wic".
Characteristic trisyllabic call of the male - "whic-whic-ic" - is heard over long distances until late summer.
The male's courting call is a harsh "korrk-kok".
A "chuck, chuck-er" call note, and an explosive "pitchi-i" alarm signal; also a variable "tschreck".
The male utters a sound resembling "kraar".
The male's courting call begins with a rapidly accelerating "tik-up, tik-up, tik-up", ending with a "pop", followed by hissing and whispering; the hen's call is a "kok-kok" resembling the pheasant's.
The male utters a sound resembling "tchu-swee" and a whistling sound when he takes to the air; the female's call is a loud "kok-kok".
Only the male makes the typical gobbling noises.
Loud trumpeting calls; in the vicinity of the nest, cries that sound like "kr-r-r".
A loud, clear resonant whoop.
"Krruih", and a much-repeated "pit"; during the courtship display, "gep-gep-gep" followed by a ringing "krui, krui, krui" and "kik, kik, kik".
During the nesting period, a whistling "whiit", especially in the evening and at night.
The song "rerrp rerrp rerrp...", carries a great distance, especially at night
"Kr-r-rk", or a note that sounds like "kittick".
A clear "tewk" or "kt-kowk"; also a short, sharp "skik".
Low, bellowing sounds.
A loud "pic, pic, pic"; when courting piping trills.
A ringing "peese-weet"; during courtship display, "pee-r-weet".
A mellow call that sounds like "too-li"; when courting, a repeated "quitu-weeoo".
A whistling "tee-u"; when alarmed, "tree-a".
Delicate sounds such as "wit-wit-wit" and a flutey "poo-eef"; when courting, trills such as "tritritritritrirr".
Delicate, flutey note that sound like "titi-ri-titi-ri".
A flutey "tlu-i"; when courting, "tirr-peeoo" and similar noises.
Abruptly uttered notes: "tuk-a-tuk" or "khikhikikikiki".
On the ground makes sounds like "chic-ka".
During the courting season the male utters a soft croaking "orrrt-orrrt" and a sneezing "tsiwick".
A flutey call such as "cour-li", which may be heard throughout the year.
Flutey notes.
A note that sounds like "reeka-reeka-reeka", repeated several times in succession.
A loud "tuinit"; also "chick-chick-chick".
A flutey "tleu-hu-hu"; when danger threatens, a note that sounds like "teuk" repeated several times in succession.
A loud "tew-tew-tew"; when courting, a flute-like "tew-i".
A flutey "weet-tluitt".
In flight, "twee-see-see"; during the courtship display a trilling "titti-weeti, titti-weeti".
When courting "tlea-tleea-tleea"; in flight, a sharp "chiff-iff-iff".
Flight note is a high-pitched "reer"; song is a purring trill.
Muttering sound when courting.
Short scratchy notes such as "whit" or "prip".
A high-pitched, flutey "kleep" or "kloo-it".
A sharp, loud cry that sounds like "kyip, kyip, kyip".
A wailing "coo-ree" or a high shrill "keerrr-eee".
A low-pitched "uk-uk-uk", when attacking, "tuk-tuk".
A guttural "eee-air".
Usually a harsh low-pitched "owk".
A deep, loud cry sounding like "goh-goh-goh".
A ringing "kyow", also "gah-gah-gah".
A high-pitched cry that sounds like "gah-gah-gah".
A repeated "kwarr" or short "kroup".
A not very loud "kek-kek-kek" or a whistling "kay-ee".
In the nesting grounds its call sounds like "kitti-wack" or "kaka-week".
A short "kreek" or "kitt".
A very deep "kaah" or "kraa-uh".
Usually "kree-err", also a short "kirri-kirri".
A short call that sounds like "kee-kee" or "kria".
A long "aak", soft "chu-ick", also "kekekekek".
A high-pitched "kree-ik" or harsh "kitt".
A harsh cry that sounds like "kirrik".
Long whistling notes.
A long "arrr" or "arra".
A whistling "arr".
Whistling notes and twittering trills.
Heard only occasionally on the breeding grounds, the call consists of notes that sound like "ow" or "arr".
A cooing note that sounds like "coo-roo-oo".
A cooing note that sounds like "cooo-coo, coo-coo, coo".
A long-drawn-out "roor-r-r".
A deep "coo-coo-coo"; in flight, a nasal "kwurr".
The male's call sounds like "cuc-coo", the female's like "kwickkwick-kwick"; the young produce a "tseetseetsee".
A long, wild shriek, also hissing, snapping and yapping notes.
A penetrating note which sounds like "coo-hu", and is sometimes followed by a guttural chuckle.
Characteristic hooting call that sounds like "oot-too-hoo, hoo-hoo".
A loud, repeated "krow-ow" or a repeated "rick".
A whistling note that sounds like "keeoo", "kitchick" or a bullfinch-like "whee-whee-whee".
A shrill "kiu", a sharp "werro" and similar sounds.
During the courting season "hoo-hoo-hoo, oo-oo-oo-oo"; sometimes also "kewick".
During the courting season a penetrating "oo-oo-oo"; also semi-whistling sounds.
A deep "boo-boo" or "kee-aw".
The flight call is a soft "goo-ek"; the alarm call a high "quick-quick-quick" and the night song a loud rapid churring, rising and falling, which can last for as long as five minutes.
A shrill, piercing "screech" uttered in flight.
A delicate but sharp piping note.
In flight a lengthy "che-kee" or a short "chee".
In flight, "prruip".
A loud "kr-r-r-r-ak" or "krak-ak" like a crow's call, and a harsh chatter.
The characteristic "poo-poo-poo".
During the courtship period a very loud ringing "laugh"; the female's note is shorter and does not have the same ring.
A long drawn-out "kleea", a high, grating "krri-krri-krri", and in flight a ringing "choc-choc-choc".
A loud, tooting call.
A loud "kik" or "chick". In spring it drums with its beak on the trunks or branches of trees.
A repeated, high "pee-pee-pee". It may be heard drumming from early spring until autumn.
A repeated "kyee-kyee".
A characteristic "toolee" or "toolooeet".
A clear, liquid "chir-r-up".
In flight, a note that sounds like "tcherip".
A much-repeated "tswit, tswit".
A clear "tchirrip" or "tchichirrip".
A ringing, monosyllabic note, "tsweep".
Call-notes are more metallic than the pied wagtail's, alarm is a shrill "see-eet".
A lively "tchizzik"; alarm is an abrupt "tchik".
Rare and variable call notes such as "tsweep", "chup" and "chirrup".
When courting, a long drawn-out "teeze"; the alarm note is "sip sip sip".
Song sounds like "tseep...."; call resembles "tissip".
Courting note that sounds like "tseep-eep".
A harsh, grating "shack-shack" or "chee-uk".
A characteristic "shrek-shrek".
Call note is a weak trill, "zhree".
A short "zit".
A loud "tit-tit-tit" and twittering "tserr".
A high, piping "tseep" and trilling note.
Courting call is a note that sounds like "twhit".
Song similar to that of the reed warbler, but the sequences are more frequently repeated and sound like "tuc tuc tuc".
A loud "tchuc", "tweek", and similar sounds.
Not a very loud song - something like "chirruc-chirruc, jag-jag-jag".
Alarm note "karrr karrr".
A musical "deederoid" or "hoocet".
Call-note "check-check" also "tchur-r-r" and a faint "whit".
An emphatic "tac-tac".
A quiet but fast "wheet-wheet-whit-whit-whit", also a repeated "check".
Call notes like "tcharr" or "check".
A soft "hweet".
A bright "hooeet".
"Pru" or "whit whit whit".
A soft "zee-zee-zee" or louder "whit".
A rapid "tzee-tuc-ruc" and a grating "tzee".
A short "whit".
A liquid "wheet", short "tuc" and similar sounds.
Courting call "tac"; the song is a warbling "wheet".
A ringing "tic" or "tsip".
A sharp "tooick", a liquid "wheet" and "whee-tic-tic".
A stuttering "tititic" and a brief "tsip"; warning "fuid, teck-teck".
"Wheet-tsack-tsact" resembling two pebbles being knocked together.
A short "tic-tic" or "tu-tic-tic".
A hard "chack" or "weet-chack".
A hard "tu-tuc-tuc" and a thin "see-ip".
A loud "tchak-tchak-tchak", also "see see".
"Tchack tchak", when alarmed; also "terr terr", at night and in flight a clear "see-ip".
A clear, piping "pee-u" and a "tac-tac-tac" like the blackbird's.
"Tchink, tchink, tchink"; an anxious "tchook".
A liquid "tchuck" or "tchick", sometimes "dag-dag".
"Kwik, kwik, kwik" like blackbird.
Song composed of various melodies and whistling notes.
Courting note "cheen", alarm note "tching".
A repeated "tsirrup" and a weak "tsee-tsee-tsee" which may be heard even in flight.
A characteristic "tzee tzeetzee", but often only "cho-r-r".
In spring a characteristic "seetoo seetoo seetoo"; the courting call is a soft "sissi-sissi-sissi" and a scolding "chi-chi-chich".
Courting and alarm note is a repeated "eez-eez-eez" with a short "zi-zi-zi" in between. The male also makes a loud "day" sound.
A clear "tsink, tsink", "tchair, tchair" or "chi-chi-chi".
Varied call-notes like "tsee-tsee-tee-tsit".
A loud "pichew" or "piti-chewee", sometimes also "chick-adeedee-dee". It is, however, rarely heard.
In early spring a loud whistling that sounds like "chwit-shwit-chwit". Courting note is a "tsit-tsit" or a long trilling "chi-chi-chi" or "qui-qui-qui-qui".
Sounds resemble "tsee" or "tsit" but uttered only rarely.
A metallic "chip".
A weak "sip-sip".
Courting note that sounds like "chip".
A courting note that sounds like "tseek".
A loud "tsweet" and "ten".
A series of short, whistled notes.
Tinkling song - long, rapid and bubbling.
Song - flute-like, whistling notes repeated in series.
The familiar "chwink-chwink".
A metallic "tsweep"; also "tchuc".
Song - a repeated slow whistling note of several tones.
A rapid "si-twi-twi-twi" or a hard "chit-chit-chit".
A repeated short "chup" or "ten", also a rapid trill.
A frequently repeated, liquid, twittering "swilt-witt-witt-witt".
A sound resembling "tsy-zi"; in flight often "tsooet".
The characteristic flight call is a rapid "chuch-uch-uch" or "tiu-tiu-tiu". Alarm note is a plaintive "tsooeet".
Usual call "tseet" or a rapid twitter.
Sounds resemble "chip chip chip".
Sharp "ptik"; also a two-syllable "ptik-it" or "tzecip".
A soft, piping sound resembling "wheeb".
A loud "cheep", "chissis", and various twittering and chirping notes.
A short "chick" or "chop"; in flight, "tek tek".
A harsh, descending "tcheer".
Harsh, croaking calls like the jay's.
A penetrating "skraaak" and sometimes a mewing note.
A two-syllable, oft-repeated call that sounds like "jay jay".
Raucous, barking cries such as "chak-chak-chak".
Cry like that of the jay; call in spring sounds like "kror".
"Kyaw", like jackdaw, a characteristic "tchuff" and a gull-like "kwuk-uk-uk".
A clear, repeated "chak" also "kya". Imitations of other bird calls and even human words.
Usual notes "kaw" or "kaaa".
A deep "kraa" or croaking "keerk".
In flight, a deep, repeated "prruk", with a courting call sounding like "tok". Mimics various sounds, including the human voice.
Mostly silent, but makes a loud hiss when angry and other snorting sounds. Loud throbbing "waou waou" noise made by wings in flight. Young birds make a high-pitched whistle.
Call is a soft, mellow, yelping "oop, oop", or "hoo, hoo".
Loud whooping or trumpeting call.
Not as noisy as other geese - gives an "ung-ank" or an "ow, ow, ow, ow" call.
Call is higher pitched and less harsh than other geese - often an incessant and rather musical "wink, wink".
Cackling calls that are higher pitched than Greylag and with a laughing sound to them.
Loud cackling and honking calls - can sound rather like sheep at a distance.
Deep, resonant, trumpet-like calls.
Call is a single bark that is higher pitched than most other geese. Can resemble yapping of dogs, especially when heard from a distance.
The single "waruk" calls mix together in flocks to form a dog-like yelping or babbling that carries a long way, and the clamour grows louder as flocks take to the air.
Generally it is silent, but the male and female have different distinctive calls. The call of the male is a husky wheezing call, and the female makes a high-pitched "hur, hur, hur, hur".
Male usually silent or makes sweet-sounding whistles. The voice of the female is lower, giving a growling "ark-ark-ark" call.
Generally rather quiet. Male has quiet "took, took" call as rival males chase each other. Female makes a soft quacking sound.
Call of male is a far-carrying, musical, two-syllable whistle, "wee-ooo". Call of female is a rather harsh growl.
Generally less noisy than other ducks. Variety of calls similar to Mallard, but quieter. Male has a drawn-out "greee" and female has a series of deep quacks.
Usually rather silent. Male has a deep, rasping croak, often given in flight. Call of female more like a higher-pitched version of a Mallard's "quack".
Calls of female are varied and include the familiar "quack" that is often repeated many times in quick succession. Call of male is a quieter, low, rasping "crrrib".
Call of male is a piping, far-carrying whistle, "prip-prip". Female's call is a rapid, high-pitched quacking.
Calls of male include a dry rattle and a burping sound used in display. Female has a quiet "quack" like a Teal.
Usually rather silent. Displaying males have a variety of calls including a soft whistle. Female has a soft croak, often given in flight.
Usually silent except during courtship when male makes a soft, wheezing "wiwwierr".
Generally silent. Male has a soft, dove-like call during courtship and female has a low growl.
Male generally silent, except for a low whistle during courtship. Female makes a harsh "karr", especially in flight.
Silent for most of the year but male has a dove-like cooing call, "ar-ooo", when displaying.
Compared with other sea ducks the Long-tailed is quite noisy, with the yodelling calls of the males being made throughout the year and at any time of day or night. Female makes a low quacking.
Limited range of calls can be heard while birds are in flocks, especially during courtship, the most frequent being whistling and piping.
Generally rather quiet, but sometimes croaking or growling calls can be heard from flocks in winter.
Usually silent unless displaying. Loud "zeee-ZEEE" and quieter "rrrrrrrr" usually accompany displays of male.
Generally silent. The only calls are those associated with courtship or when alarmed. The most frequent calls have been variously described as creaking, grunting and rattling.
Usually silent, but makes rough croaking or rasping sounds, especially when displaying and nesting. Usually silent at other times.
Mostly silent. Some soft calls during courtship and occasional "growls" when disturbed.
Generally silent but during display there are non-vocal sounds associated with 'breast-beating' as well as various rattles, ticking noises and burps.

"Whip, whip-whip" (said to sound like *Wet my lips*) is the most commonly heard call. It is repeated up to eight times at a burst. The call may be heard at any time of day or night in spring, but especially around dawn and dusk. Males also have a curious little growling noise - like a cat.
Crowing call is a loud, gruff *go-back, back, back*. When disturbed will often make a sharp "kwok, kok-ok, ok".
Call of female is a high-pitched cooing. Male has series of loud and rapid clicks. Call is a harsh croak and rasping noises, and its alarm is a grating sound.
Mostly silent except around the lek. Male has loud pigeon-like "cook-roo". Female has loud crackle or "kok, kok" flight call.
At the lek the males have an amazing song that is a series of double "clicks" and ends in a loud "pop", likened to a champagne cork coming out of the bottle!
Can be quite noisy, with the adults giving a loud chuffing "chuck-chukka-chuff".
Grating "kerr-ick" given during day and night and especially around dawn and dusk. "Kip-ip-ip" fight call if disturbed.

Most usual crowing call is a far-carrying, resonant "kor-ork, -ok, -ok" often accompanied by energetic and noisy flapping of wings. This call is often heard at dusk and in response to sudden loud noises such as gunshots or thunder.
This species is seldom heard except for a crowing call during the breeding season that is a loud and metallic "chak" or "cha-chak".
Mostly silent except on breeding grounds where it has a loud, drawn-out wail.
It makes a variety of eerie yodelling calls in the breeding areas, but is mostly silent at other times.
Usually silent. At breeding sites it can be noisy, giving excited crescendo of calls like a high-pitched, wailing "ya-roo, ya-roo, ya-roo".
The most common call is a trilling, or whinny, that is used during courtship or territorial disputes. Sometimes given by a pair of birds as a duet.
Occasional growling "gorr, gorr", especially during courtship and when nesting.
Mostly silent. Surprisingly loud hooting or wailing song given in courtship and territorial encounters during the breeding season.
Mostly silent. It has a hard, guttural trill during courtship. It also has various threat and contact calls while breeding.
A chittering trill and a plaintive "wheeooo wheeooo" are heard at breeding sites. It is mostly silent at other times.
Mostly silent while at sea, but raucous calls and screams have been reported.
It is mostly silent away from its breeding colonies.
At sea it is generally silent. At the nest it has a variety of weird calls, including crowing, cooing, howls and screams.
Migrants are either silent or out of hearing range.
Usually silent except a breeding colonies where males make a far-carrying, purring "a-rrrrrr" call from their burrows.
Usually silent at sea. Loud calls at breeding colonies variously described as 'musical', 'crooning', 'churring' and 'purring' or a crowing "her-kitti-werke".
Noisy at breeding sites and in roosts. Loud guttural "agock-agock-agock" call made by adults, but mostly silent at other times.
Mostly silent. At nest it makes a series of grunts and clicks.
Pairs cackle to each other on their nests and feeding flocks cackle raucously - otherwise silent.
Dry, cackling calls from feeding groups. Noisy at colonies with growls, especially when greeting mates at the nest.
Usually silent except at breeding colonies when it makes a variety of croaking and quacking calls.
Away from breeding colonies and roosts it is often silent. Adult make a harsh croaking "rick-rack" call and a short harsh "raa" call when defending nesting areas from predators and rivals.
Generally silent. When breeding it may make low-pitched grunts or croaks and some deep cawing sounds.
Usually silent, apart from loud "frank" or "kaark" call, often given in flight. At nesting colony there are a variety of croaking calls.
Usually silent but does have a hoarse croak, rather like Grey Heron.

The "boom" of the male is heard from January to April, especially at dawn and dusk. The sound is rather like the noise that comes from blowing across the top of a glass bottle! It is resonant, and travels up to 5 km. It also gives a harsh "aark, aark".

In spring males call in early morning or late evening with a low, dog-like bark "hogh". This note may be repeated 25 times a minute for up to 30 minutes. A soft "quer, quer" is heard from adults approaching young, and young make a crow-like "kraar - kraar".
Generally silent; even in a nesting colony the main sounds are an occasional deep grunting and bill snapping.
Usually silent but near the nest a shrill "pieu-pieu-pieu".
Generally silent, but make a piping "pi-aa" in the breeding season.
Call a mewing "peee-uu", which may be hear at any time of the year.
The most frequent call is a far-carrying and rather mournful "peeeeooo".
Silent except when nesting when it makes rapid "yikkering" call during sky-dance display and various other scolding calls.
Generally silent, except when nesting. At nest it has a chattering "yick-yick-yick" call that is higher-pitched than that of a Hen Harrier.
Mostly silent, but during courtship displays the adults have wailing "kweooo" call.
The call is a shrill, mewing "peeee-ooow".
It makes a dog-like yapping, high-pitched woodpecker-like "kew, kew, kew, kew" and a quieter "ko-ko-ko". Most calls are made near the nest or during courtship.
Generally silent, but sometimes makes a "yelp"ing call.
Most calls are heard close to the nest or when displaying. The most frequent is "gek-gek-gek", which is also given when birds are alarmed.
Silent for most of the year. When nesting, most common call is a shrill "ke-ke-ke-ke".
Usually silent. Most common call is a shrill "kee-kee-kee" that is most usually heard near the nest.
Usually silent, but near the nest the shrill "kek-kek-kek-kek" call may be hear when the bird is excited or is chasing off intruders such as crows.
Usually silent except for shrill "kyew, kew, kew, kew, kew" calls made in the vicinity of the nest.
Usually silent, but may be noisy at nest. If female is disturbed she produces a grating "scraa, scraa, scraa", often building a crescendo. Male's call is higher.
Makes a variety of grunts and squeals during the day and night. Most obvious call is a drawn-out, squealing shriek rather like a piglet.

Usually silent during the day, but adults call at dusk and throughout the night in the spring. The call is a rapid "whit, whit", repeated at approximately 1 second intervals and likened to a whip cutting through the air.
Wide range of calls, the most familiar being a loud abrupt "kurr-uk" that seems to echo across the water. It makes other harsh, croaking calls.
The most usual call is a loud single note, "kowk", that may be heard during the day and at night.
The distinctive song, "crex-crex", is mostly heard at dusk and during the night. It has been likened to drawing a comb across a matchbox and is the origin of the Corncrake's scientific name.
A loud clanging, trumpeting note is given in flight and on the ground.
Usually a loud, shrill, piping "kleep, kleep".
Usually silent away from nest. Most common call is pleasant "clute, clute", which becomes more urgent and strident if the bird is seriously alarmed.
Wailing "coo-leee" call is reminiscent of a rather shrill Curlew. Vocal at night, especially dusk.
Not generally a noisy species, but if disturbed it makes a "wet-e-wee" call. Migrants make contact calls which carry a long way, "pilk, pilk, pilk" or a soft "kwip".
Most usual call heard from breeding birds is a loud "pee-u" that is often given in flight. It also makes a rapidly repeated "pip-pip-pip" and a repeated "greea" call during its songflight.
Call a distinctive low whistle, "toolip". Song during its display flight is yodelling "t'lew, t'lew, t'lew".
Most usual call I lonely-sounding "u-we". Songflight has a longer, far-carrying "per-we-oo-, per-weeoo".
Most usual call is a lonely-sounding and far-carrying "plu-oo-wee", often given in flight.
Call, from which it gets its alternative name of Peewit, is a rather wheezy, drawn-out "pee-wit". The song that accompanies its display is "pee-wit, wit, wit-eeze wit".
Generally very silent, even when lekking, but it can make a low "tu-wit" especially when disturbed.
Usual flight call is rough "treep". Display song on breeding grounds is a piping trill.
Most frequent call is a low-pitched "knut" and a higher-pitched "quick-ick", usually given when it takes flight.
When disturbed it will give a "chit" or "tit" cll that is repeated about three times.
When disturbed, takes off with a loud, dry trilling "tirr-tirrr-tirr".
The normal flight call is a dry, grating "kreet".
The most common flight call is a rippling, dry "chirrup".
Call given in flight or when flushed is a liquid "twick, twick".
When roding it has two to four frog-like croaks, followed by a thin but far-carrying "tsiwick, tsiwick".
Usually silent outside the breeding season. At nesting time it produces a range of display-flight calls including some sounding like a cantering horse - "kollarap, kollarap, kollarap".
In addition to drumming, it has a rapid "chip-er, chip-er" alarm call in spring, used in flight and when perched. It also makes a loud rasping "scaap" when disturbed.
Although usually silent, flocks sometimes make a Swallow-like twittering "wee-wit" as they take off.
Usual call in flight is a rather metallic, twittering "kit-it-it". It also has rippling song on breeding grounds that ends in rattling "quitta, quitta, quitta".
Most common call is loud clear "weeka-weeka-weeka".
Flight note in flocks is a low, nasal "kirruc, kirruc".

The commonly heard call is a rippling whistle "pe,pe,pe,pe,pe,pe,pe". Sometimes known as the "Seven Whistler" on account of the usual number of notes. On its breeding grounds it has a bubbling call, rather like a Curlew.
Common call is a distinctive "cour-eee" from which it gets its common name. In spring, songflight is accompanied with lonely-sounding, bubbling trill.
Usual flight call is a loud and distinctive "chu-it".
Noisy and nervous wader that alerts other birds to approaching danger with ringing "tew, tew" all. In spring, has a yodelling "tu-udle, tu-udle" that accompanies display flight.
Loud, ringing "tew, tew, tew" call is often given in flight. Also has a rich "ru-tu, ru-tu, ru-tu" song in spring.
Most common call is a rather dry "chiff-iff-iff", usually give in flight.
Call is a shrill "tee wee wee", usually given in flight as an alarm all. Song is a twittering version of the flight call.
When disturbed it frequently makes a distinctive "tweet, weet, weet" call in flight - the last two notes being higher-pitched.
Most common call is a sharp "twit", or "whit" given in fight or on the water.
Common call is a low "wit". Also a "zhit" call given when a bird is disturbed.
Generally silent. When breeding, most common call is mewing "ka-aaow".
Generally silent when not nesting.
Generally silent outside its breeding grounds.
Usually silent away from reeding grounds. Main calls are a loud "gek-gek" during attacks on intruders and a rolling "hah-hah-hah".
Most common call is a distinctive "kow-ah", deeper than that of Black-headed Gull.
The commonly heard call is a rather harsh "kree-aaa".
Includes the 'long call', throwing its head back in a series of cries, and a short "kyow, kyow, kyow".
The "kyow" call is more nasal and deeper than Herring Gull, rather similar to Lesser Black-backed.
The call is similar to that of a herring gull but more shrill.
Generally silent in winter. Its call sounds similar to that of the Herring Gull.
A rather gruff "kaw" and rough laughing cries, "ga ga gag".
Call is a rather gruff bark, "uk, uk, uk".
Call is higher-pitched than other gulls, an almost mewing "keee-ya".
Around its breeding cliffs, it shouts its "kitti-waaark" call from which it gets its name. At other times it is rather silent.
Not normally very vocal but has a "kek, kek, kek" call.
It has a single harsh note rather like an Arctic Tern's call.
Noisy, the most common call being a loud grating "keer-ick".
The calls include a loud "chew-ik" and a rasping "kraak".
Most common call is a loud, rasping "keee-yaah".
Call a slightly higher-pitched version of Common Tern's call, a harsh, scolding "kee-aar".
The most frequent call is a loud, shrill "kik-kik".
Usually silent, only very occasionally calling a sharp "kik, kik".
Usual call is a growling "arrrr".
The call is growling "caarrrrr" and the juvenile has a plaintive whistle.
Mostly silent, but makes a weak, high-pitched whistle "peeeeeh" at breeding sites.
Generally silent, but at the colonies it makes a low growling "arrrh" often repeated to sound like hoarse laughter.
It is usually away from its breeding grounds. At colonies it makes noisy chattering calls.
Call during display is a gentle "orr-roo-cooo".
The song is a soft, deep "ooo-woo, ooo-woo".
Call is a soft, restful "orr-oo-cooo, orr-oo-oo-coo".
It has a harsh, excited "kwur" call. The song is a loud and repetitive "coo-cooo-cuk, coo-cooo-cuk".
Song is a loud, lazy, cat-like purring that is given from a perch between May and July.
The call is a loud screech "kee-ak" that may be given from a perch, but is often made by flying birds.
The call of the male is the famous "cuc-oo". It also makes a harsh, laughing "gwork-gwork-gwork"
A piercing shriek, especially during courtship. Call for food is a loud "snore" made mainly by the young, but also by adults during courtship.

Song is the familiar hoot "hooo-hoo-hooo" of the male used to proclaim his territory and during courtship. Sings in late winter and again in Autumn. Female also has a hoarse version of the hoot. Another common call is a sharp "kee-wick",  made by both sexes. Occasionally calls during daylight.

Makes a wide variety of sounds. Song is a quiet but penetrating low "hoo-hoo-hoo-hoo". The small young have jingling calls, but later they make a drawn-out squeak that has been likened to a squeaky gate.
Usually silent, but has a low, hollow "boo-boo-boo-boo" and also a hoarse bark.
The most frequent call is a sharp, mewing "kiew, kiew" that is most common in March and April during courtship when the male also gives a pure, single hoot "woop".
Song is a long, drawn-out churring that rises and falls as the bird turns its head. Flight call is a loud, liquid-sounding "coo-lik".
Usual call is a harsh scream "screee".
Call is a soft, low, resonant "hoop, hoop, hoop" that carries a surprising distance.
Call is a shrill "chreee" or a double note "chee-kee".
A very vocal species that has a distinctive, far-carrying and rather liquid "pruuk-pruik" that may have a trill-like quality when several birds are calling at the same time.

The most usual call that is heard in spring at its breeding sites, and occasionally on migration, is a falcon-like "quee, quee, quee", which is far-carrying and often the only indication that a pair is present.
Call is a ringing, laughing "queu, queu, queu", and it also makes  feeble drumming.

Sharp and loud "kick kick" may be heard throughout the year and is often the best indication of the bird's presence. "Song" is an instrumental sound made by drumming with its bill on a branch. The short bursts of drumming last around 5 seconds and accelerate before fading away at the end. Most drumming takes place in late winter and early spring.

Call is a shrill "pee, pee, pee" rather like the weak call of a Kestrel. Drumming, heard from February to April and occasionally in autumn, is longer but more rattling and softer than that of the Great Spotted. It does not drop in pitch and fade away like Great Spotted. Alarm call is a quiet, soft "kick".

Song may be heard by day or night from January until August, and especially between March and June. It also sings in the autumn. Song is attractive, sweeter and more musical than a Skylark's song and includes fluty "lu-lu-lu" notes. Also a "titloo-leet" flight or alarm call.
Chief call is a loud "chirrup" often given in flight or when it is alarmed. Song is a long pleasant liquid warbling, usually given in flight, but sometimes from a perch or from the ground.
Voice in winter flocks is a shrill "tsee-tsi". On breeding grounds has a warbling Skylark-like song usually given in flight.
Song is a harsh rattling or twittering, given frquently in flight and also when perched. The song is usually associated with courtship, but is also heard at other times.
The alarm call is a loud "tswit" which is often give in flight. The song is a hurried dry twittering trill.
The main call is a hard "prrit" and the song is a soft twittering that is heard during the summer.
The call is a sharp "teeze", often given in flight. Song may be given from a perch

In flight it usually strings three calls together, "sweet-sweet-sweet". Song is given during the aerial display and is a series of plaintive and accelerating "seep, seep" followed by repeated "tseut, tseut" and ending with a trill.
Call is intermediate between the Meadow and Rock Pipit, a loud "weest". The song (unusual in Britain) is loud and slightly more musical than a Meadow Pipit.

The call is "pseep", more metallic and less squeaky than a Meadow Pipit and often given singly. The song is similar to that of a Meadow Pipit, but is stronger and with a more obvious trill. The song is mainly heard between March and July.
Call is a loud "psweep" that is given in flight and from a perch. Sings from May until July. Song is a variation on the call, interspersed with a rather feeble warble.
Usual call is a loud, hard, sharp "tswick" that is shorter than the Pied Wagtail. Song, heard mainly between March and May, is a quiet trilling and quite melodious, given in flight or when perched.
Usual call is a sharp "twissi-vit"or "chizwit" that is often given in flight. Song is quiet twittering interspersed with occasional call notes.

Call, frequently given in flight, is a sharp "zit, zit" that carries above the sound of the river. Song is a sweet rippling warble, heard mainly September and October and again January-March, but also at other times.

Call is a loud "tic-tic-tic" that has rattling quality. Song is powerful for such a diminutive bird, and it trembles as it sings a cascade of notes, generally ending with a loud and distinctive trill.

Call is a shrill, piping "tseep" that is also heard while the birds are displaying. The short, fast warble is often given from a prominent perch in low trees and bushes. Males sing in the winter but most song is heard between January and July. Males copy parts of neighbouring Dunnock's songs and incorporate them in to their own.

Call is an urgent "tic, tic" and a high-pitched "tsweee". Sings almost throughout the year (and sometimes at night near street lights). Song is varied and melodious and takes two distinct form. After autumn moult the song is rather sad and wistful, but from around Chistmas it becomes stronger, faster and more vigorous.

Song is a remarkable rich, mellow series of notes that is delivered powerfully at night when it is most obvious, but also frquently heard during the day. It is loud and flutey and there are occurring phrases including a distinctive rapid "chook, chook, chook, chook" and a plaintive "pioo, pioo". Song is normally heard only between April and early June. Call is a soft "hweet" similar to a Chiffchaff but louder. The other call is a hard "tacc, tacc".
Most common call is an urgent "tucc, tucc". Song is a short warble with some metallic jangles at the end. It is heard from March to July and sometimes in late summer.
Call a rather sweet, warbler-like "hooweet". Song a loud warble ending with distinctive mechanical jangle.
Call is a sharp "tic, tic", similar to, but not as hard as, the call of a Stonechat.

Call is a hard "hweet, chac, chac", the last two notes being remarkably similar to two pebbles being cocked together. The variable song is rather like that of a Dunnock and sometimes given during a short songflight.

Call is short, hard "tacc, tacc" or a plaintive warbler-like "hweet". Song may be given from a perch or in a short songflight and is a clear, repeated "zruu, zruu, zruu" accelerating and ranging up and down the scale. Mimics other species and other sounds.
Call is a hard "chack, chack". It also has a pleasant warbling song that is given on the ground or during a short songflight.
Call is a hard "tac, tac, tac" like the clicking of stones. Song is strong and flutey as it sings out a phrase of a few notes, pauses and sings another phrase. Quality is similar to a mistle thrush.

Noisy species wih a beautiful, mellow song that is a slow clear warble, which "tails off" at the end. If disturbed it makes a loud "tchook-tchook-tchook". At dusk many birds will give nervous "chink, chink, chink" calls. Song is mainly heard between March and July.
The call is a loud "chacker, chack, chack" and a nasal "ee-eep" often given in flight. Song is a rather feeble warble with several hard, harsh notes and not often heard in Britain or Ireland.
Soft thin "seeip" call, usually given in flight, is frequently heard after dark during migration. Song is variable and seldom heard in Britain or Ireland; it consists of jumbled, but repeated, notes.

Far-carrying musical song comprises a series of short phrases, each repeated 3-5 times. Pattern of song is distinctive; individuals may have a repertoire of 100 phrases. Sings during the day and also at dusk (and sometimes a night near street lights), after most other birds finish singing. It sings from March to July and again briefly in autumn and during mild winter weather. Flight call is a thin "tsic", not as hard as a Robin's "tick" alarm note. It can be heard at night as migrants pass over.

Call is a loud rattling and chattering, given when the bird is alarmed, but also when travelling in flocks. Song is powerful, rather like a Blackbird, but louder with repeated song phrases, with pauses between.
Call is a high-pitched, trilling "sirrrrr", like a bell.

The song is an amazingly powerful, far-carrying, almost explosive series of liquid notes "pwit, pity-chewit, chewit, chewit". The song is heard throughout the year and at night during the breeding season. Te call is an abrupt "chup" or "chip".

Song is a remarkable insect-like trill that can be sustained for several minutes or more without a break. Trill is uniform in pitch and has been likened to the mechanical sound made by an angler's reel. Volume appears to change as the bird turns its head while singing. Song comprises 26 double notes per second and is heard mainly between April and July, during the day and at night, and especially at dawn and dusk. The ability of humans to hear the song decreases with age!

Song is loud, strong and repetitive; a mixture of varied fast chattering phrases, sweeter-sounding notes and some mimicry hat often includes sparrow-like chirrups. Call is a scolding "tuk" or grating "chrirr". Sings during the day and sometimes at night.
Song is a noisy, unmusical, repetitive chatter and churring with frequent changes in pitch. It is more even, less varied and lower pitched than Sedge Warbler's song and full of "rrr" and "zzz"s.

Has a very different song from a Reed Warbler: a variety of rich and sweet phrases with some churring that is typical of this family, but without the harsh notes of the Sedge Warbler. Frquently mimics other species. One individual mimicked 70 different species within half an hour, and a total of 99 British species and 133 African species have been heard. Often there are imitations of Swallows, Greenfinches and Blue Tits mixed with African species, and all running up a musical scale.

Call is a short hard "teck", or a triple note "tec, tec, tec". Song is a musical "tey-te-dwee" that incorporates imitations of the songs and calls of other species. Song is similar to that of a Marsh Warbler, but is less rich and with phrases being repeated, especially a nasal "geeea".

Usually migrants are silent but sometimes utter a sparrow-like "cherrek". Territory-holding birds have a fast, rambling song - not very musical - which includes a rhythmic "ptss-chur-chur", a rising strong "kooeee, looeee" and a repeated "bi-doo", all interspersed with sparrow-like churrs.

Call is quite distinctive buzzing "tchirrr". The song is a "Whitethroat-like" warble, but more metallic and musical. Song is mostly given from a perch, but it may also be delivered during a short songflight.
Usually rather silent, but it makes tacking and churring calls similar to a Whitethroat, including a hard "charr" call and a two-note "tchad-tchad". One call is like a quiet Mistle Thrush's rattle.

Song usually delivered from within dense cover such as a bush or hedge. Call is a hard "tac, tac" rather like a Blackcap but shorter. Song is heard from late April to June and is a dry rattle on the same note, and is very similar to a Cirl Bunting's song or the beginning of a Yellowhammer's. At close quarters a more musical warble can be heard before the rattle, and often a quiet "stic, stic".
Common calls are hard "tacc, tacc" and scolding "churrrr". Song is a jumbe of unmusical phrases. Also has a more musical song sometimes heard early in the breeding season.

The sweet and melodic song is one of the most lovely sounds of summer. Similar to that of a Garden Warbler, but Blackcap has more obvious phrases, rich clear notes, varying tempo and generally ends with a flourish. Call is a hard "tack" and a grating "churr". Sometimes individuals will mimic songs and calls of other birds.

Song may be heard between April and July an attractive stream of sweet, musical phrases that is confusingly similar to that of a Blackcap. Tends to be more even, subdued and hurried in its delivery and carries on in the same way for a long time, often singing non-stop for a minute or more. Calls are a hard "tacc, tacc" and grating "churr".
The call is a high-pitched "chu-eep", which rises upwards.
The call is similar to that of a Coal Tit and is loud single rising note "suu-eet". Individuals often call repeatedly, especially if others are also calling in the locality.
Call is loud, rising "huitt" and the song a distinctive repeated "ip-zap zip-zap, zip-zap". Between song phrases it sometimes makes a much quieter "terric, terric" call.
The song is a pretty, liquid series of descending notes that starts softly and ends with a flourish. The common "hoo-ee" call is almost two notes run together.

Call is a loud, sweet sounding, rather plaintive "pew-pew". Song a remarkable series of "tsic, tsic" notes that accelerates into a shivering trill, with the bird trembling as it sings. Song is not usually given for a second time from the same perch and sometimes it will sing during its display flight. Also has a second song that is made up of the "pew" notes.

Call is a thin repeated "tzee" that has been likened to a squeaking wheelbarrow! The alarm is a sharper clicking "eez-tchick". Song is a rather quiet series of high-pitched notes and low scratchy warbles.
The usual call is a rattling note, rather like a Wren's. It also makes a loud sharp "chick".
Call is a sharp "whit" and also a "tic". Song is a simple series of rather sweet notes "suee-suee-sweet-sweet".
Call is a high-pitched, thin "tsee" that is useful for locating this species. Song is sometimes heard in winter and regularly from February. It is high-pitched, wheeling "tee-lee-de, tee-lee-de".

Usual call is a "zit", lower pitched than Goldcrest and often a single note whereas a Goldcrest usually runs three or more call notes together. Song is a succession of "zit" notes that get louder and faster. It is slightly slower and harsher than a Goldcrest's song and ends suddenly without a flourish. Song is most commonly heard in May and June.
Call is a metallic ringing "ping, ping" that may be given from cover, but also frquently by groups in flight. Song is a rather quiet twittering.
Common call is  thin, high-pitched "see, see, see" often interspersed with a short rolling "thrup". Song rarely heard - an elaborate version of the calls.

Call is a loud and clear "pit-chu", quite unlike the call of the Willow Tit, which is followed by "dee, dee". Song is a rapid series of a single or double "chip" notes that run into each other to become a rattle.
Call is a nasal "si, si, taah, taah, taah", very different from the call of the Marsh Tit. The sweet warbling song of slow descending whistling notes is not often heard.

Call is a thin high-pitched trill often repeated rhythmically. It is similar in quality to the call of a Long-tailed Tit, but sharper. It also makes a high-pitched "see, see, see" call. Song is combination of the various calls run together.
Many calls sound like a high-pitched Great Tit. Makes a thin "see, see, see" call and has a loud song that is a repetitive double note "pea-chew, pea-chew", but there is variety in these songs.

Call is a thin "see, see, see" and it has a churring alarm call that rises at the end. Song can be heard at any time of year, but particulary from late winter into summer. It is a "see, see, see-chu -chu -chu" and ending with a short trill.

Has a very wide variety of different songs and calls, and vocabulary is complex. Most familiar call is a sharp "chink", rather like a Chaffinch, and a scolding "cha-cha-cha" when alarmed. In flocks, makes a softer "tsee". Song is variations on *teacher-teacher* which has been likened to a squeaky bicycle pump and is heard between January and June, and sometimes in autumn.

Call is a loud "tuit, tuit, tuit-tuit" that becomes more strident when alarmed. This call is territorial and may be heard at any time of year. Also has a loud rattling "pee, pee, pee" trill that is most frequently heard in spring. Song is very varied and loud with whistling notes up and down the scale.
Call is a thin, high-pitched, wavering "tsee, tsee" call. Song is heard from February to April and again in autumn, a high-pitched trill followed by a warble that can be hard for humans to hear.
Call is a harsh "chack, chack". Song is a scratchy warbling, now hardly ever heard in Britain.
Although often silent its calls include a harsh "sheck, sheck" or a magpie-like chatter. Some calls resemble a Starling's wheezing call or the shriek of a Jay.
Song is a loud clear flute-like whistle "wee-la-weeo", sounding very tropical. Also makes various harsher calls, including chattering rather like a Jay, and a cat-like squawk.
Call is a harsh screech that travels considerable istance through the woods. It also has other, less obvious calls, including a mewing sound.
Frequently noisy with a "chackr, chacker, chacker" call that is both fast and scolding. It also has a commonly heard "cha-ka" call and a rarely heard, quiet, bubbling, repetitive song.
Usual calls have some of the qualities of a Jackdaw, but are less abrupt, higher pitched and slightly more musical, a drawn-out "kyaa" and "kyeow" being the most common.
Call is a familiar hard "tchack" from which it gets its name. Also makes a loud "ky-ow". When mobbing a predator its cawing "kaarr" calls sound rather like Rooks and Carrion Crows.
Most common call is a raucous "kaah". Song begins after moult has been comleted and consists of not very tuneful caws, croaks and squeaks.
Has a variety of calls including the deep and resonant "kaarr" and a hard "konk, konk", but not as resonant as a Raven.

Has a variety of calls including the deep and resonant "kaarr" and a hard "konk, konk", which may be harder and more rolling than that of a Carrion Crow - although this is difficult to detect as there is considerable variability between individual birds.
Voice is suitably powerful for such a large bird. Usual flight call is hollow-sounding "kronk, kronk" or an echoing "toc, toc, toc".

Has a "tcheerr" call. Both sexes sing throughout year, but especially before egg laying. Song consists of harsh and rattling notes, including wheezy warbling and musical whistles, and often incorporates calls of other birds such as chickens, curlews, ducks. Mimics noises such as telephones and car alarms. Song is often accompanied by a visual signal, when the throat feathers are ruffled and the wings waved energetically.
Makes several simple calls, and insistent chirping and churring notes. Song is monotonous repetition of a single chirp.
Basic call is a distinct "chip" that is higher-pitched than call of House Sparrow. Rudimentary song is a variation on call "chip, chip, chippi, chip".

Sings mainly between February and June. Song is short, fast and rather dry. It is a descending series of trills that accelerates and ends with a flourish. Call, which may be heard throughout the year, is a loud "pink, pink".
Call, heard both in flight and when perched, s a rising "tchway". Song, which is rarely heard in Britain or Ireland, is a slow, wheezing "dzwee".

Most common call is a fairly high-pitched, clear monotonous trilling "tirrilillit"or "prrrp" note, and also a harder two- or three-syllable "tchizzick", remininscent of the call of a Pied Wagtail. Young also make "zee" or "zit" notes. Song is a rapid stream of jingling notes.

Most common call , often given in flight, is a pleasant tinkling "whit-a-whit, whit", heard all year round and is often the best clue of the bird's presence. Song is a liquid tinkling with trills and more nasal notes.

Song is heard mainly between March and July. Makes a variety of wheezy notes and trills, repetitive "too-eee", and loud twittering trill that is often followed by a drawn-out wheezing "dzeee". In flight gives a repeated "chichichichi" and a dry "jup, jup, jup".
Call, frequently given in flight, is a clear, loud "tsuu" or a ringing "tszng". Song is a sweet twittering that includes a drawn-out wheeze.

Song of male, which may be heard at any time of year, but especially in spring, is a rather fast and pleasant warbling that has a slightly wheezy quality. Flight call is a rapid twittering "chi, chi, chi, chit".

Call usually incorporates a harsh "twaaay", similar to a Linnet but more "nasal". Also makes a more drawn-out "tchway" and "tchway-de-wee". Song is a variety of these individual notes, and not as well formed as that of Linnet.
Flight call is a purring trill. Its song incorporates the trill and a twittering "chi, chi, chi, chi" that is usually given in its songflight.
The call is a trilling "tji-tji-tji".
Call is a sharp "chip, chip, chip" and flocks make a loud crescendo of "chips". At dusk it makes a Blackbird-like "chink-chink". Song is an unremarkable soft twittering.
The call is a hard, sharp "chup, chup".
Similar to Crossbill although some observers have described a deeper emphatic "quop, quop" call. Song tends to be lower, slower and slightly better enunciated than the Crossbill.
Most usual call is a loud "chew-ee, chew-ee" like the contact calls of young Willow Warblers but louder and the first syllable harsher. Song is a simple but very variable "sit-too-swit-too".
Usual call soft but distinctive "peu, peu" and also quieter piping as birds keep contact in dense cover. Song is a quiet, creaking or piping warble and is seldom heard.
Most common call is a short "tic, tic", slightly harder than a Robin's alarm call. The rarely heard song is a slow "deek, waree, ree, ree".
Flight call is a distinctive dry, rattling "terrek". Sometimes it will make a Snow Bunting-like descending "teu" call. Song is quite musical and given during a songflight.
Call, usually heard in flight, is a rippling twittering "tirrirrirrip". There are calls that sound like "seu"and "sichew". Song is loud and musical and given from a perch or in flight.

Call is a sharp, clipped "zit" or soft "trillp". The famous "little-bit-of-bread-and-no-cheese" description of the song helps to describe the pace and form, which is variable, but tends to be a rapid succession of repeated notes with the last phrase drawn out into a long wheeze. Song is repeated monotonously during breeding season.

Call a rather thin, high-pitched "stic, stic", higher and more metallic than Yellowhammer. Song heard between February and September; a rattling trill of a single repeated note - quite similar to the song of a Lesser Whitethroat and not unlike a Yellowhammer's song, but lacking the "cheese" at the end.

Usual call is shrill "tsew" that is given in flight, and also a metallic "ching". Song is very simple an repetitive; it is a collection of a few metallic notes ending in an unremarkable flourish "tweek, tweek, tweek, titty-tweek".
The call is a shrill "tseeup" or a liquid "tip". The song resembles Beethoven's Fifth Symphony - a short, simple "dee, dee, dee, deee" with a flat note at the end.

Males with several mates sing more than males with only one. Song may start when males visit their territories in January or February and soon sing incessantly throughout the day. Song is an accelerating series of jangling notes that has been likened to jangling of keys. Call is a rather abrupt "quit".
Adults have a deep resonant call. Young beg with piping "ping-ping".
The call is a characteristic "kowak-kowak".
Call is low, nasal croak.
Call is deep rolling "krr-rr-rra".
Only sounds are coughs and bill-clappering.
Despite name, it hisses in threat and emits deep explosive "heeorr" call.
Calls are similar to Whooper's but higher-pitched. Groups chorus with crane-like drawn-out "klah" notes.
Flight call is characteristic "klo-klo-klo", but contact call is a loud melancholy bugle-like call.
The call of the Greylag is a deep honking.
Male has curious cricket-like "kirrip" call. Female replies with thin high guck.
Voice is familiar deep "quack quack".
Call is "quack" like domestic duck's.
Male's call is short whistled "kree".
The call is a plaintive "yek-yek-yek".
Call is sweet double whistle, "ti-yu, ti-yu".
Male gives harsh piercing calls.
Male's call is two-note explosive hacking followed by whirr of wings.
The voice is a loud, far-carrying double note, "taa-pwi", and curious warbling calls.
Gives loud trumpeting calls, "kay-yaw, kay-yaw", often from roost perch.
The calls are remarkable, with a monotonous "kee-wak, kee-wak", often at night, and loud cacophonous group calls.
The call is a bubbling "pyurrrk" or clucking "kreck, kreck, kreck, kreck".
Gives deep tooting calls.
The coot gives a variety of nasal explosive calls.
Pairs duet with clear far-carrying horn sound.
Call is a persistent "klit-klit-klit" similar to that of Pied Avocet; also gives tern-like cries, "kyee".
Makes frequent clear flutish calls, "kluit kluit kluit".
Call in flight is drawn-out "peeyoo".
Call is a shrill whistle.
Call is a series of loud screams, *did-he-do-it, pity-to-do-it*.
Characteristic call is shrill "ee-wit, ee-wit".
(...) mixes with Eurasian Curlew and has similar rising, plaintive "cur-li" call.
Voice is musical three-note call, "teu-hu-hu", with raised first note.
Call is a noisy, loud, ringing "tew" rapidly repeated three or more times.
Call is loud rapid shrill whinny.
Voice is a shrill "wee-wee-wee-wee".
Call is a shrill "eek eek".
Call is a rolling, screaming "krreeay".
Call a short "kek kek", less raucous than most terns.
Call is soft muffled cooing "druu-oo-u".
The call is a melodious "kroo kroo-kroo kroo".
The call is a deep "cru-u-u-u-u", repeated several times, with emphasis on first note.
The call is a melodious "ter-ku-koor".
The call is a long mournful note.
The call is a melodious, deep "click-hrooo".
The call is a high-pitched shrill whistle.
The call is a deep "glug glug glug".
Call is a harsh screech.
(...) with a characteristic soft, hollow "hoo-o", repeated several times per minute and with emphasis on the first note.
The call is a hollow poop.
Male gives duck-like alarm call, "krek-krek-krek". Female has a barked alarm call and also gives whistled "seeuee" calls.
The owlet calls repeatedly during daytime with an easily imitated call, "poop poop-a-poop".
Call is a loud piercing cry, "kee-kee-kee-kee".
The call is a shrill "peep peep" (...)
The call is a fast trilling "kerik-kerik-kerik".
The call is a harsh crow-like "chak chak".
The call is a soft double or triple "hoo-poo-(poo)" and harsh shrieks.
The call is a loud, far-carrying "wer-gok" (...)
The usual call is a constantly repeated cry like that of a cat, but the bird makes other calls including a loud rasp.
Voice is three-note whistle, "pu-wi-u", with raised second note.
Call is a sharp "wit-wit".
Call is hard "chissick".
Voice is repeated thin "tsee see tsee".
Calls with fluty cheerful phrase similar to those of other bulbuls.
The song is a soft, sweet simple phrase.
(...) noisy, lively groups (...) keep up a lively chattering or give rather non-musical repetitive phrases of simple song, "bulbi bulbit".
(...) give typical chattering chirps and simple-phrased non-musical calls.
The song is a sibilant monotnous three-note call, a rising three-note call and various mewing calls.
(...) has loud scolding notes and sharp ringing call, "tickety boo".
Calls variable, including loud squawks, witers and strident whistles.
It makes many loud lively calls, often imitating other species.
The call is a loud cheerful "che-wit, che-wit" and a melodious song, but the bird is also a good mimic of many other bird calls.
(...) has a loud, clear song and whistled call notes, often mimicking other birds' calls.
The call is a loud, clear and distinctive "pip" (...) and a sharp *be quick, be quick, be quick*, or loud mellow song.
Call is a monotonous, "zee dzit".
Has loud sweet song.
The call is a distinctive sweet trill.
Has a short sweet song.
Grating alarm call and simple "tchih tchih", given from prominent low perch.
Call a shrill, rather plaintive "t-e-e-e-".
Has a powerful sweet song.
(...) singing with a clear melodious voice. The alarm call is a harsh clicking.
The alarm call is a harsh click similar to magpie-robin's, but the song is much richer and more melodious.
Call is a penetrating harsh whistle, or a screech of alarm similar to that of forktail.
Rattling alarm call like Chinese Blackbird.
Call (...) is buzzing "dzee dzee".
Sweet song is less musical than that of European Blackbird, but rattling alarm call is much the same.
Call is a thin "tzee".
Alarm call is harsh screech like that of Blue Whistling-thrush.
Voice is a series of sharp chirps.
Varied calls include noisy repeated "ch-wee ch-wee ch-wee" and monotonous wren-like song.
Call is loud "chip chiwoo".
Song is a sweet shrill warble.
The call is a fine "zip" followed by a fast shrill trill.
Noisy, with regular chatter of sweet whistled *silly billy* and sharp, clear trilling and twittering.
Call is a clear whistle of three or four notes.
Call is thin, high-pitched "twee-twee-ee-twee", with second note highest.
Song is loud three-note whistle, *where are you*, with second note highest.
Call is a loud sweet warble.
Call is a soft chatter.
The usual call is a high-pitched, repeated "pink"; also gives low churring.
Call is a loud three-noted hoot, with last note lowest.
(...) has a loud, three-noted call with the last note being the highest.
Calls include loud treble chatter, chuckling call and occasional sharp notes.
The song is a low-pitched whistle, "sweep-sweep-sweep-sweep", with emphasis on first note; also rising sibilant call, "tzu-tzu-tzu", and excited chattering.
Voice is a churring and clear "prrreee-prrreee" call.
Call is a loud clear note.
The calls include chittering, churring, and a resonant series of "choonk" notes at about three per second.
Call is a twanging lively "pching" or twittering song.
Voice is a rapid loud mellow whistle of eight to ten notes on the same pitch, also group chittering.
Call is tiny continuous twittering.
Call is plaintive bleats and churring notes.
Call is a loud creaky wailing "ou-phee-ou-phee", repeated several times.
Groups maintain chattering calls, but also have various laughing calls and loud piercing contact note, "piew piew piew".
Calls include group mutterings and harsh chorus.
Lives in noisy groups which give loud maniacal cackling chorus, as well as various clear whistles and chatters.
Calls include squeaky contact notes, bursts of group laughter and short whistles.
It has a cackling group alarm call (...)
Calls less strident than most other laughingthrushes and include feeble chirps.
Call is a clear whistled song and harsh grating chorus.
The call is a clear loud whistle.
The species' song is even more melodious than that of the famous hwamei and sounds similar to the European Blackbird's (hence scientific name).
Has various ringing and buzzing calls and discordant group cackling.
The call is a loud, clear four-note whistle.
The call is a monotonous loud three-noted *to-wee-you*. Groups also give whirring alarm calls and emit constant harsh scolding notes (...)
The call is a loud musical "chi-chweeew" or "tu-reew-ri"; also makes low churring notes (...)
The bird gives clear loud calls.
A noisy flocking bird which gives a variety of loud descending whistles and rattling calls.
Lives in noisy chattering flocks (...)
Call is a loud but mournful "tu-tui-tui-tui-tuuui", rising then falling in pitch.
Voice is soft contact calls or harsh loud churring alarm notes.
Call is a loud, long two-note whistle, *see-saw*, repeated endlessly, rising in pitch at end of call.
Voice is a slurred whistle, "chu-u-wee, chu-u-wee", with second note falling, otherwise on rising pitch.
Has loud plaintive call of three or four notes.
Call is an agitated churring (...)
Call is five-note song with three notes on same pitch and last two lower.
Call is resonant repeated "fei fei fei...", rising at the end, or rattling "de de de de".
It has a loud, clear ringing call.
Voice is continuous "ser-weet ser-weet".
The call is a distinct nasal mewing.
Gives a short buzzing call note.
Emits constant squeaky chatter.
Call is very shrill "tweet tweet" and low churring notes.
The call is a thin metallic trill "seehwiwiwiwi". Birds also give dry churring calls and a high-pitched "seeh-seeh-seeh" (...)
Calls very variable and loud, including characteristic three-note "tee tee tu" with the stressed last note dipping and rising again.
Gives loud sharp "seet, seet" calls, scolding "twet-twet, twet" and musical whistled song.
Call is loud "cheet cheet".
The call is a quiet shrill note, "shweet".
(...) noisy chases, giving a characteristic sharp "cheet" call (...)
The call is a clear, fluty "we-weeleow" and harsh nasal mewing.
The call is similar to that of Black-naped Oriole, a three- or four-noted "tu-hu-a-yu".
(...) to scold with harsh strident calls.
(...) screeching, strident calls are similar to those of the Long-tailed Shrike (...)
Voice consists of harsh grating and scolding and loud metallic 'creaking-gate' calls.
Calls include a wide range of loud clear whistles and a musical song with harsh grating notes.
The call is a harsh shout, "ksher", or plaintive mewing.
Birds give harsh screeched contact calls plus a wide range of other calls and whistles.
Call is a harsh rolling "zhruee" or clear "kwee".
Call is raucous ringing "bo-a-link".
The species makes an amazing range of extraordinary cranking and honking calls and whistles.
Call is a rolling harsh cackle.
Call is a harsh sharp "kee-ach".
The call is a high-pitched rasping "ka" or lower-pitched "kowk".
The call is a harsh croaking "kraa".
The call is a harsh throaty "kwaa".
Call is shrill chatter (...)
The calls are harsh screeches and whistles.
Call is harsh screeches and whistles.
Call is harsh screeches and whistles.
Voice is harsh screeches, whistles and liquid gurgling notes.
Voice is loud and variable; it is a good mimic of other birds and can be taught to talk.
Call a very loud, piercing "tiong" and whistles; often mimics other birds calls.
Calls include a single "cheep", rapid "chit-chit-chit" or repeated song, "cheep-chirrup-cheweep".
The call is a chirpy hard "cheep cheep" (...)
Flight call is twittering "dzidzi-i-dzi-i". Song is like that of European Greenfinch.
Voice is soft "chi-chi-chi-chi", or song of "dui-dip-dip-dip".
The calls include loud sharp whistles, rapid piping and sharp buzzing "deep-deep, deep-de-de-de".
Call is loud nasal "schwenk" or longer "un di di di dit" song.
