loud, clear; the tune or pattern of notes is jerky, erratic; the notes are often abrupt, varying from hard, metallic noises and buzzing sounds to clear and musical notes. Some of the sounds have been appropriately described as like the dry squeaking of a metal cartwheel turning slowly on a rusty axle. The overall effect, however, is cheerful, pleasant and distinctive. While the song is varied, patterns become recognisable. A small typical sample--"skzit-kotch-zzweiler, chweeip, kzzeech-kotch-aweiler"--finishes with a musical trill and whipcrack. This song has resulted in the Brown Songlark being known to children as the "Skit, scot,a-wheeler".
contact call is a quite loud chirp. The song is a rising and falling sequence of clear, sweetly warbled notes; overall less plaintive than that of the Silvereye.

strong, high pitched, whistled contact or flocking calls, possibly louder than those of the Silvereye, and tinkling notes from foraging flocks. The song is strong, varied and tuneful with musical warbling and trills.

a clear, peevish "tseeep"; song a rather slow, erratic series of clear, sharp, slightly peevish notes: "tsweeip-cheeip, peeip-a-chweip, cheeip" with many slightly different variations in rambling sequence, often rather lengthy; there is a different, more hesitant version that is used at first light. In a softer, quieter sub-song, mimicry of some other birds may be included. Calls of western race, gouldi, are perhaps slightly more harsh.

usually silent, most likely to be heard at dawn or in dull weather. Song consists of three clear notes, the first level, the second rising briefly, the third again steady--"wheeer-aoo-whooo"--and may continue as a soft tuneful sub-song.
the call differs recognisably from that of the Bassian, described as two clear, whistled notes, the second lower, "wheee-rooo".
male sings almost continuously through the breeding season, a clear, spirited sequence of notes; mimics native birds. In contact and in flight, a thin "tsip".
low clucking sounds and a pleasant, reedy song.
a trilled, fluid, musical whistle in contact and advertisement of presence or territory, and much lively chattering, harsh scolding sounds in alarm or warning.

various nasal and wheezing calls--from individuals, "scriaarch, scraark, scraich-scraich-scraaairch, chrak-chrak-chrak" and similar sounds. From the flock, a jumbled racket of intermixed squawking and wheezing.
most characteristic call a long downwards whistle, and "chwee"; also high "tizz-tzz", and diverse wheezing, rattling and clicking noises; includes mimicry.

a mix of loud, clear and mellow whistles, especially a high, clear and vigorous "wheeoo, wheeoo, wheeoo" and contrasting harsh, rattling "carrarrk, carrarrk" and sharp "tseit-tseit". Gives a clear, liquid note on take off.
in contact, a high, fine "tseee", and harsh, almost screeching chatter of alarm when in flight. The song is a pleasant, mellow fluting sound with higher trills.
Call is a high-pitched, laughing "kah-lah-aluck"; calls of 'elgasi' described as hoarser and lower pitched than other ssp.
Calls said to be higher pitched than Taiga Bean-Goose.
Calls loud and deep, very different from Greater White-fronted.
NA
Gives single high-pitched calls.
Calls are higher pitched and delivered more rapidly than Snow Goose.
Calls include a high-pitched, hoarse "kla-ha". Less vocal than other geese.
High-pitched cackling.
Call is a low, rolling, slightly upslurred "raunk-raunk".
Males give hissing calls, females harsh quacking or trumpeting.
Call is a deep, musical "honk-a-lonk".
Calls of all ssp. are higher pitched than Canada Goose, some dramatically so; calls of 'hutchinsii' more similar to Canada Goose.
Call is a noisy, high-pitched whooping or yodeling.
Common call is a single or double "honk" like an old car horn.
Common call is a buglelike double note.
Gives a variety of hisses and snorts, but generally silent.
Call is a high-pitched, four-note whistle.
Call is a squealing "pe-chee".
Male gives a soft, upslurred whistle when swimming; female's squealing flight call is a rising "oo-eek".
NA
Male, a "quack" and rasping "kreep"; female, a series of "quack" notes.
Similar to Mallard.
Similar to Mallard.
NA
NA
NA
Male, a liquid "preep" or "krick"; female, a weak, high-pitched "quack".
NA
Male gives a piercing, three-note whistle; female call is a much lower "quack".
Male gives a whistled "wheeeeu", like American Wigeon but with two, not three, syllables, and even higher pitched.
NA
Male gives a whistled call, similar to Green-winged Teal; female gives a single or series of "quacks".
Male gives a two-syllable call; females gives a "quack".
Male gives a whistled "peeu"; female gives a nasal "quack".
Male gives a chattering call; female gives a nasal "quack".
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
Usually silent, in flight wings produce a loud whistling sound.
Male's call is a high-pitched nasal squeaking, but mostly silent, except during breeding season.
Loud, yodeling, three-part calls, heard all year.
Mostly silent, except during display.
Most vocal of the scoters. Drakes call even in winter; most frequent call is a prolonged and plaintive whistle.
Whistle note of male much shorter and higher pitched than Black.
Mostly silent.
Mostly silent. Display sounds feeble in comparison to goldeneyes.

Wings in flight produce a whistling sound in both species. Drakes give a raspy, high-pitched, double-note call when throwing head back in elaborate display; females of both species give a grunting note.
In display (less elaborate than Common), drake gives an "e-eng" call.
NA
Generally silent, except in display, when drake gives a rolling froglike note; female gives a single harsh note.
Generally silent, except in display, when drake gives single, bell-like calls. Both sexes give single harsh calls.
Generally silent, except in display, when drake gives various notes, including mewing calls; female gives various harsh calls.
Mostly silent. During display, male produces soft ticking and popping sounds.
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
Male's song is a rising, whistled *bob-white*, heard chiefly in spring and summer and delivered from a low perch; whistled "hoy" call is heard year-round. Also gives soft clucking notes.
Call given by male in breeding season is a loud, quavering, descending whistle. Female gives multisyllabic whistles on one pitch.
Male's mating call is a loud, clear, descending "quee-ark", at a distance "twoook"; both sexes give whistled notes in rapid series.

Territorial breeding-season call of male is a prolonged note that rises and descend. Calls include varied grunts and cackles, most differing from California; loud, querulous "chi-ca-go-go" call is similar to California but is higher pitched and more hesitant and usually has four notes.

Territorial breeding-season call of male is a single "cah" note, shorter and less descending than Gambel's territorial call. Calls include varied grunts and cackles, including a characteristic and sharp series of "pit" notes; loud, emphatic locatin note, "chi-ca-go" call is similar to Gambel's but is lower pitched and less hesitant and usually has three notes rather than four.
During breeding season, male utters a loud, single harsh note, "squeach". Both sexes give a location call when separated, a low, nasal "chip-churr", accented on the second syllable.
Male's call is a deep, ringing "cha-cha-lac", often given in a loud chorus with other birds; female's voice is higher pitched. Most vocal during breeding season.
Calls include a series of loud, rapid "chuck chuck chuck" notes and a shrill "whitoo" alarm note.
Calls include a hoarse "kee-uck", likened to a rusty gate.
Male's territorial call is a loud, penetrating "kok-cack". Both sexes give hoarse, croaking alarm notes. When flushed, rises almost vertically with a loud whirring of wings.
Calls include various clucks and cackles while feeding. One advertising call suggestive of Long-billed Curlew, male's call rises, female's descends.
In spring a male's gobbling call may be heard a mile away.

In spring, male displays by raising ruff and crest, fanning tail, and beating wings to make a hollow, accelerating, drumming noise. Both sexes give soft clucking notes. Often displays from a fallen log.

Both sexes give soft clucking notes. In courtship display, male spreads tail, erects red eye combs, rapidly beats wings. In territorial flight display, male flutters upward on shallow wingstrokes; Franklin's ends this performance by beating wings together, making a clapping sound. Female's high-pitched call is thought to be territorial.
Male's display call, usually given from ground, softer and lower pitched than Sooty and audible only at close range.
Male's display call is a seris of loud low hoots audible at considerable distance, usually given from perch in tree. More southerly ssp. mostly conceal air sacs when hooting (more research needed).
Calls include a henlike clucking and soft, low hoots.
Calls include low growls and croaks, noisy cackles. In courtship and territorial displays,male utters a raucous *go-back go-back go-backa go-backa go-backa*.
Calls include low growls and croaks and noisy cackles.
Courting males make a deep "oo-loo-woo" sound known as 'booming', like blowing over top of an empty bottle.
Male's courtship notes are higher pitched than Greater.
Male's courting notes include cackling and a single, low "coo-oo" call accompanied by the rattling of wing quills.
Male's display call lower pitched, more uniform than Greater.
In display, male rapidly inflates and deflates air sacs, emitting a loud, bubbling popping.
Gives nasal "beep"; in display, a rapid, buzzy trill.
On breeding grounds, delivers a loud series of gulping notes. Also gives an electric "huzza-huzza-huzza-huzza".
Mostly silent, except on nesting grounds.
Most vocal on breeding grounds; most frequent call is a rising whistled note. Old World birds give very different vocalizations, likely a separate species (Black-necked Grebe).
Calls, usually heard only on breeding grounds, include a "crick-crick" note and drawn-out braying calls.
Call is a loud, two-note "crick-kreek".
Call is a single, drawn-out "kreeeek" note.
Mostly silent; occasional honking notes.
Song is a deep, owl-like "whoo-whooo"; grating call given in display flight.
Song is a soft "coo-cuk-cuk-cuk-coooo".
Songs include a loud, deep "coo-cura-cooo" or "coo-croo".
Distinctive song heard in early spring and summer, a long, high-pitched "cooooo" followed by four loud "up-cup-a-coo" notes.
NA

Three-syllable song, "coo-coo-cup", is given year-round; also a loud, downslurred mewing call in display flight; most similar Ringed Turtle-Doves give a two-syllable call, the second rough and drawn-out.
Song is a rather harsh "coo-coo-croooo" and "co-crrooo-coo", with emphasis respectively on the last and middle notes.
Song is a double "cooo-coo", often phrased as "no-hope". In flight, wings make a rattling sound.
Song is a repeated soft, ascending "wah-up".
Song like Common but faster and a little lower in pitch.
N.A. strays have been silent. Song from a perch a series of very deep, resonant, monosyllabic "coo" notes, repeated every three to four seconds and slightly trailing off at end.
Song is a long, cooing note given from a perch in a tree. Recent N.A. birds have not been heard vocalizing.
Low-pitched song is like the sound produced by blowing across the top of a bottle. Wings give a high twittering sound in flight.
Song, a drawn-out, cooing *who-cooks-for-you*, has many variations and is heard during the breeding season.
Song is similar to Mourning Dove but faster.
Song is a mournful "oowoo-woo-woo-woo". Wings produce a fluttering whistle as the bird takes flight.
Call is a slow, guttural "gaw gaw gaw".
One song sounds hollow and wodden, a rapid staccato "kuk-kuk-kuk" that usually slows and descends to a "kakakowlp-kowlp" ending. Also a series of "coo" notes and a slowly repeated single "keep".
Song usually consists of monotonous "cu-cu-cu" or "cu-cu-cu-cu" phrases.
Song is a dovelike series of notes, descending in pitch.
Male's song is the familiar "cuc-coo" for which the family is named but is rarely heard in N.A.
Song a variable, hollow note often delivered by series of hoots, then series of paired notes ("hoo-hoo"); has not been heard in N.A.
Call is a liquid "tee-ho", accented on the first syllable.
Call is a whining, rising "quee-lick".
Call a rapid, tremulous trill, heard only on breeding grounds.
In courtship display, mae's wings make a hollow booming sound. Nasal "peent" call, given even in migration, is diagnostic.
Call is a varying "pity-pit-pit".
Distinctive song is one or more low "pur" notes followed by a higher, descending "wheeer".
Loud, whistling song sounds like *chuck-will's-widow*.
A clear, loud *whip-poor-will*. Also "cluck" notes, especially in flight.
Like Eastern, but *whip-poor-will* song much burrier; also gives "cluck" notes in flight.
Song, an accelerating series of "cuk" notes ending with "cukacheea".
Song is a whistled *poor-will*, with a final "ip" note audible at close range.
Series of "chick" calls, delivered more slowly than Chimney.
Call is a loud, descending harsh chatter.
Call softer, higher, and more insectlike than Chimney Swift.
Chattering call louder, lower-pitched than Vaux's Swift.
NA
NA
NA
NA
Sog a repeated, often incessant "tsip tsup" with other notes mixed in; often given from a perch.
Usually silent. Gives hard ticking chip notes, often in a series of higher "sip" calls in flight.
Call a hard, rich "chih", sometimes doubled; rapid series of notes in chases.
Call a sharp "chip"; gives other squeaky notes.
Call a loud, high, repeated "seep". Song of male given from a perch is a long, continuous series of "seep" notes.
Call a sharp "chip", reminiscent of Black Phoebe. Male's song delivered from a conspicuous perch, a series of sharp "chip" notes with other notes interspersed.
Call a soft "tchew"; sometimes mixed with squeals in chases. Adult males give a soft wing hum.
All calls like Ruby-throated, including the soft "tchew".
Call is a high-pitched metallic "tink", often given in a series. Male's call is a loud "zing" usually heard during circular flight display.

Common call note a sharp "chick"; chase call a rapid, dry rattling. Male's song a jumble of high squeaks and raspy notes. Male rises slowly in display and then dives steeply giving a sharp "tweek" (produced by outermost tail feather) at bottom and rising again for repeat performance.
Chattering "je-dit" call is similar to Ruby-crowned Kinglet. Male's display call is a whining "zing".
Chattering calls are loud and metallic. Male's display call a repeated, silvery "tink tink tink".
Calls suggestive of Anna's Hummingbird.
Relatively silent. Gives soft, high-pitched, metallic "chip" notes. Adult males produce buzzy "bzzt" calls in display dives.
Except during winter molt, adult male's modified outer primary tips produce a loud, cricketlike trill in flight. Calls include a metallic "chip", different from Rufous and Allen's.

Buzzy wing trill of adult male and all calls essentially identical to Allen's. Calls include a "chip", often given in a series (less metallic than Broad-tailed); chase note, "zeee-chuppity-chup", is a constant sound around feeders where Rufous or Allen's dominates.
All call notes and adult male wing buzz similar to Rufous.
Hard buzzy "dzzrit". Song of male is a squeaky complex warbling with chip notes.
Gives a sharp "tschick" as well as other shrill and squeaky notes.
Call a loud, squeaky chattering; male's song a series of sibilant "ts" notes.
Call, heard chiefly at night, is a wailing "krr-oww".
Distinctive call, heard chiefly in breeding season, is a four- or five-note "tick-tick, tick-tick-tick" in alternate twos or twos and threes, sounds like tapping two pebbles together.

Most vocal in the middle of the night. Distinctive song heard chiefly in breeding season, is a repeated "kik-kee-do" or "kik-kee-derr"; sometimes four notes: "kik-kik-kee-do". Also gives a fast sputtering trill and growling notes.
Calls heard year-round are a descending whinny and a sharp high-pitched "keek"; a whistled "ker-wheer" is heard mainly on breeding grounds.
NA
Presumably like Clapper, but no comparative studies.
Call is a series of 10 or more dry "kek kek kek" notes, like King but accelerating and then slowing. Some calls are nearly identical to King.

As wih Clapper, most often heard at dusk and dawn. Usually distinctive call is a series of fewer than 10 "kek kek kek" notes, fairly evenly spaced; tempo slower than Clapper. Also a series of grunting notes.
Song is a series of "kik kik kidick kidick" phrases, also a "tic tic turrr"; heard chiefly in breeding season; common call, heard year-round, is a descending series of "oink" notes.
Call is a sharp "kek"; also a series of grunting notes.
Gives a wide variety of nasal and cackling calls.
A high "keek"; also a descending series of nasal clucking notes.
Variety of grunting and clucking calls; also a sharp "krrp", slightly lower than Common Gallinule.
NA
Common call is a trumpeting, "gar-oo-oo", audible for more than a mile. Young birds give a wholly different, cricket-like call.
NA
Call is a shrill, trumpeting "ker-loo ker-lee-loo".
Common call is a loud "kek kek kek", also a loud "keek" call, vaguely suggestive of call of Long-billed Dowitcher.
Common call is a loud "wheet", given in an agitated series when disturbed.
Call is a loud, whistled "queep" given singly or in a fast series.
Like Black Oystercatcher.
Call is a drawn-out, three-note whistle, the second note lower pitched.
Flight call is a plaintive "ku-wheep".
Call is a loud, rich "chu-wheet".
Call is a mournful, drawn-out whistle.
Call is a descending whistled "pew" that carries a long way.
Gives a hard and rather grating nonmusical "tirrick".
Distinctive loud, piercing "kill-dee" or "dee-dee-dee", heard mainly during the breeding season. Often heard at night.
Call is a sharp, whistled "whit".
Call is a soft, fluted "pooee"; song, delivered in display flight, is a series of these notes.
Distinctive call is a whistled, upslurred "chu-weet"; song is a series of same.
Distinctive call is a clear "peep-loo".
Calls include a low "krut" and a soft, whistled "ku-wheet".
Calls heard on breeding grounds include low, drawn-out whistles and harsh notes. In migration and winter, gives a harsh "krrr" note.
Usually silent, but flight call is a soft, rolling, descending note.
Flight call is a whistled "pee-wit".
Call is a series of harsh staccato notes, usually given in flight.
Calls include a rolling "pulip pulip"; also a call like a wolf whistle, given in display flight on breeding grounds.
Calls include a musical "quee-dlee" and a loud "tchew-tchew-tchew".
Call is a series of hollow whistles on one pitch.
Main call is a loud whistled "chu-a-whit", and all other vocalizations are completely different from Whimbrel.
Call is a loud musical, ascending "cur-lee".
NA
NA
Flight call is a rather nasal, mewing, quick "vi-vi-vi".
Generally silent away from breeding grounds; call is a rather high-pitched and rising "pid-wid".
Largely silent, except on breeding grounds; calls like Hudsonian, but lower in pitch.
Flight call is a slightly nasal "kah-wek"; also a repeated "ga-wi-da".
Distinctive call is a low-pitched, guttural rattle.
Calls include a guttural rattle, higher than Ruddy Turnstone.
Gives a sharp "kwit" and a chattering call.
Call is a scratchy "keesh"; also a chatter.
Usually silent away from breeding grounds, apart from soft contact notes; occasionally gives a shrill, whistled "kee-wee-ah".
NA
Mostly silent; sometimes gives a soft "ka-whit" in flight.
Call is a "kip", often in a series.
Call is a short "churk".
Call is a raspy "jeet".
Call is a high plaintive "kreee".
NA
NA
Gives a lower-pitched call than Least Sandpiper.
Call is a very distinctive, repeated, rapid dry rattle.
Call note is a very high-pitched insectlike "jeet".
Call is a low raspy "kreep", similar to call of Pectoral, but less rich.
NA
Call is a dry and high-pitched buzzy trill; also shorter calls.
Call is a harsh, reedy "kree".
Call is a soft, rippling "chirrup".
Call is a low, hoarse "querp".
Call is a rich, low "churk".
Call is a mellow, two-note whistle.
A high, harsh, "squelch" note, but migrants usually silent.
A high, somewhat harsh note, but mostly silent in migration.
Call is a mellow "tu tu tu", repeated in a rapid series in alarm call.
Call is a sharp, high-pitched "keek", given singly or in a rapid series.
NA

Often not seen until flushed, as it gives a harsh two-syllable "ski-ape" call in rapid, twisting flight. Where breeding, males deliver loud "wheet" notes from conspicuous perches. In swooping display flight, vibrating outer tail feathers make quavering hoots, like song of Boreal Owl.
Flight-display notes of the male are lower pitched than Wilson's; harsh "ski-ape" flight call like Wilson's.
Call is high, ducklike "squak".
Call, heard mainly in spring, is a nasal "peent". During display also gives chirping sounds.
Flight call is a series of shrill whistled notes on one pitch, usually in threes.
Calls include a shrill "peet-weet" and, in flight, a series of "weet" notes, lower pitched than Solitary Sandpiper.
Call a shrill, piping "twee-wee-wee".
Common call a loud, sharp whistling of multiple notes, resembling calls of Long-billed Dowitcher. Russian name Fifi is onomatopoetic.
Calls include a shrill "peet-weet", higher pitched than calls of Spotted Sandpiper.
Call is like Solitary, but louder.
Call is a rapid series of clear, hollow whistles, all on one pitch.
Best distinction is voice. Common call is a loud, ascending "too-weet", similar to Common Ringed Plover.
Territorial call is "pill-will-willet", distinctly faster and higher pitched in nominate ssp. Other raucous calls are given year-ound, all averaging higher pitcher in the nominate ssp.
Call a loud, slightly descending series of three or more "tew" notes.
Call is one or more "tew" notes, a little higher than Greater, the individual notes being more clipped and all on one pitch.
Typical flight call is a loud "tew-tew-tew", very much like Greater Yellowlegs, but the notes are all on one pitch.
Call is a "tew" note, like call of Lesser; often delivered in a series.
Calls include a musical "tew" or more mournful "tew-hieu". Alarm note is a series of "twek" notes.
Distinctive call, a loud rising "chu-weet", closely resembles the call of Semipalmated Plover and completely unlike any other Tringa.
Calls include a hoarse "wurk" and other low, croaking notes.
Call, a high, sharp "kit", is often given in a series.
Call is a sharp "keip", higher pitched than Red-necked.
NA
NA
NA
NA
NA
Largely silent, except on breeding grounds where quite vocal, most common call is a rising and falling trill, lasting one to three seconds, which can be given from the ground in flight.
Gives guttural calls on breeding grounds that are deep and of a growling nature, "aargh".
Gives a variety of deep growling calls on breeding grounds.
On nesting grounds gives a variety of growls, "knorrrr".
High-pitched screaming and whistles on breeding grounds.
Give a variety of very rapid, high-pitched, twittering and whistled calls on breeding grounds.
Call, heard only on the breeding grounds, is a harsh, rhythmic croaking, often given from safety of burrow, often in unison.
Poorly known. A thin whistled series of "fii" notes has been described.
Highly vocal at all times of the year; indeed, said to be the most vocal alcid at sea. Call is a series of loud, high "kree" notes.
Low groaning and short quacking notes; far less vocal than Marbled.
Nine different calls have been identified. Call on water is a short "leep". Around nest other calls, including a short, emphatic "chirrup".
Quite unlike Scripps's. Gives a cricketlike rattle, similar to Craveri's.
Call is a piping whistle or a series of whistles (heard year-round); quite different from calls of Guadalupe and Craveri's.
Call, very different from Scripps's (but not unlike Guadalupe), is a cicada-like rattle, rising to a reedy trilling when agitated.
On breeding grounds, gives buzzy, scratching notes.
Silent except on breeding grounds, when call is a musical trill, rising in pitch.
On breeding grounds, gives mewing notes.
On breeding grounds, gives loud, doglike barking calls.
On breeding grounds, gives a series of mooing notes.
On breeding grounds, gives rising and falling growling notes.
Similar to Atlantic Puffing, given on breeding grounds.
Various low grumbling notes given in breeding colonies.
A repeated "kittiwake"; also a nasal "awk". Calls mostly May to Aug.
Call is higher pitched and squeakier than Black-legged.
Call s a ternlike "kiew", heard mainly on breeding grounds.
Call is a ternlike "kew", heard mainly on breeding grounds.
Occasional nasal and ternlike calls. Gives rapid loud and evenly spaced notes in flight display on breeding grounds.
Call is a nasal or raspy ternlike "kerrr" or "gerrr".
Calls are ternlike, a grating or screechy  "ree-ah".
Mostly silent away from Arctic breeding grounds, where it gives ternlike chitters and a mellow yapping.
Call is like Laughing Gull, but slightly higher and softer.
Calls include crowing series of "hah" notes; also single "kow" or "ka-ha".
Calls include distinctive low nasal notes that are very different sounding from our other gulls.
NA
NA
Calls of brachyrhynchus include a wheezy "kyap" and a mewing "kii-uu".
Calls include a mewing "kee-ew", a sharper "kyow", and a whining "sseeaa". Also has an extended 'long call'.
Calls include a "kyow" and a higher "kii-ow"; als a long, slightly nasal trumpeting 'long call.' All calls are lower pitched than the Ring-billed.
For smithsonianus, a series of buglelike calls makes up 'long calls'. Also a full "kyow".
Like smithsonianus Herring, but slightly deeper.
Mostly silent in nonbreeding season; otherwise calls close to Herring.
Calls similar to Herring and Iceland Gulls.
Similar to Herring Gull; some calls actually higher pitched.
Similar to Western Gull; 'long call' possibly higher pitched.
A wide variety of calls, some like Herring Gull, some lower.
Call distinctly lower pitched than Western.
Similar to Glaucous-winged.
NA
Like Herring Gull but slightly deeper.
Calls, such as "kyow", are deep and horse. 'Long call' is lower pitched and slower than Herring Gull.
Usually silent; crowlike "karrk" call heard around breeding areas.
NA
Typical call is a soft nasal "weep".
Typical call is a high, nasal "wacky-wack". Also a nasal "ipp".
Call is a squeaky "twee-ee-ee", unlike any other tern.
Calls include high-pitched "kip" notes and a harsh "chir-ee-eep".
Calls include a metallic "kik" and a slurred "k-seek".
NA
Calls are a sharp "kip" and a distinctive low, piercing, drawn-out "kee-a-r-r-r".
Call, a raspy "tr-tee-ar", higher than Common; also a sharp "keet".
Calls include a hoarse "kyarr", lower than Common; also a higher "ket".
Call is a soft "chi-weep" or "ki-vit"; alarm signal a drawn-out "zra-ap" like ripping cloth.
Adult call is a raspy, sharp "kay-wack"; call of juvenile is a faint high-pitched "peep peep".
NA
Calls include abrupt "gwit gwit" and "skee-rick" notes, like Elegant.
Sharp "kee-rick"call very similar to Sandwich Tern.
Calls include a bleating "kee-rer" and ploverlike whistled "tourreee".
Adult's calls include a harsh, raspy "kowk" and "ca-arr"; immature's a distinctive, whistled "whee-you".
Typical call is a nasal "ip" or "yep".
NA
NA
NA
Flight call, heard on breeding grounds, is a rapid, gooselike "kak-kak-kak".
On breeding grounds, gives various yodeling calls.
On breeding grounds, yodeling calls are deeper than Pacific.
Loud yodeling calls delivered on water and in flight are heard all year, but most often on breeding grounds when often heard at night.
Calls are similar to Common.
NA
NA
NA

NA
Mostly silent; some bill clacking at nest site.
NA
NA

NA

NA
NA
NA
Mostly silent; may give occasional croaks and rattles.
NA
NA
Distinctive spring (sings on winter grounds before departing) and early summer song, "oonk-a-lunk", is most often heard at dusk in dense marsh reeds.

Calls include a series of harsh "kek" notes delivered year-round, which, when learned, is often the best means of detection; song, a softer series of "ku" notes, is heard only on the breeding grounds.
Occasional deep croaks.
Mostly silent. During display, male produces soft ticking and popping sounds.
Low, raspy note, mostly at nest site.
NA
Occasional deep croaks.
Mostly silent; some low croaking at nest site.
Mostly silent; some low croaking and squawking, mostly at nest site.
Mostly silent; low grunts at nest site.
Common call is a loud, sharp "kyowk".
Calls include a low, harsh "woc", which is more guttural than Yellow-crowned.
Calls include a short "woc", which is higher and less harsh than the Black-crowned.
Low grunts.
Like Glossy Ibis.
Occasional low grunts.
Mostly silent; occasional low grunts.
NA
NA
NA
Call is a series of loud, whistled "kyew" notes.
Mostly silent; occasionally a nasal grating sound.
Loud rattling notes given near nest when disturbed and in courtship.
Downward whistle, given mainly on breeding grounds.
Calls include various whistled notes.
Mostly silent.
A rather faint and thin "kee-yep" or "yep", sometimes in a series; usually silent away from nesting area.
A variety of calls including a series of high-pitched twitterings or whistles, often delivered in a staggered rhythm.
NA
NA
Occasionally gives a high, downslurred call; also a series of "keee" notes when agitated.
Mostly silent, except around nest. Adults give a single, sharp passerine-like note; juveniles give a high-pitched call.
Most notes with a nasal quality, include a series of "kek" notes. Juveniles give a squeaky whistle.
Calls include a loud, wailing "kee-ah", more plaintive in juvenile, and a loud series of single notes.
Call is a series of loud whistles, falling in intensity near end.
Call is a long, harsh, grating "eeaarr".
Gives a loud screaming call, not too different from Red-tailed, but more of a whistle and less harsh, especially at end.
Call, heard on breeding and winter grounds, is a thin, shrill, slightly descending whistle: "pee-teee".
Call is an evenly spaced series of clear, high "kee-ah" or "kah" notes.
In U.S., birds have been silent, but in Mexico, where common in many places, one of the Roadside's characteristic sounds is a drawn-out, complaining scream, delivered from a perch.
Calls include a loud, descending whistle.
Generally silent, especially in nonbreeding season. Has a high-pitched, drawn-out, slightly descending, two-syllable call.
A drawn-out scream, usually heard near nest site.
Rarely heard except when disturbed at nest site.
Gives harsh alarm calls, "kree-a", chiefly in breeding season.
During breeding season, gives a soft, plaintive courting whistle. Alarm call is a loud screech or squeal.
Distinctive call is a harsh, descending "keeeeer".
Typical call is a raspy, hissing screech often given in flight.
Generally silent except during breeding season. Common call is one or more long "hooo" notes.
Typical call is a raspy, high barking.
Call is a series of three to eight loud, deep hoots; second and third hoots often short and rapid. Juveniles give a raspy begging call.

Distinctive call is a rhythmic series of loud hoots: *who-cooks-for-you, who-cooks-for-you-all*; also a drawn-out "hoo-ah", sometimes preceded by an ascending agitated barking. Much more likely than most other owls to be heard in daytime; often a pair call back and forth.
Call is a series of deep, resonant "whoo" notes.
Main call is a series of four doglike barks; contact call, given mainly by females, is a hollow, upslurred whistle, "coooo-weep".
Mostly silent away from breeding grounds.

Two typical calls: a series of quavering whistles or a whinny, descending in pitch; and a long, uninterrupted trill on one pitch. Whinny call seldom given by 'mccallii', but when given, it is shorter; the longer trill is also different (pitched higher, rhythm changes).
Two common calls: a series of short whistles accelerating in tempo; and a short trill followed immediately by a longer trill. Both often follow a series of agitated barking notes.
Two common calls: a series of short whistles on one pitch and at a fairly even tempo; and a series of very irregular hoots, like Morse code.
A series of single or paired low, hoarse, hollow hoots.
Call an irregular series of high "churp" notes and chattering notes.

Call is a mellow, whistled "hoo", repeated in a well-spaced series, a little faster in interior 'pinicola' group; also gives a rapid series of "hoo" or "took" notes followed by a single "took". Nominate ssp., 'gnoma', see from southeastern AZ south through the mountains of Mexico, gives a series of double "took-took" notes with occasional single notes interspersed. Considered by some to be a separate species, 'Mountain Pygmy-Owl', though no marked genetic differences.
Most common whistled call is a rapid, repeated "took".
Mostly silent away from nesting sites. Gives a series of rapid whistled notes at night. Also various whistled and screeching notes.
Calls include soft "coo-coooo" and chattering series of "chack" notes.
Territorial call, heard primarily in breeding season from late winter to late spring, is a monotonously repeated single-note whistle. Also gives a rising screech and a nightmarish wail note.
Call, heard late winter to midspring, is a short, rapid series of hollow "hoo" notes, like sound made by Wilson's Snipe in flight display.
Song is a series of croaking "co-ah" notes; other variations as well.

Calls include a loud upslurred squeal ending in a "chuck" note; also a loud, hard cackling, usually given in flight when disturbed. Male's song is a long, quavering series of whistled notes that increase in volume.
Call is a loud, dry rattle.
Calls include a harsh rattle, lower and slower than Belted Kingfisher; also a single "chack" note, like Great-tailed Grackle, given chiefly in flight.
One call, a faint but sarp "tick tick", often ends in a short rattle; another, a squeaky "cheep", is given in flight.
In breeding season utters a loud "queark", similar to Red-bellied Woodpecker (p. 308) but harsher, sharper, and higher pitched; call, given year-round, is a soft, guttural rattle.
Most frequent call, "waka", usually repeated several times.
Usually silent. A single squeaky, sharp "chip" is given in interactions with other birds. Most vocal on breeding grounds.
Calls, a rolling "churr-churr" and cackling "kek-kek", are slightly louder and raspier than Red-bellied.
Call, a rolling "churr", given in a series during breeding season, or "chiv-chiv", is slightly softer than Golden-fronted.
Calls, a rolling "churr" and a loud, sharp, high-pitched "yip", often given in a series.
Gives a harsh, shrill raptorlike call.
Gives a querulous, descending mewing call.
Gives a querulous, descending mewing call.
Gives a querulous, descending mewing call.
Call is a low, rattled "prrrt", much lower tha Ladder-backed's "pik"; also gives a series of loud and screeching, spaced, descending notes.
Calls include a sharp, double "pee-dink" or "pee-dee-dink".
Call is a crisp "pik", very similar to Downy Woodpecker but different from the rattled "prrrt" given by Nuttall's; also a descending whinny.
Call is a sharp "peek", similar to Hairy Woodpecker but hoarser.
Calls include a loud, sharp "peek" and a slurred whinny.
Call, "pik", and whinny are softer and higher pitched than Hairy.
Distinctive calls, a raspy "sripp" and a high-pitched "tsick", are much more buzzy; recall a loud Brown-headed Nuthatch.
Call is a sharp "kick".
Call note is a single, sharp "pik", lower pitched and louder than American Three-toed. Drum is low and deep and sound carries far.
Call is a soft "pik" or "kimp". Drumming becomes slightly faster and weaker toward end.
Call heard on the breeding ground is a long, loud series of "wick-er" notes; a single, loud "klee-yer" is given year-round.
Call are like Northern.

Distinctive call note sounds like a toy trumpet: a high-pitched, nasal "yank", given singly or in short series, like a loud version of the call of eastern White-breasted Nuthatch, but beware of Blue Jays giving similar calls; double-rap drum is characteristic of genus Campephilus.

Call is a loud "wuck" note or series of notes, given all year, often in flight; similar call of Northern Flicker is given only in the breeding season. Loud, resonant drumming given most frequently by male.
NA
Call is a series of "kek" notes.
Calls include a low rattle and a single "wuck" note.
Call is a shrill "killy killy killy".
NA
Silent except near nest site, where it gives shrill notes.
Calls are higher tha Peregrine. Largely silent away from nest.
Gives harsh "cack" notes when agitated at nest site.
Gives harsh "cack" notes when agitated at nest site.
Gives a continuous pleasant warble and sharper chattering calls.
Call is a loud, flickerlike "kew".
Gives a short high-pitched "shreek", singly or in a series.
Loud, laughing calls carry far.
Gives harsh and grinding screeches.
Like Yellow-chevroned, but perhaps richer, less shrill.
A high and rather shrill "krere-krere" or "chiri-chiri", given most often in flight.
Call is a loud, grating "krii".
Gives high and loud screeching notes.
Gives a loud, low, hoarse repeated "cheeeah" note.
Varied calls, some melodious, others screeching and grating.
Gives sharp, squeaky, and loud harsh notes.
Gives a series of strident and harsh notes, many with a nasal quality.
Calls similar to those of Mitred, but less harsh.
Calls include a distinctive usplurred whistle a well as raucous crowing much like Red-crowned.
Calls generally raucous but include a mellow, rolling "rreeoo". Fledged juveniles give incessant mechanical "zuh-zuh-zuh" series of begging calls.
Various loud squawks; many calls high and squeaky, with a rising inflection; also more pleasant notes.
Calls include a resonant human-like "aa-haa-haa".
Calls include harsh squawks and pleasant whistled notes.
Song on breeding grounds is a descending series of loud, clear "peer" notes; year-round call is an innocuous, whistled "pee-yerp".
Call is a whistled "tchurree-tchurree". Sometimes given singly; also a soft "peek" like Hammond's Flycatcher.

Distinctive loud, clear three-part song. Across boreal north from AK to NL "quick-three-beers" with slight emphasis on last note. In western U.S. "what-peeves-you" with clear emphasis on longer, higher middle note. The current ranges for the two described ssp. do not reflect these vocal differences. Typical call is a repeated "pip".
Song is a whistled "ho-say ma-re-ah"; call is a repeated "pip".

Distinctive song is a clear, slow, plaintive "pee-a-wee", the second note lower; this phrase often alternates with a downslurred "pee-yer". Calls include a loud "chip" and clear, whistled "pweee" notes; often given together, "chip pweee".
Calls include a harsh, slightly descending "peeer" and clear whistles suggestive of Eastern's "pee-yer". Song, heard chiefly on breeding grounds, has three-note phrases mixed with the "peeer" note.
Call is a clear, steady "dee-dee-dee", also a soft "dep" note.
Call is a soft "peace", extended in song to an emphatic "pee-tsup". On breeding grounds, also gives a flickerlike "ti ti ti ti ti".

Song, a liquid "je-bunk"; also a plaintive, rising "per-wee", both heard mainly on breeding grounds. Call is a sharp, whistled "chiu", heard in migration and on winter grounds, that sounds somewhat like Acadian.

Best identified by voice. Call, a loud "pip", similar to Hammond's but lower, sharper; heard year-round. Distinctive song, a falling, wheezy "weeb-ew" is heard mainly on breeding grounds, but also by some spring migrants. On breeding grounds, also gives a descending "wheer".
Call is a liquid "wit". Songs, a sneezy "fitz-bew"; on breeding grounds, also a rising "brreet"; often sings in spring migration.
Song, a dry "che-bek" accented on the second syllable, is usually delivered in a rapid series; call, a sharp "whit", is sometimes also given in a series. Most vocal empid in migration.
Call note, a sharp "peek". Song, heard only on breeding grounds, like Dusky, but hoarser and lower pitched, especially on second note.
Song is a vigorous "chi-wip" or "chi-bit", followed by a liquid "whilp", trailing off in a gurgle. Call is a loud "wit".

Calls include a "wit" note, softer than Gray Flycatcher; a mournful "deehic", heard on breeding grounds. Song has several phrases: a clear "sillit"; an upslurred "ggrrreep"; another high "sillit", often omitted; and a clear, high "pweet".
Call is a sharp "seet"; male gives upslurred "psee-yeet" note. Song is a complex series of notes, including call notes.

Separable in field only by male's call, a two-note upslurred "see seet"; some populations in northwestern portion of breeding range give more intermediate notes. This fits with the new genetic evidence that reveals a wide swath in northwest part of range where birds have intermediate DNA, raising the issue of whether the two should be lumped. "Seet" note seems slightly sharper in Cordilleran than Pacific-slope Flycatcher.
Call a sharp "whip", a bit louder, lower pitched than Dusky. Song of northern populations (in Mexico) consists of two to four hesitant phrases.
Call a soft "pwit". Typical song is a quick "chicky-whew" or "chee-lick".
Distinctive song is a harsh, emphatic "fee-be", accented on the first syllable. Typical call note is a sharp "chip".
Four-syllable song is a rising "pee-wee" followed by a descending "pee-wee". Calls include a loud "tseee" and a sharper "tsip", slightly more plaintive than Eastern Phoebe's call.
Song is a fast "pit-tse-ar", often given in fluttering flight. Typical call is a plaintive, whistled "pee-ee", slightly downslurred.
Male in breeding season sings during fluttery display flight with chest out. Song is a soft, tinkling "pit-a-see pit-a-see"; also sings while perched. Typical call is a sharp, thin "pseep".
Song, a clear musical whistle, a rolling *whit-will-do*. Call, sharp "whit".
Distinctive call, a loud whistled "wheep", sometimes given in a quick series. Song is a clear, loud "queeleep queelur qurrleep".
Most frequent call is a mournful, descending "peeur".
Distinctive call, heard year-round, is a rough "prrrt". Song, heard on breeding grounds, is a series of burry "ka-brick" notes.
Distinctive call, a rather high-pitched "wink", is often doubled.
Call a rather sharp "weep", suggestive of Great Crested.
On breeding grounds, song is a strident "whee-ee", often followed by a rolled "ji-ji-jit"; also gives rising and falling whistles.
Call is a high, thin "pseee".
Loud call is an excited chatter, like the squeaking of a rubber duck. Song is a soft "tre-le-re-re".
Call is a short, loud "chi-bew", accented on second syllable.
Common call is a sharp "whit".
Distinctive calls, a shrill, rolling "breeeer"; and a more common "kip", similar to call of Western Kingbird, given singly or in a series.
Distinctive call is a rapid, twittering "pip-pip-pip-pip".
Song is a buzzy "pecheer-ry", accented on second syllable.
Call is a harsh "dzeet" note, also given in a series.
Vagrants to U.S. mostly silent. Gives sharp "sik" notes and buzzy chattering calls.
Calls similar to Western Kingbird.
Common call is a loud, high, whistled "pureet".
Nominate's calls include a loud buzzy "tireet", often repeated. Wings produce a muffled sound in flight.
Song is a deliberate "kis-ka-dee"; call is a loud "kreak".
Call, thin, mournful "seeoo", sometimes preceded by chatter.
NA
Song is a medley of low warbles and harsh, squeaky notes; calls include a harsh "shack-shack".
Song and calls are similar to Loggerhead.
Song a persistent string of varied, choppy, two- or three-note phrases. Call note, "tsidik", quite similar to Ruby-crowned Kinglet.

Typical song is a loud, variable five-to seven-note phrase usually beginningand ending with a sharp "chick"; als gives a chatter call suggestive of House Wren. Song incorporates parts of songs of other species.
Song is similar but harsher; call notes slower and harsher.
Song is a repeated or mixed rising "zu-wee" and descending "zoe zoo"; also a flat "chew". Calls include a low "chit" and whining chatter; birds from interior Southwest give a harsher "tchurr-ree".
Song is a series of scolding notes. Call notes like House Wren.
Song is a series of musical "chu-wee chu-weet" notes, faster and sweeter than Plumbeous. Calls include a shrill, descending musical notes, often delivered in flight, as is song.
Song is hoarser than Blue-headed, very like Cassin's; call similar.
Song is haorser than Blue-headed, like Plumbeous; call similar.
Song similar to Red-eyed, but slower, sweeter. Call a harsh chatter.
Song, a slow repetition of buzzy, low-pitched two- or three-note phrases separated by long pauses, often contains a rising *three-eight*. Calls include a rapid, harsh series of "cheh" notes.
Song is a rapid but hesitant series of notes, suggesting House Sparrow.
Persistent song, sung all day, a variable series of sweet, deliberate short pauses, often doubled. Calls include a nasal, whining "quee".
Song, deliberate one- to four-note phrases, less varied and more emphatic than Red-eyed.
Song very similar to Red-eyed but generally slower, thinner.

Song of gilvus delibered in long, melodious, warbling phrases ending with sharp, higher note ("squirt"); song of swainsoni less musical and choppier, with higher ones and break near beginning. Calls include a peevish rising "cheee" and low "chut" notes. Apparently does not interbreed where the two ssp. come together in AB.
Calls include a very nasal, grating, drawn-out "kra-a-a".
Highly variable call notes include whistled "wheeoo" and low "chuck".
Gregarious and noisy; most common call is a series of raspy "cheh-cheh-cheh" notes.
A noisy species; its harsh scream is similar to the call of Red-shouldered Hawk. Another call sounds like a hiccup.
Typical flight call is a high-pitched, piercing "mew", audible over long distances. Also gives a rolling series of "queh" notes.
Most common of varied calls is a piercing "jay jay jay"; also gives a musical "weedle-eedle" and mimics the call of Red-shouldered Hawk.
Calls include a series of "shack" or "shooka" notes and other calls suggestive of Red-shouldered and Red-tailed Hawks.
Calls include a raspy "shreep" often in a short series.
Calls similar to California, but somewhat higher pitched.
Varied calls include raspy, hoarse notes.
Calls similar to California, but slightly lower and deeper.
Calls include a loud, ringing "week", given singly or in a series; similar in both ssp. groups.
Noisy; many calls, one a whining "mag", another a mellow "wurp".
Calls are similar to Black-billed.
Calls include a metallic "kow" and a softer "jack" note.
Call is a low, froglike "croak".
Call is somewhat hoarser and lower than American, but beware of juvenile American crow.
Always best distinguished by voice: Call is a high, nasal "uh uh", the second note lower; also low, short "car" notes.
Adult is readily identified by familiar "caw" call, but juvenile's higher-pitched, nasal "cah" begging call resembles the call of the similar Fish Crow.
Frequent call, a drawn-out "croak", usually slightly higher pitched than Common Raven.
Most common call is a low, drawn-out "croak".
Calls include a high "tsee-ee" or "tsee-titi". Song is a weak twittering, delivered from the ground or in flight.
Song is a continuous outpouring of trills and warblings, delivered in high hovering or circling song flight. Call is a liquid "chirrup" with buzzy overtones.
Loud , rich gurgling and whistles; also a low "churr".
NA
NA
Calls and song include whistles and liquid gurgles or chirps.
Gives rapid and high-pitched twittering notes.
Call, a rough scratchy "prrit", somewhat similar to Rough-winged Swallow.
Call is a short, sweet, single or double "vit" or "veet"; song is a series of squeaky notes.
Call is a low, buzzy "zzrtt".
Call is a series of buzzy, short "dzrrt" notes, not unlike the sound made by high-tension powerlines.
Calls include a rough, squeaky "chri", a nasal "trrr", and a rattle.
Call is a rising "pweih", much sweeter than Cliff Swallow.
Most common callis a rapid, high-pitched variation of "chick-a-dee-dee", similar to Juniper Titmouse. Song is a rapid and clipped series of whistled notes.
Song is variable, a repeated series of syllables made up of whistled, alternating, high and low notes. Call is a hoarse "tschick-a-dee".
Typical song is a loud, whistled "peter peter peter"; less vocal than Black-crested; calls softer and less nasal.

Song is a rolling series of syllables, rapid, with uniform pitch. Call is a hoarse "tschick-a-dee" similar to Bridled Titmouse. Overall, chattering call notes are more clipped and delivered much more rapidly than Oak Titmouse.
Calls louder, sharper than Tufted. Song is also like Tufted, but notes are slightly higher and are delivered more rapidly.

Best distinction is voice. Call is a lower, slower "chick-a-dee-dee-dee" than Carolina; typical song, a clear, whistled "fee-bee" or "fee-bee-ee", the first note higher in pitch; vocalizations show considerable geographic variation.
Best distinction for separating species is voice. Call is a higher, faster version of "chick-a-dee-dee-dee" than Black-capped; typical song is a four-note whistle, "fee-bee fee-bay".
Song is a warbled whistle; call note, a husky buzz.
Call is a hoarse "chick-adee-dee-dee"; typical song, a three- or four-note descending whistle, "fee-bee-bay" or "fee-bee fee-bee".
Call a high, hoarse, rapid "tseek-a-dee-dee". No whistled song given.
Call is a nasal "tseek-a-day-day".
Call is a distinctive series of "dee-deer" notes.
Song is a plaintive three-note whistle, the second note higher. Calls include rapid chip notes and a single sharp "seep".
Calls from coastal slope birds a rapid, soft twittering, given in loud, excited chatter when raptor appears; interior birds give sharper notes.
High-pitched, nasal call sounds like a toy tin horn.

Song of eastern carolinensis and Pacific aculeata is a series of whistled "tuey" notes on one pitch; lower in carolinensis. Call is a low-pitched "yank" in carolinensis, a higher-pitched "wheer" in aculeata, and a rising series of even higher "yida" notes in lagunae group. Song of latter varied, but often consists of a series of their calls.
Typical calls, a high "peep" or a rapid "peep peep"; als a piping "wee-bee"; grouped in three or more notes in nominate ssp., pygmaea.
Call is a repeated double note like the squeak of a rubber duck. Feeding flocks also give twittering, chirping, and talky "bit bit bit" calls.

Call is a soft, sibilant "see"; song, a high-pitched, variable "see see see titi see" with differences between eastern and western ssp. Groups; vocalizations of albescens appear distinct but local dialects complicate situation; more study needed.
Song variable mixes of buzzes and trills; call buzzy "tick-ear" or "dzeeeee".
Loud, silvery song, a deccelerating, descending series of liquid "tee" and "tew" notes. Typical call is a sharp, buzzy "jeet".
Song, heard all year, is a low-pitched, harsh, rapid "cha cha cha cha cha". Call is a variety of low, croaking notes, sometimes in a series.
Exuberant song is a cascade of bubbling whistled notes; calls include a soft "chek" and a harsh scold; also in western birds a rolled "trrrrr".
Call is a "chimp", often doubled, quality like Wilson's Warbler. Song is like Winter Wren, but faster, less melodic.
Most frequent call is "kelp", often doubled and highly suggestive of Song Sparrow but sharper. Song is a beautiful series of musical trills.
Vivacious, melodious song, a loud, clear *teakettle tea-kettle teakettle* or *cheery cheery cheery*. Sings all year. Calls are loud and varied and include a "chirt" or double "chirt-eet".
Songs are mechanical-sounding mix of bubbling and trilling notes; more liquid in East, harsher, faster, and much more variable in West. Alarm call is a sharp "tsuk" often doubled.
Song begins with a few single notes followed by a weak staccato trill or chatter; call note, a rich "chip", often doubled.
Song consists of loud rich phrases, often with rapid repetition of notes; wide variety of call notes.
Song variable, a high, thin buzz and warble, similar to Song Sparrow. Calls include a flat, hollow "jip".
Call is a querulous "pwee". Varied song of high, thin notes, chips and buzzy notes; harsher in slightly duller-plumaged western obscura.
Calls quite suggestive of most frequent call of Bewick's Wren.
Calls include rasping "cheeh" and hissing "ssheh"; song is a rapid series of "jee" notes; all vocalizations harsher than Blue-gray.
Call is a rising and falling, kittenlike "zeeer"; song is a series of "jzer" or "zew" notes.
Song is loud, musical, wrenlike. Call, a sharp, loud "dzeet", often given in a series, and in flight.
Call is a series of high, thin "tsee" notes. Song, almost inaudibly high, is a series of "tsee" notes accelerating into a trill.
Call is a scolding "je-ditt". Song, high, thin "tsee" notes followed by descending "tew" notes, ends with warbled three-note phrases.

Usually heard before seen. Male's loud song, sung year-round, begins with a series of accelerating notes and runs into a descending trill: "pit-pit-pit-r-r-r". Female's song lacks trill. Both sexes give soft, low "prr" note, often in a series.
Whistled "hoo-eet" call note is very unlike Arctic's buzzy note.
Birds seen in N.A. have been silent; calls are geographically variable, "tristis" gives an even "hip".
Song is a long series of toneless buzzy notes. Call is a buzzy single-syllable "dzik".
Often silent; call note distinctive: a two-syllable "tzz-eet".
Call, a hard, sharp "tschick", suggests Lincoln's Sparrow.
NA
Call is a soft, nasal rising "chuee".
Call, upslurred "swee-eet", suggests male Pacific-slope Flycatcher.
NA
Distinctive call, a metallic "rink-tink-tink", delivered infrequently; also an excited "chack". Song, a thin, reeling sound, like a fishing line.
NA
Gives rattled "trrt" call; also a metallic "tic" and harsh "ze-it".
NA
NA
NA
Calls include a deep, low "chuck" and a loud, whistled "quee-ah"; song, long and complex, includes warbles and lisping notes.

In courthip, males sing from high perches and in elaborate display flight. Varied, melodious often begins with a crisp, metallic "ting ting ting"; call, "tchak", often given in a series; mimics other species.
Calls include a "hueet" and dry "keck-keck".
Calls include "chak" and whistled "wheet". Song, a scratchy warbling mixed with call notes, often given in flight with tail spread.
NA
Call note is a musical, rising "chur-lee", extended in song to "chur chur-lee chur-lee".
Call note a mellow "few", given in a brief series for song.
Call is a thin "veew"; song, a low, warbled "tru-lee".
Call note is a high-pitched "eek"; song, heard all year, is a loud, complex, melodious warbling.
Thin, nasal song is somewhat like Veery, but first and last phrases drop, middle one rises; call is a sharp "pheu", similar to Veery, but higher pitched and not descending.
Song usually comes in three parts, the first and last rising; call like Gray-cheeked but higher pitched.
Song is a descending series of "veer" notes; call is a sharp, descending, whistled "veer" or "phew".
Song, an ascending spiral of whistles; call is a liquid "whit" in Pacific coast ssp. a sharper "quirk" in others; a night a peeping "qeep".

Song is a serene series of clear, flutelike notes, the similar phrases repeated at different pitches. Calls include a deeper "chuck" (geographically variable), often doubled, and a whiny, upslurred "wee".
Loud, liquid song of three- to five-note phrases, each phrases usually ending with a complex trill. Calls include a rapid "pit pit pit".
Flight call is a high, piercing, drawn-out "dzee".
Call is a series of "shack" notes; also a shrill, wheezy "shree".
Song is a noisy twittering; call note is a series of "shack" notes, like Dusky Thrush; also gives a thin "seeh".
Call is a thin, penetrating "seeeh", usually heard in flight; also a hard "kuk" note.
Loud, liquid song, is a variable *cheerily cheer-up cheerio*. Calls include a rapid "tut tut tut"; a high, thin "ssip" in flight.
Calls include a plaintive, drawn-out, whistled "teeeuu", a clucking series of "chuk" notes, and in flight, a high, thin "ssi".
Calls include a slurred "reeeur-ee", a clucking note, and, in flight, a high, thin "ssi"; song resembles American Robin but is slower, clearer.
Call is a nasal "rreeuh", often doubled.
Calls are quavering "wheeerr", a metallic "wheer", and a clear "sweee-uh".
Call is a soft, low "tschook"; song is a slow series of variously pitched, drawn-out buzzy notes.

Song is a mixture of melodious, nasal, and squeaky notes interspersed with catlike "mew" notes; some are good mimics. Most readily identified by harsh, downslurred "mew" call; also gives a low "quirt" and a clucking noise.
Song and call notes vary widely.

Song is a mixture of original and imitative (other species) phrases, each repeated several times. Often sings at night. Both sexes sing in fall, claiming feeding territories. Call is a loud, sharp "check".
Song is varied but not known to include imitations; call slightly harsher, more downslurred than Northern.
Sings a series of varied melodious phrases, each phrase usually given only two or three times. Seldom imitates other birds. Calls include a sharp "spuck" and a low "churr".
Song similar to Brown Thrasher. Gives "tsuck" call like Brown; other calls, a mellow "kleak", and a loud, whistled "cheeooep".
Song is a long series of warbled phrases. Calls include a "chuck" and a high "churr", but often silent.
Calls are a low, flat "chuck" and "chur-erp". Song is loud and sustained, with mostly guttural phrases, often repeated once or twice. Imitates other species and sounds.

Distinctive call a sharp upslurred "whit-wheet", sometimes three-noted (palmeri); even-pitched "whit-whit" (oberholseri and curvirostre). Song is elaborate and melodic, and includes low trills and warbles.
Song is a sustained, melodic warbling, each phrase repeated one to three times. Low "chuck" all is seldom heard.
Melodious song, heard chiefly at dawn and dusk. Calls include an ascending, whistled "tweeeep", often delivered from a bush.
Song is varied and musical. Calls include a repeated "chideery" and a whistled, even-pitched "toit-toit-toit".
Characteristic call is a rich, musical "wi-ti-wheet"; also other chattering calls.
Calls include gurglings, whistles, and screeches.
Call is a loud, piercing two-note whistle, "ti-ong". An excellent mimic, and captive birds can be fine talkers.
Song includes squeaks, warbles, chirps; imitates songs of other species. Often silent, though gives various harsh calls in interactions with others and has a soft, breezy flight call.
Distinctive call, a buzzy twittering, lower and harsher than Cedar.
Call is a soft, high-pitched, trilled whistle.
Distinctive call is a low-pitched, whistled, querulous "wurp?". Song is a brief warble, seldom heard.
Typical song is a loud "peeta peeta peeta", similar to Tufted Titmouse; distinctive call is a soft, whistled "phew", also a hard "pit".
Call is a high, thin series of "see" notes.
Song a repetitive, measured and somewat jerky "tseet tseet tsu-weet". Call a soft "chwit"; begging juveniles give rapid series of chip notes.
Song high, buzzy. Call a sharp "tsip" and "tsik tsik tsik".
Gives "tcht tcht" contact notes; high-pitched song.
Song, "tiks" and whistles, is nearly inaudible; call is a loud "kibee".
Call is a buzzy, high-pitched "jik" or "jik jik". Song rather deep, slow, and measured and in two parts.
Similar to House Sparrow but harder.
Calls include a sweet "cheelip" and monotonous chirps.
Song is a rapid series of buzzy notes on one pitch. Call is a loud buzzy "tsweep", similar to Eastern Kingbird.
Call is a metallic "chink-chink", higher and sharper than White.
Calls include a two-note "chizzik" given in flight and a whistled "chee-wee" given from perch.
Flight call a sharp "pip-pit"; japonicus possibly thinner; song, a rapid series of "cheedle" notes given in flight on breeding grounds.
Call is a loud, squeaky "squeet", usually repeated. Song, given continuously in high flight, is a descending series of musical "tzee-a" notes.
Call is a buzzy "tsee".
Call is a hard, buzzy "pwit" or "pit"; often silent when flushed.
Call, given in flight, is a high, piercing "tseee", dropping in pitch. Loud, varied song is delivered from the ground or in song flight.
Call is a metallic "pink-pink"; also a "hweet".
Flight call is a nasal "check-check-check"; also gives a nasal "zwee". Song consists of just a short buzzy note.
Call is a soft, piping "pheew".
Typical flight call is a whistled "pui pui pui"; alarm call is a musical "chee-vli". Location call shows considerable geographic variation. Song is a rather short, musical warble.
Call, a high, chirping "chew", is often given in courtship flight and in unison when flocks take flight, which is frequent.
Call similar to Gray-crowned Rosy-Finch.
Call similar to Gray-crowned Rosy-Finch.
Calls include a musical "chur-lee" and in flight, a sharp "pit", a bit sharper in californicus. Song is a rich warbling, longer and move variable in purpureus; shorter than Cassin's.
Call a dry "tee-dee-yip". Lively variable warbling song, longer, more fluty, and more complex than Purple Finch, especially californicus.
Lively, high-pitched song consists chiefly of varied three-note phrases; includes strident notes, unlike Purple Finch's song; usually ends with a nasal "wheer". Calls include a whistled "wheat".
Call is a soft, nasal "djuee".

Calls, given chiefly in flight, vary among ssp. but basically a series of "kip" notes, quality differing subtly to markedly among call-note types; for diagnosis, best recorded so sonogram can be analyzed later. Song begins with two-note phrases followed by a warbled trill.

Distinctive flight call is a rapid series of harsh "chet" notes. Variable song, often delivered in display flight, combines harsh rattles and musical warbles. Vocalizations of larger, thicker-billed bifasciata of Eurasia markedly different. Unrecorded N.A.
Call is a nasal "dzweeee".
Calls include a harsh rising "tee-ee" and, in flight, a harsh, descending "chee". Song is similar to American Goldfinch but much huskier.
Song is a lively series of trills, twitters, and "swee" notes. Distinctive flight call, "per-chik-o-ree".
Call is a plaintive, kittenlike "tee-yee". Song is somewhat similar to American Goldfinch. Frequently imitates other species' calls.
Call is a bell-like "tink-ul". Mixes "tink" notes into jumbled, melodious song. Like Lesser, often mimics other species' calls.
When perched, gives a "swee-ee-eet" call; flight call is a dry rattling. Song combines trills and twittering.
Calls and song similar to Common.

Loud, strident call is a "clee-ip" or "peeer". Five groups with differing vocalizations described. Eastern vespertinus has lower pitched and burrier (more trilled) calls. Other four call types from West: three from within range of brooksi (northern Rockies and Cascades, southern Rockies, Sierra Nevada) and montanus (possibly extirpated in U.S.).
Call is a loud, explosive "ptik".

Typical call is a dry, ticking rattle, harder and sharper than Lapland and McGown's Longspurs. Song, heard in spring migration and on the breeding grounds, is delivered only from the ground or a perch. It consists of rapid, melodious warbles, ending with a vigorous "wee-chew".

Song, heard mostly on the breeding grounds, is a rapid warbling, frequently given in short flights. Calls include a musical "tee-lee-oo" or "tee-dle" and, in flight, a dry rattle distinctively mixed with whistled "tew" notes.

Song, heard only on breeding grounds, is a pleasant, rapid warble, given in song flight or from a low perch. Distinctive call, a two-syllable "kittle", is repeated one or more times. Also gives a soft, high-pitched rattle and a short "buzz" call.

Song, heard only on breeding grounds, is a series of exuberant warbles and twitters, generally given in song flight. Calls include a dry rattle, a little softer and more abrupt than Lapland Longspur; also gives single finchlike notes.
Calls include a sharp, whistled "tew"; a short buzz; and a musical rattle or twitter. Song, heard only on the breeding grounds, is a loud, high-pitched musical warbling.
Calls and song similar to Snow Bunting.
Typical song is a loud *teacher teacher teacher*, rising in volume. Calls include a sharp, dry "chip".
Song is a series of sharp, dry chip notes, like Chipping Sparrow but faster. Common all is a buzzy "zeep-zeep"; also a sharp "chip".
Call note, a sharp "chick", flatter than Northern. Song begins with three or four shrill, slurred descending notes followed by a rapid jumble.
Call, a metallic "chink", slightly sharper than Louisiana. Song begins with loud, emphatic notes;ends in lower notes, delivered more rapidly.
Main song is a soft "bee-bz-bz-bz"; also gives an alternative song similar to Blue-winged Warbler. Calls also similar to Blue-winged. Hybrid's songs usually sound like one of the parent species.
Main song is a wheezy "beee-bzzz", the second note lower; alternate song is longer and more complex. Call is a dry, sharp "chip"; in flight, call is a thin "zit".
Song is a series of loud, ringing "zweet" notes; gives a dry chip note and buzzy flight call.
Song is a long series of high, thin "wee-see" notes. Calls include a sharp "chip" and high "seep-seep".

Song is a series of thin, slurred whistles like beginning of song of Louisiana Waterthrush; often ends with a rising "tee-oh". Various renditions include *whee whee whip-poor-will* or *ooh ooh stepped in poo*. Will usually sing from a branch, but will also sing from the ground. Calls include a loud, dry "chip".

Distinctive two- or three-part song; in the three-part version, several rapid two-syllable notes are followed by a few higher single notes, usually ending with a staccato trill. Call is a sharp "chip"; flight call is a thin "seet".
Song is a high-pitched staccato trill, faster in lutescens; quite variable in sordiata. Call note, a somewhat metallic "chip"; also a thin "seet".
Song of eastern ruficapilla is a series of high "see-weet" notes and a lower short trill; call is a dull "chink". In ridgwayi, song is sweeter, call is sharper.
Song is a trill similar to Orange-crowned Warbler. Call is a loud note similar to Virginia's but not quite as sharp.
Song is a rapid series of thin notes, often ending with lower notes; call is a sharp "chink".
Lively song is a short trill followed by lower, whistled notes. Call is a sharp "chink".
Call is a high, sharp "sik", similar to Orange-crowned Warbler, but softer. Song is a very fast, buzzy trill on one pitch.

Loud, accelerating song repeats a brief seris of explosive "beech-er" or "whip-ity" notes. Most frequently given call is a buzzy "zeet", like Yellow or Blackpoll warbler. Rarely heard call note is a nasal "chimp" or "poitch".
Call is a flat, hollow chip, not unlike one call of Bewick's Wren. Song is a series of slurred two-note phrases followed by two or more lower phrases.
Call is a sharp, harsh "tsik", distinctly different from Mourning. Two-part song is a buzzy trill ending in a downslur.
Variable song; one version is loud, rolling "wichity wichity wichity wich". Also gives an elaborate flight song on breeding territory. Calls include a raspy "tidge".
Song is a rich, varied warble; call is a rising "chee dee".
Song is a series of rolling musical notes, "churry churry churry", much like Carolina Wren. Call is a low, sharp "chuck".
Song is loud, musical, whistled variations of "ta-wit ta-wit ta-wit tee-yo". Call is a flat, metallic "chink".
Variable song, frequent version is a short series of high, thin notes usually followed by a wheezy, downslurred note. Many other songs, all wheezy. Call is a rich, sweet "chip".

Song is a short, fast, accelerating series of buzzy notes on one pitch, ending with a long, single buzz note. Rather infrequently heard "chip" is slurred; flight call is a buzzy "zzee", like Blackburnian.

One song is a short series of high notes followed by a squeaky, ascending trill, ending on a very high note; another is a series of high, two-part phrases. Call is a "chip" like a number of other wood-warbler species; flight call is a buzzy "zzee".

One song is a rising buzzy trill, ending with an abrupt "zip" in eastern birds; no clear final note in primary song and trill rate is slightly slower in more westerly birds. Calls include a clear "chip".
Song like western types of Northern Parula. Chip notes also like Northern.
Song, rapid, variable, is sometimes written *sweet sweet sweet I'm so sweet*. Call is a sweet, rich "chip", often repeated in a rapid series when agitated. The flight call is a breezy "zeet".
Song is a whistled *please please pleased to meetcha*; call is a chip note like Yellow Warbler but is not repeated rapidly as Yellow often does.
Song is a short, whistled "weety-weety-weeteo". Call, given rather infrequently, is a unique, weak, nasal "tchif" or "wenk".
One song is a high, thin "seet seet seet seet"; call is a very high, thin "sip".
Typical song is a slow series of four or five wheezy notes, the last note higher: "zwee zwee zwee zweeee" or a slower "zur zurr zreee". Call is a single sharp "dit", like Dark-eyed Junco.
Song, a slow warble, usually rising or falling at the end in Audubon's, a musical trill in one song of Myrtle. Call note of Myrtle is lower, flatter.

Varied songs include a buzzy "weezy weezy weezy weezy-weet". Call is a flat "tchip", slightly duller than Townsend's. Flight call is like other related species in this group (remaining species on p. 474).

One song is a hoarse "zeee zeee zee-zo-zee"; the other is often written as *trees, trees, whispering trees*. Call is a sharp, flat "tip" or "tsik", much like the other species on this page. The flight note is a thin, non-buzzy "see".
Song, "bzzzz layzee dayzee", ends on a high note. Call notes are like Black-throated Green.
Song is a high "seezle seezle seezle seezle zeet-zeet". Call notes like Black-throated Green or Townsend's.

Variable song, a series of hoarse "zee" notes. Call note, "tchip", much like the other species on this page. Note of Black-throated Gray is softer. Flight call for all five of these related species is a thin, non-buzzy "see".
Song consists of high-pitched double notes. Calls include a sharp chip note and a buzzy "zeet". Flight call is similar to Yellow Warbler.
Song is a series of high "tseet" notes. Calls include a sharp "chip" and a buzzy "zeet". Flight call like Bay-breasted.
Song is a twittering musical trill, varying greatly in speed. Call is a flat, sweet "chip".
Song is a rapid, accelerating trill. Call is a sweet "chip".
Song is a series of clear, downslurred whistles ending with a rising note. Call is a rich "chip".
Song is a loud series of low notes followed by slurred whistles; call is a loud, forceful "chip", similar to Prairie.
Distinctive song, a rising series of buzzy "zee" notes. Call, a flat "tsuk".
Song is a rapid, buzzy trill. Call is a sharp "tsik". Flight call is a high "seet" or low "see-seet".
Song of rich, loud slurred notes; call is a penetrating "schree".
Song begins with musical chip notes and accelerates into a series of dry, whistled warbles; sometimes sings from an exposed and higher perch; call, a "tik", is often doubled or in a rapid series.
Gives five to seven clear whistled notes, ending with a distinct upslur; suggestive of Hooded Warbler. Call is a rapid repeated "tuck".
Song is a rapid, variable series of "chee" notes, falling into a weak trill in pusilla. Common call is a sharp "chimp"; also a "tsip", the frequent flight call.
Song begins with one or more short, sharp chip notes and continues as a rich and highly variable warble. Call is a sharp "tick".
Song is a series of varied, ringing "zweet" notes. Call is a sharp "tchip", suggestive of Black-throated Gray Warbler.
Song is a series of rich, liquid warbles; call is a clear, whistled "chee".
Song is a variable series of sweet "s-wee" notes, often accelerating toward the end. Call, a chip note, is very different from Painted Redstart.
Song, a jumble of harsh, chattering clucks, rattles, clear whistles, and squawks. Call, a sharp "chow", a nasal "air", and a sharp "cuk" or "cuk-cuk-cuk".
Call is a thin, high "tsee", given singly or in a series.
Gives a mewing "meeah" call; also a thin "ssit", often repeated.
Call, high-pitched "tsip"; song geographically variable, even within West Indies; Bahama birds give several ticks followed by rapid clicking.
Song is pitched high, then low, a variable *sweet sweet sweet sweet cheer cheer cheer*. Calls include a distinct, high "wink".
Song is a buzzing "tik-zeee"; call is a high, lisping "tst".
Song is thin, insectlike trills; call is a high-pitched "sik" or "tsi".
Calls include a dry "chip" and a buzzy "speeee". Song is an accelerating series of chip notes.

Full song has three parts, often rendered as "drink your tea", or shortened to two parts: "drink tea". Northeastern birds' call is an upslurred "chwee" or "joree"; in alleni, a clearer, even-pitched or upslurred "swee".

Song and calls also show great geographical variation. Interior montanus a few introductory notes, then a trill. Pacific coast birds a simple trill of variable speed. Great Plains arcticus a variable number of rapid introductory notes followed by a trill. Call of monatus a descending and raspy mewing; generally, Pacific ssp. and arcticus a rising "ree-eee".
Clear, whistled song begins with "weet-chur", ends in raspy, buzzy trill, unlike similar-sounding western montane Fox Sparrows, which often breed in same areas. Calls include a catlike "mew".

Call is a sharp, metallic "chink" note; also gives some thin, lispy notes and an excited, squealing series of notes, often delivered as a duet by a pair. Song, accelerating "chink" notes with stutters in the middle, is heard mostly in late afternoon.

Call is a shrill "chee-yep" or "chedep". Song, more musical, less metallic than California; opens with a call note, followed by sweet slurred notes. Also gives a duet of lisping and squealing notes, like California.
Call is a sharp "peek"; song is a series of "peek" notes.
Distinctive call note, a sharp, high "seep". Variable song, several chip notes followed by an accelerating trill of chip or "sweet" notes.

Best located and identified by song, often given in brief, fluttery song flight: typically a soft double whistle, a loud, sweet trill, a low whistle, and a final, slightly higher note; or a series of chip notes ending in a trill or warbles. Also gives a trill of "pit" notes.
Best located and identified by song: one clear, whistled introductory note, followed by a variable trill or warble on a different pitch. Male sings from open perch; often heard in late summer.
Best located and identified by song: several high sharp "tsip" or "che-lik" notes, often given alone or followed by a short, accelerating, rattly trill.
Calls include a distinctive sharp "dear", usually given in a series; song is a rapid, bubbling series of rising and falling chip notes.
Calls include a musical "teedle-eet"; also a thin "seet". Song usually begins with several clear notes followed by a variable, rapid warble.
Song is a series of clear, plaintive whistles accelerating into a trill; hard chip note similar to Orange-crowned Warbler.
Song is a rapid trill of dry notes on one pitch. Call is "tsik"; flight call, also given perched, is a high, hard "seep".
Song is a brief series of insectlike buzzes; like Brewer's, song heard in late winter and spring migration. Flight call is a thin "sip".

Song is a series of varied bubbling notes and buzzy trills at different pitches; often sings in spring on winter grounds and on migration. Song of taverneri differs: overall higher pitched, less buzzy, lacks descending "sweet" notes. Call is a thin "sip", like Clay-colored Sparrow.
Song, an accelerating series of sweet notes; call, a high, thin "seep".
Song is rich and melodious: two long, slurred notes followed by two higher notes, then a series of short, descending trills. One call is a thin, Spizella-like "seep".
Call, a whistled "hoo-ee". Song consists of rich whistles and trills.
Song with two loud, clear notes, followed by a series of rich, melodious notes and trills and unmusical buzzes. Call a sharp "tsip".
Often sings from conspicuous perch. Song, series of paired phrases preceded by a few introductory notes. Call, loud, hollow "tchep".
Song is rapid and high pitched: two clear notes followed by a trill. Calls are faint, tinkling notes.
Song of belli, a series of jumbled notes, like a cross of Blue Grosbeak and Rufous-crowned Sparrow. Song of canescens differs, perhaps variable; more study needed. Calls similar to Sagebrush.
Song is a strongly defined, pulsating pattern of rising and falling phrases, seemingly in a minor key. Twittering call of thin, juncolike notes.

Song begins with two or three chip notes, followed by two buzzy trills. Distinctive flight call is a thin "seep". Song of rostratus has short, high introductory notes, followed by about three rich, buzzy "dzeeee" notes; call is a soft, metallic "zink".
Typical song is one or two high chip notes followed by a brief, grasshopper-like "buzz"; also sings a series of varied squeaky and buzzy notes.
Song consists of two or three high, thin notes, followed by a single warbled note and a low trill.
Distinctive song, a short "se-lick", accented on second syllable.
Song softer, more complex than Nelson's.
Song is a short, high, insectlike buzz.
Song, a wheezy "p-tssssshh-uk", ends on a lower note.
Song like Red-winged Blackbird, but buzzier.
Two call notes: a flat "tschup", repeated in a series as an alarm call; and a sharp, buzzy "zeee". Rich, loud song, a rapid, bubbling trill.
Typical song has three or four short clear notes followed by a buzzy "tow-wee", then a trill. Distinctive call note is a nasal, hollow "chimp".
Typical song is a slow, musical trill, all on one pitch. Two call notes: a prolonged "zeee", softer than Lincoln's Sparrow, and an Eastern Phoebe-like "chip".

Songs are sweet, melodic in northern Red group; include harsher trills in ssp. Thick-billed ssp. give a sharp "chink" call, like California Towhee; others give a "tschup" note, like Lincoln's Sparrow but louder, though in "Slate-colored" call is a little different, more of a "tewk", and slightly downslurred.
Song is a series of long, clear, quavering whistles, often beginning with two notes on one pitch followed by two notes on another pitch. Calls include a loud "wink" and a drawn-out "tseep".

Song is a thin whistle, generally two single note followed by three triple notes: *pure sweet Canada Canada Canada*, often heard in winter. Calls include a sharp "pink" and a drawn-out, lisping "tseep".

Songs for all ssp. are often heard in winter; three of the ssp. (oriantha, pugetensis, and nuttalli) give one or more thin, whistled notes followed by a sweet twittering trill; resident coastal nuttalli is particularly geographically variable in song dialects, even from immediately adjacent areas; leucophrys and gambelii give a more mournful song with no trill at the end. Calls include a loud "pink", sharper and more downslurred in oriantha, and sharp "tseep".
Song is a series of three or more plaintive, whistled notes: *oh dear me*. Calls include a soft "tseep" and a flat "tsick".

Song is a musical trill on one pitch, often heard in winter. Varied calls include a sharp "dit"; in flight, a rapid twittering. Some songs and calls of "Gray-headed" dorsalis are more suggestive of Yellow-eyed Junco.
Song is a variable series of clear, thin whistles and trills. Calls includea high, thin "seep", similar to Chipping Sparrow.
NA
Call is a short "ziit".
Call note is a sharp "tsick".
Call note is a hard, sharp "jit" or "tsip". Song, a soft, bubbling warble.
NA
