Call is a "tzip", similar to Little Bunting.
Call is a sharp "zhii".
Call is a "seeoo", falling in pitch; flight note, a hoarse "brzee".
Call, a "cheeep", recalls Eurasian Tree Sparrow, very unlike Reed.
Song suggests Black-headed Grosbeak. Call of northern ssp. is a single low, sharp "chuck", unlike all other Piranga tanagers.
Song is robinlike; call is a staccato "ki-ti-tuck".
Robinlike song (hoarser than Summer Tanager) of raspy notes, "querit queer query querit queer", is heard in deciduous forests. Call is a hoarse "chip-burr"; sometimes just first part is given.
Song is like Scarlet Tanager. Call is a "pit-er-ick"; also a whistled upslurred, questioning "wheet" flight call.
Song similar to Western and Scarlet Tanagers; call is a low-pitched "preeck", also like Western but huskier.
Song is a variable warble; call is a penetrating, rising and falling "seeiyu", also a double-whistled note.
Song is a loud, liquid whistling with many variations, including "cue cue cue" and "cheer cheer cheer" and "purty purty purty". Both sexes sing almost year-round. Common call is a sharp "chip".
Song is a liquid whistle, thinner and shorter than Northern Cardinal; call is a sharper, more metallic "chink".
Common call, often given in flight, is a distinctive electric-buzzer "bzrrrrt". Song is a variable "dick dick dickcissel".
Rich, warbled songs of Rose-breasted and Black-headed are nearly identical, but Rose-breasted's call, a sharp "eek", is squeakier.

Songs of Black-headed and Rose-breasted are nearly identical, but Black-headed's "ik" call is lower pitched. Juvenile's begging call, a two-part, downslurred "swee-o", is a characteristic sound in mid- to late summer, even from southbound migrants.
Call and song quite similar to Black-headed Grosbeak.
Chip notes of parellina group of ssp. are strongly suggestive of Hooded Warbler; indigotica gives a high "ssip" call. Song, seldom heard in TX, is a short warble with a longer introductory note.
Listen for distinctive call, a loud, explosive "chink". Song is a series of rich, rising and falling warbles.
Song is a rapid series of varied phrases, thinner and sweeter than Indigo Bunting. Call is a loud, rich "chip".
Song is similar to Painted Bunting. Call is similar to Indigo Bunting, but slightly smoother.
Song is a series of varied phrases, usually paired. Calls include a sharp "pit" or "spitch"; flight call is a dry buzz.
Song is a series of varied phrases, sometimes paired; faster and less strident than Indigo Bunting.
Song is a clear, whistled "see-you see-yeeer"; distinctive call is a high, buzzy "drzzt", given in a rapid series in flight.

Song is a series of bubbling, flutelike notes of variable length, usually accelerating toward the end. Sharp "chuck" note; rattled flight call similar to Eastern, but lower pitched; also gives a whistled "wheet".

Male's loud, bubbling "bob-o-link" song, often given in flight, is heard in spring and summer. Flight call heard year-round and carrying a great distance is a repeated, whistled "ink". Also gives a blackbird-like "chuck" call.
Song is a liquid, gurgling "konk-la-reee", ending in a trill. Most common call is a "chack" note.
Song is a harsh, braying "on-ke-kaaangh"; lacks Red-winged's liquid tones. Call lower pitched than Red-winged.
Song begins with a harsh, rasping note, ends with a long, descending buzz. Call note is a distinctive rich "croak".
Call is a low "tschak"; song, a high, squeaky "koo-a-lee". Female sings as well, although her song is not as well described.
Typical call is a low "check"; song, a wheezy "que-ee" or "k-seee".
Song is a short, creaky "koguba-leek"; call note, a loud, deep "chuck".
Calls include a quiet "chuck" and a variety of rough squeaks, rattles, and other chatter. Most common song is a series of harsh "jeeb" notes.
Songs include clear whistles and loud "clack" notes; show marked geographical variation between eastern prosopidicola and western nelsoni. Call note is a low "chut" and a louder "clack".
Song, whistled notes followed by trills. Male's high-pitched sweet flight call is not like other cowbird. Other call a soft "chup"; females give a chatter.
Male's song is a squeaky gurgling. Calls include a harsh rattle and squeaky whistles.

Call is a harsh, guttural "chuck". Song is wheezy and buzzy, often delivered by displaying male in spectacular 'helicopter' fluttery flight over an often indifferent-looking female. The collective whistles of roosting males in winter can suggest European Starlings. Females give a rattle.  Vocalizations show some geographic variation.
Calls include a sharp "chuck". Song is a loud, rapid burst of whistled notes, downslurred at the end.
Calls include a distinctive whistled, rising "wheet"; song is a series of whistles, trills, and rattles.
"Wheet" call is softer than Hooded Oriole and does not rise in pitch. Chatter call resemble Baltimore Oriole.
Call is a nasal "nyeh", often repeated.
Male's song, heard throughout the year, is a long, loud series of melodic whistles. Female sings a less complex song. Call is a nasal "nyeh", a sharp "whip"; also a nasal chatter call.
Calls include a low, raspy "ike ike ike"; song is a series of clear, varied whistles.
Song is a serie of soft, tentative, three-note warbles. Both sexes sing. Call is a nasal "nyyyee" and a high-frequency buzz.

Common call is a rich "hew-li"; also gives a series of rattles different in quality (drier) and more stuttery than Bullock's series of "cheh" notes. Song is a musical, irregular sequence of "hew-li" and other notes.
Song is a mix of whistles and harsher notes; call is a harsh "cheh" or series of same and whistled "pheew".
Common call note is a harsh "shack"; also a scolding "chah-chah". Song is a mixture of rich, whistled phrases, reminiscent of Western Meadowlark. Females sing a weaker song.
Loud, whinnying trill; silent in winter
Mostly silent, but "gruck gruck" barks in winter
Short, harsh "kraak"; deep croak in flight
Usually silent
Silent, but clap their bill when greeting
Silent at sea, but barking "arr arr" at nest
"Khro khro" croaks at nest
Grunting "kroack-kraik-kroack"; silent at sea
Mostly silent, but hissing calls when angry
Trumpeting call like an old-fashioned car horn
Loud "kuru" calls like an excited dog
Noisy cackling and honking; "ahng-ong-ong" call in flight.
Loud trumpeting "ah-honk".
Males make a low whistling noise; females have a "gagagaga"call.
Males make a high "whe-ooo"; females make a purring sound
Males make a high "crik chrik"; females make a short, sharp "quack"
Females make a "quack quack" sound; males are much quieter
Mostly silent, but sometimes "quack quack"
Males make a deep "took took"; females have a quieter "quack"
Males croak in flight; females make a quacking "reck reck reck"
Mostly silent, but growling "kurr kurr" in flight
Mostly silent
Loud, explosive "corrk-kok" call; clucking in flight
Loud call which sounds like "go-bak, go-bak, bak-bak-bak"
Grating "kerrick" call when excited, especially at dusk
Mechanical "chuck-chukka-chuck" calls or gobbling and hissing
High-pitched wailing "pee-ooo-eee", similar to a buzzard
Noisy, high-pitched "peeee-uuuu", like a cat mewing
High-pitched "ki-ki-ki-ki-ki"
Harsh "kek-kek-kek-kek" sound
Loud "kek-kek-kek-kek" call
Clear, musical "kew-kew-kew"
Loud, sudden "kruuuuuk" call
Loud "kowk" call
Loud, high-pitched "kleep-a-kleep"
Loud "ee-wit" call
Two-note whistle, "poo-eep" or "choo-wee"
Sorrowful whistle, "pee-uu-eee"
Two-note whistle, "pu-weee"
Piping "klute klute" call when alarmed
Quiet, dull "wutt-wutt"
Sharp, hard "twick twick" in flight
Thin, reedy "shreee" or rasping "treerrr"
"Tuk-a-tuk-tuk" call in flight
Very musical, rising "courlee" call
Quick, yelping "kiruk kiruk" call in flight
Noisy "weeka-weeka-weeka"
Rapid "titti-titti-titti-titti", often repeated several times
Musical "teeu-tu-tu-" call and yodelling "lew-lew-lew"
Ringing three-part "tew-tew-tew" flight call
Loud, full-throated "tweet, weet-weet"
Shrill "swee-wee-wee" flight call
Mostly silent, but occasionally a low "wek"
Sharp "scaap" when flushed and a musical "chippa-chippa-chippa"
Harsh "keyaaar" call - their colonies are very noisy!
Mostly silent, but a "kitti-veeek" call by their nest (like their name!)
Very noisy - loud mewing and wailing cries, yelps and barks
Deep, throaty wailing "ouk ouk" calls
Deep "uk-uk-uk" bark
A shrill "keeee-yaa"
High-pitched "keee-yarrr"
Sounds like common tern, but higher-pitched
Rapid and shrill "krik-krik"
Noisy, harsh "ki-rrick"
Very noisy at their nest with a growling "arrrr"
Growling and gruning "caarr" calls at their nest
A low growling "arrrr"
Loud, throaty cackling and grunting
Loud wailing noises at nesting sites; "kuk-kuk-kuk-oo" in flight
Cooing calls, "ooo-roo-coo"
Rhythmic five-part cooing, "coo-ROO-roo, oo-roo"
Rhythmic two-part cooing, "ooo-woo, ooo-woo"
Cat-like purring, "rooorrr rooorrr"
Rhythmic three-part cooing, "coo-COO-coo"
Eerie shrieks - sometimes they are known as 'screech owls'
Long three-part "hoo-hoo-hoo"; females call "ker-wick"
Musical, rising "kiew kiew kiew"
Deep "boo-boo-boo", but usually silent
Low, moaning "ooo-ooo-oo"
Loud laughing "gluck-gluck-gluck"
Loud "tchick-tchick" call
Sharp, shrill "cheee"
Vibrant "cooo-ick" in flight; also a purring song sometimes for up to 5 minutes without a break
Loud "cuc-koo" in spring; also laughing "kow-kow-kow" if alarmed
Loud screaming "screeee", often in groups
Light "tswit-tswit" call; long twittering song
"Chirrup" call; soft twittering song
Low "chirrup" call; soft twittering song
Loud, high "tseep" call; fast warbling song
Loud "chirrup" call; warbling song
Weak "peep-peep-peep" call; high-pitched song
Whistling "pseep" call; song like meadow pipit but fuller
Sharp "tissik" flight call; simple warbling song
Loud "twseep" call; simple warbling song
Sharp, piercing "tsickick" call; twittering song with whistles
Sharp "zit zit" call; soft warbling song
High "sirrrrrrr"
Hard "tik tik" call; loud rattling song usually ending in a trill
"Wee-tak-tak" call, like stones struck together; short, quivering song
"Wee-tak-tak" call like a stonechat; warbling song
Rapid "tic tic" call; warbling, melancholy song - sometimes at night
"Wheeet" note like a willow warbler; hurried jingle song
Short, unmusical "zeee" call; scratchy weak song
Sharp "huit" call; short, simple "tzit zit trui trui" song
Low "tchook-tchook" call; rich, flute-like, melodic song
Loud "chak-chak-chak" call; song is various squeaks and whistles
Soft "tsip" call; loud, tuneful song with repeated phrases
Soft "seeep" call; falling whistling song
Loud rattling "tsarrk"; flute-like song like a blackbird
Complicated song with rattles, gurgles and whistles
Dry "chirr chirr" call; chattering song with sweet notes and chirrups
Sharp "chrrr" call; chattering song - less lively than a sedge warbler's
Harsh "tak" call; loud warbling song
Harsh "tak tak" call; short, scratchy song
Soft, repeated "hoo-eet" call; soft song ending with a flourish
"Hweet" call; repetitive "chiff-chaff chiff-chaff" song
Loud "sweet" calls; low "sioo sioo sioo" or fast "ti-ti-ti-ti-ikirrrrr" song
Hard "tic-tic tuc-tic tic" call; robin-like song
High-pitched "zee-zee" call; high-pitched song
Loud piping "tuit tuituit" call; whistling song
High-pitched "tsit" call; song is a falling series of notes
High-pitched "zee-zee" call with hissing "trrrr" trills
High "tsee" call; bright two-part "see-too, see-too" song
Thin, rising "see ssee" call; high trilling song
"Chink" call; lots of different songs, including *tea-cher tea-cher*
Shrill "pitchu" call; repeated "chip chip chip" song
Loud "skark skark" and loud screech
Loud and harsh "chacka-chacka-chacka"
Loud, deep "kraa-kraa"
Deep "kronk kronk" croak
Very loud "cawww"
Short, sharp "jack jack", and high-pitched "kyow"
Loud "chip-chip-chip" calls
Simple chirps and chirrups
Loud, high-pitchd chirruping and cheeping; "tek tek" in flight
Loud "tseek" call; song is repeated chirps
Grating "zit" call; song with deep final note "se-se-se-se-se-se-se-soo"
Loud "chink chink" call; bright rattling song ending in a flourish
Simple "twit-a-twit" call; long twittering song like a swallow
Loud "chup" call; wheezy song with whistles and twitters
Squeaky "tzeeu" call; twittering song
Deep buzzing "dzeeee"
Soft "pee-uu" call; quiet, creaky song
"Tsooeet" call; twittering, musical song
A melancholy, plaintive call; 3 sets of paired tremolos (Slud). In Panama, 2 long-drawn tremulous whistles, mainly at dawn and dusk (Eisenmann).

A clear, tremulous whistle of varying number of notes, rising with a slight change of pitch, then several downward notes ending on a minor key (Chalif). Like dragging the hammer up the upper keyes of a xylophone about 7 tones, then starting at original pitch and running down about 5 tones (Friedman and Smith).
Call of male a ventriloqual hollow "ah-oowah", the "oo" slurring down, then returning to pitch (Lancaster).
A plaintive minor whistle, "hoo-oo", with a slight upward inflection (RTP).
A piglike bass rattling "krurr" (Slud).
Suggest a night-heron: deep "quok quok quok" (Wetmore).
A harsh croaking "wok wok wok". Also a curious far-carrying snoring sound (Wetmore).
Quawking suggestive of a night-heron. Bill-rattling.
A catlike "myow"; a ringing cry suggestive of hawk-eagle (Slud). A far-carrying "kek-kek-kek-kek" (Wetmore).
A musical oriole-like whistle; a shrill scream.
A shrill "chiew-ip" (Laughlin); a thin "tsip-tsip-tsip-tsip-wheeeeeeooo"; also a thin, long-drawn "wheeeeoooo (Eisenmann).
A nasal whining whistle suggesting Roadside Hawk. A nasal "kahh" or "whaow".
Male has a soft clear whistle; female (near nest?) a loud "cac cac cac" (Amadon).
A nasal squealing whistle; also a harsh "haaaah"; a high 3-syllabled whistle (RTP).
A longish whistled "wheeeeeeeer"; in aerial display "keek-keek-keek" (Eisenmann).
Very unlike that of Great Black Hawk. An arresting "yeep-yeep-yeep-yeep"; also "pipipipipip" (Slud).
An almost jaylike "ya ya ya ya ya"; a nasal gutteral "whaaaaa" or "whag" (Chalif).
A harsh "karrr" (RTP).
A loud plaintive "cree-eer" (RTP).
A querulous "heyaaa"; a hoarse whistling "seeuu" (Chalif). A buzzy or hissing squeal, "kzweeeooo" (Eisenmann).
A repeated "ke-ke-ke-ke-ke-ke"; also "cut-a, cut-a", etc.
A squealing whistle, suggesting Red-tail's (RTP).
A wailing "wheeeeooooo".

A ringing call, "whut, whut, whut-eeeeeeeer, whut-eeeer" (Willis). Calls constantly when soaring; a liquid, loud, melancholy phrase, "oolee'oo" or "tleewee'oo" or "kweeoo"; sometimes "kee keek leeweeoo" (Eisenma). "Ka reee oh" (Alden).
Call, "whee whee wee wee wheet" (Alden).
A loud harsh "cacao" or "ca-ca-ca-ca-caw", from which it derives its Spanish name, 'Comecacao' (Land).
Harsh grating calls, "trak-trak-trak". Also "quick-quick-quick-querr", last note delivered with toss of head (Amadon and Brown).

Very much like a human laugh; a loud shrill "ha ha ha" repeated up to 14 times (Grossman). A rather fast "hah, hah, hah-hah-hahahahah", somewhat accelerating and falling slightly in pitch (Eisenmann).
One to several distinctly separated barking sounds, much like those of a small dog (Slud).
A loud "hah hah hah", etc., suggesting Laughing Falcon.
A thin querulous "krree krree krree kree", etc., or "peel peel" (5-8 times), suggesting Kestrel (Chalif).

Alarm, a harsh chickenlike cackle. Characteristic call, a raucous 3-syllabled "cha-ca-lac", repeated in chorus from treetops, especiall in morning and evening. Dr. A. A. Allen described a chorus as "keep'-it-up, keep'-it-up, keep'-it-up" etc., answered by a lower "cut-it-out, cut-it-out".
Similar to Plain Chachalaca's but 4-syllabled.
Call 4-syllabled, similar to West Mexican Chachalaca's but 'less burry, with closer intervals' (Vaurie).
Harsh throaty cackles; honking sounds. 'A loud metallic "kwank" or "kwink" repeated many times' (Chalif).
A long whistle, steady in volume but rising in pitch over a 2-octave range (Land).
A deep low 3- or 4-note "oo-oo-oo", repeated several times and having a soft mooing quality. Also mandible-clacking and croaking (Andrle).

Male has a high, thin, whistled "wheeeoo" and "wheep"; also "whee, whee whee". A squeaky "weeyp". Sometimes combined as "wheeyp wheeeeeee" (rising in pitch). During display, a low-pitched hooting ending in a boom - "whoooo-hoohoo; boom". Female a soft "hmmm"; also a "hoot-hoot" (Eisenmann).
A squeal when flushed.
A clearly whistled "bob-white!" or "poor, bob-whoit!". Covey call, "ka-loi-kee?" answered by "whoil-kee" (RTP).
Practically indistinguishable from Common Bobwhite's.
Similar to Common Bobwhite's.
Loud; a low-high-low combination: "grouww-chow-lo" or "hrook-chou-low", repeated (Chalif). An excited, ringing "whipa-whipee'o"; repeated, musical (Eisenmann).
Loud clear whistles, beginning with 4 whistles increasing in volume (but decreasing in interval), then 3 to 6 repeated phrases. Call note, "pitter pititit" (Chalif).
A soft whinnying or quavering whistle. Ventriloquial (vaguely suggests Common Screech-Owl).
Gobbling utterly unlike that of "Meleagris" and may be written as "ting-ting-ting-co-on-cot-zitl-glung", the last note having a bell-like quality (Leopold).
A deep, chesty grunting; also a clucking "tuk-tuk-tuk" etc., gradually accelerating (Bond).
A striking cry, heard most often at dawn or dusk; a repeated chickenlike cackle: "pop-tiyi pop-tiyi co-co-co-co-co" or "chittyco chittyco caw-caw-caw" (Slud).
A peculiar bark of 1-3 otes (Chalif). Note, "Kow", given one or repeated; suggests Pied-billed Grebe (Wetmore).
A mournful, dragging tinamoulike whistle (RTP). A reedy trill; a plaintive piping.
A sharp cackle, especially in flight. Also rasping, chattering, and clacking notes.
Note, a sharp meallic "tsee"; also a slightly rolling "tur-r-r" (Wetmore).
Very noisy at nght. 'A long-continued "prrrip prrrip prrrip pip pip pip pipipipipipipipip" (Slud).
A low owl-like "wof, wof, wo, co-woo" (Maynard).
Cooing more drawn out than White-winged Dove's "who who wooooooo", long note swelling (RTP).
Sounds like 'Santa Cruz'; 1st  notes (San-ta) short and musical, last note (Cruz) a long "cooooouu" (Chalif). "Coo'oo, ruk-tu-coo'oo" or "ruk-tu-coo'oo" (Eisenmann).
A fairly loud "hhoo-oo'-hoo"; slightly resonant (Andrle).
"Ooo", then "oo-coo-hooooo", descending on a long drawn note (Chalif). A melancholy, drawn-out "hoo, cu-cu-coo'oo", sometimes shortened to "cook, cuckoo'oo" (Eisenmann).
A mournful "cuacoo-coo-coo" like a Mourning Dove but slightly more curtailed; also a short "oaa-oo" (Bond).
A harsh cooig, "who cooks for you?"; also "ooo-uh-cuck'oo". Sounds vaguely like crowing of young rooster.
2 notes on same pitch, "coo-hoo" or *no hope* (RTP).
A soft monotonously repeated "woo-oo". In distance sounds monosyllabic: "wooo", with rising inflection (RTP)>
A rather fast "whoop-whoop-whoop", etc. 10-30 times, often given without pause; speed varies (Eisenmann).
"Whoop" or "per-woop", repeated 2-24 times (Chalif).
A single "woop" or sometimes "poooop", repeated after a pause (Eisenmann). A single deep "hawp" or "hoop" (Slud).
A deep "woop-woop-woop", etc., similar to that of Blue Ground-Dove, but much shorter intervals (Eisenmann).
A low, soft, ghostly "oo-whooooooo"; at a distance only the hollow drawn-out "whooooo" is audible (RTP).
A plaintive "cu-cu-cu-oooo" (Bond).
A short, hollow "cooooo" (Smithe).
A sorrowful "oooo", almost on 1 pitch (Chalif).
A fairly soft, low-pitched "who-who'-oo", last syllable slurred downward (Andrle).
A low humming "mmmm", at 0.5-second intervals (Eisenmann); a prolonged, booming note, suggesting fog buoy (Bond).
Deep and very loud notes heard at rare intervals (Dickey and van Rossem). A booming "whoooooo" (Parker).
Loud raucous cries.
Harsh calls - "rrraaaa" (Haverschmidt).
Sharp, squeaky notes, shrill noisy chatter.
Noisy, shrieking chatter.
Raucous, screechy; "can-can-can" or "ca-ca-ca" (Slud).
Squawks, screeches. Audible more than ile (Wetmore).
In flight, cries suggestive of small songbirds (Slud).
Constant chattering in flight, quiet when perched.
In flight, a shrill noisy chattering. A scratchy "ra-a-a-a-a-a-a-a" or "ack-ack-ack", etc. (Slud). A semimusical "week, week, kweekee'roo, kee'roo, kee'roo", etc. (Eisenmann).
High-pitched, including a thin, unparrotlike "tseek", and a "cheek-cheek" varied to "check-check" (Eisenmann).
Noisy, screeching calls.
A noisy yapping, "ak-ak-ak" or "yap-yap-yap".
A harsh "kree-o, krak-krak-krak" (RTP).
Noisy; "kyake kyake kyake", etc., or "yoik yoik yoik", etc., "ack-ack" or "eck-eck", etc. (Slud).
Raucous cries; often with a human quality.
Noisy; a rolling "krrrillik, krrrillik", etc., and a raucous "chowk, chowk", etc. (RTP). Flight calls usually include a "chop-chop" phrase (Schwartz) or "kyup-kyup" (Eisenmann).
A deep throaty, rather deliberately uttered "gaw-gaw-gaw", etc. (Bond). Call of Yellow-bill is faster.
A series of 5-10 slow whistling "yeep's"; also "ya-aaa" (Chalif). "Geep-kareer", suggestive of call of Kiskadee; also a loud clear series "whep, whep, whep", etc. (Eisenmann).
A repeated "whee-o" or "tee-ho" (1st note slurring up and thin, 2nd lower); in flight a low chuckling note (RTP).

A high clear 2-note whistle, "feen-feeen" (2nd note half a tone higher), repeated at steady intervals (Chalif). A melancholy, repeataed "puu-peee", etc. (Eisenmann). Also a melancholy series of 4 short whistles, last lower in pitch (Land). The bird responds to an imitation of its call.

Resembles 2-note whistle of Striped Cuckoo, but with a 3rd trilled note, "puu, peee, pr'r'r'r" (Eisenmann). A 3-note whistle, "whoo-hee-wer'r'r'r'r", the 2nd higher, the 3rd with a tinamou-like quaver (Willis).
A series of short burbling whistles, suggestive of a referee's whistle: "prrr-rrr-prrr-prrrr", etc.; series dropping slightly in pitch and slowing in interval (RTP).
Softer than Greater Roadrunner's; a soft mournful "coo" given 4 times in descending scale (Chalif).
Similar to 'bouncing ball' song of Common Screech-Owl of w. U.S., but much louder, with a gruff threatening quality. Also a trill or double tril.
A series of 13-15 short notes rising in pitch then dropping to starting pitch. A loud, gruff, slow trill of threatening quality; the notes sound like "pup-pup-pup", etc. (Marshall).

"Boobooboo-boo, bobooboo-boo", etc. (3 "boo"'s, a pause and a "boo"); the arrangement of this 'code' may vary. At times a repeated 4-syllabled "chooyoo-coocooo", vaguely suggestive of White-winged Dove; also a rapid series of 1 pitch "boo boo boo boo boo boo boo boo", usually slowing toward end (RTP). A syncopated duetting of short and long notes like Morse code, all on the same pitch. Usual phrase, 2 'dots' and 3 'dashes' delivered thrice and termined with an extra 'dash' (Marshall).
A short trill like cricket. Very faint. Also little, single, inflected, plaintive whistles (Marshall).

A tremulous series of quavering notes rising to a crescendo, then cutting off sharply. Suggests call of eastern form of Common Screech-Owl (Land). Song, a long trill on 1 pitch, like a spadefoot toad, starting softly, gradually swelling, then it cuts off abruptly (Marshall).
A peculiar growling, somewhat froglike "k'k'k'k'-krrrrrr"; or at a distance, "grrrrrr" (Eisenmann).
A deep abrupt "bu hu hu" or "bu hu hu hui", easily imitated (Wetmore). A long-continued rapid series of chucks, similar to rapid tapping of a woodpecker (Anthony).
Northern Pygmy-Owl gives a single took every 2-3 seconds, also a series: "too-too-too-too-too-too-too-too", ending with a slow "took, took, took".
Note is "poop", whistled 1-12 times (Slud). Similar to voice of Northern Pygmy-Owl but notes higher-pitched, series shorter.

A mellow staccato whistle, "poop" or "purp" or "poip", often repeated rapidly and monotonously 2-3 times per second (RTP). Calls in daytime as well as night. (Ferruginous Pygmy Owl gives a more rapid "poop" or "purp" or "poip", 2-3 per second, a great many times.)
A rapid high-pitchd "whi-whi-whi-whi-whi-whi" or "chewk-chewk-chewk-chewk", etc., becoming higher, more yipping, puppylike, and chattering in middle of series (RTP).

"Waaa-a'-oooo"; harsh and mournful, increasing in pitch and volume, then decreasing. Also "boo, boo-ab, boo-ab, boo-ab, boo-ab, boo-ab" (Chalif). A downward modulated "hoot"; a semiwhistled screech; a gruff growl (Eisenmann).
A loud, drawn-out, catlike "whee-u-u-u" (Ingles). A resonant, low-pitched "whoo, whoo, whoo" (Eisenmann).
Hooting, similar to that of Barred Owl.
A barking hoot, "ow, ow, ow, ow" often increasing in loudness. A loud, penetrating "keeeeeeyou" (Eisenmann).
A loud "hu" or "hu-hu" (Bond).
A series of 10 mellow whistles, each distinct, but not staccat. Much softer than whistle of Ferruginous Pygmy-Owl (Marshall).
A harsh, uncouth, grating sound, "wah-h-h oo-oo-oo", strongly guttural; unbirdlike (Wetmore).

A guttural "how-wow"; also a hoarse "waark-cucu" (Bond). Also a series of loud, sustained notes becoming slightly softer at the end, "wah-wah-wah-wah-wu-wu-susu"; something between a wail and a laugh (Chalif). Bids from sw. Costa Rica to S. America utter extremely sweet plaintive whistles dropping in pitch ("poor-me-one"); not recorded in our area.
At night, a hoarse whistle, "pur-we'eeeeer"; sometimes with 1 or 2 preliminary notes ("pup pup pur-we'eeeeer"). At a distance only the breezy "we'eeeeer" is heard (RTP).
"Ree'-o-ree'", rising in intensity on 1st and last syllables, dropping abruptly on middle syllable. Produced rapidly and several time sin succession (Paynter).
Somewhat similar to that of Common Poorwill. A rapidly repeated "chuck-will" (Chalif) or "chip-willow" (Sutton). Yucatan birds utter a single vibrato "will" in series (Davis).
Unbirdlike. A rapid, staccato, insectlike series, ending on an emphatic phrase in a higher pitch: "cuk-cuk-cuk-cu-cuk-cuk-cuk-cukacheea" (Davis).
A loud, high-pitched passerine-like "pit-sweet" or "spit-sweet" (Zimmerman).
A shrill "screee-screee", reminiscent of European Swift (Bond). A loud explosive "cheeach" (Chalif).
Call, a low chatter (Wetmore), "dzip-dzip-dzip".
Rapid twitters. Song, a single squeaky "sree" repeated monotonously (Skutch).
Squeaky. Song, a deliberate "chip-chip-chip-chip" followed by a rapid higher-pitched "do-da-do-a-da" (Smithe).
High-pitched squeaks and rattles. Song, a musical trill: "chee-twee-twee-twee-twee-trill-chup-chup" (Skutch); or "stchip-stchip-stchip sku'r wee" (Slud).
Spirited, chippering squeals, squeaks (Sutton).
Song weak, unmelodious: "tsee tsee, tuc see, tu wit see" in slow tempo, squeaky voice (Skutch).
Squeaky 'tsitting' notes (Slud).
Loud double note given often while perched (Alden).
And endlessly repeated wiry "tseee-tseeree" (Slud).
A chatter. In aerial display, hum of female is high-pitched; has "zing of rifle bullet" (Willard).
Weak chipping, tsitting, and ticking notes.
A low, clear "tink, tink, tink", sounding like a small bell (Skutch). A metallic rattle; various other notes.
A warblerlike song of usually 4 two-syllabled notes: "see-bit see-bit see-bit see-bit". Also "tsit" notes (Slud).
Song, a series of 2-3 lisping squeaks, "tsk-see-seet-seet-seet" (Willis).
A descending 'tsittering' trill similar to that of Rufous-tailed Hummingbird (Slud).
Shrill, squeaky notes.
A descending trill of rapidly given "ts" notes. Song, 2-4 sibilant, piercing accented "tss" notes (Slud).
A squeaking "seek".
Note, a thin sharp "chip".
A weak "tsir" or "tsup" (Slud).
A repetitious 2-note call (1st not high, 2nd low) (Chalif). 2 calls: a low double note, "wahco, wahco, etc.", and a whistled "whee'oo" (Eisenmann).
A rather slow deliberate series, "cow, cow, cow" etc., or "cuk, cuk" etc.. Also a "kereek, kereek, kereek" (Eisenmann).
"Cow, cow, cow, cow-cow-cow-cowcow", the 1st 3 or 4 given slowly, then faster toward the end (Chalif). A harsh clucking, accelerating into a chatter (Skutch).
While perched, "tucka-tucka-tucka". Also a slow "cow", repeated 4-6 times. Alarm, a low sharp "tuck" or "cut". In flight, a rapid low "cut-a-cut-cut" (Chalif).
A series of low, coarse notes, slightly bisyllabic: "kowm kowm kowm kowm kowm kowm" or "koa, koa" etc. (RTP).
A guttural "kwa kwa kwa kwa kwa kwa"; also "choi choi choi choi choi choi" or "cow cow", etc. (Chalif).
A soft, sweet, pleasant, "cow-cow-cow", etc., incessantly repeated (Skutch).
A rusty "cla-ack" or "wa-ak" (Webster).
A short harsh "chert" (Chalif); sometimes repeated in a rattle.
A sharp "tick tick tick"; also a sharp squeak (RTP).
A scratchy "tsweek"; creaking notes (Slud).
A rapid screech-owl-like quavering "cooooooo-o-o-o-oh"; also a low continued "hoot-hoot-hoot", etc. (Willis).
A ringing "oot-oot-oot" at 5-second intervals (Parker).
A loud far-reaching "cut-cut-cakock'", strikingly like the cackle of a hen (Lowery and Dalquest)
A guttural froglike cry. Also "ka-wock kawock" and a chickenlike "awk awk" (Slud).
A low "krrrooop" (Chalif).
A very low resonant, owl-like "hoot-hoot" or "oot-boot", often given before daybreak (RTP).
A nasal "peet". A variety of calls, including a succession of short clear notes running up or down scale (Chalif).
A thin, high, reedy twitter (Eisenmann).
Seldom heard; a high-pitched "peep"; a long-drawn plainive "tzeeee" (Skutch).
A monotonously repeated scratchy "krrrk" or "grrik"; very froglike (RTP). A very often repeated "gaab" (Chalif).
Low nasal barking notes; repetitious froglike calls, ec. Said to mimic other birds.
A squeaky, repeated "we-chip, we-chip, we-chip", etc. (RTP). A repeated "ksee-yik" (Eisenmann).
A laughing rattle; a sharp little "pss pss" (Slud).
A high "peek" and a lower "cuchrrrrrrrr". Suggests a flicker (Chalif). "Wicka, wicka, wicka" (Eisenmann).
A loud "cheek-oo, cheek-oo, cheek-oo" (Alden).
"Churrr, churrr, churrr"; also a higher, sharp "chirriree" or "keereereek" (Eisenmann).
A rolling "churr" and a sharp "pit" or "yip" (RTP).
A tremulous rolling "churrrr". A flickerlike "kek-kek-kek-kek" etc. (RTP).
A rapid harsh rasping "zur-zur-zur-zur", etc. (Slud).
A rattling series: "chikikkkikikikkik", diminishing. Note, a sharp "pick" or "chik" (RTP).
A sharp "spik" or "tseek", sharper than notes of Ladder-backed Woodpecker. A hoarse whinny (RTP).
"Ka ka ka ka ka kay". Call suggests a nuthatch (Chalif). Has a distinctive double rap when it drums.
Usual note a reedy, sometimes quavering "squirp"; call a long-drawn softened rattle (Slud).
Reedy, scratchy, or squeaky noes; a chattering and a churring "rattle", and a grating-pulley sound (Slud).
A dry rattle or twitter on descending scale (Chalif). Also described as a watch spring suddenly running down, a forced buzz, rising in pitch, then descending rapidly.
A fine "chip"; may be rapidly repeated. Song, a rapid warblerlike trill that tapers off sharply (Skutch).
A loud rough "schifferty-schifferty-schifferty-schiff"; also call notes, "yip-yip-yip" and "pee-yub" (Willis).
A loud "tew'-wee, tew'wee, tew'wee" (Howell). A slow "oi-ink", repeated 2-3 times (Slud).
Noisy. Call, a descending series of plaintive "wick"'s, each gradually losing intensity (Slud).
A rapid, whistled series "whi whi whi whi", etc., running down the scale; or may end with a bright "whee-whee" (RTP)
2 or more sad 'desolately whistled sighs' that taper downward and are successively lower (Slud).
A series of fast even notes, "chichichichi", etc., on same pitch or rising and falling in pitch (Chalif).
A low "tseeyup" or "cheeyup" (Chalif). A 3-note set of reedy squeaks (Slud).
Song, 3 or 4 emphatic notes ascending in pitch, and dropping on last note: "wit-wit-wit-tew" or "pit-peet-peechew" (RTP). "Zheezhee-zee-zhoo" (Monroe).
A harsh "nye-wee'yo" (Eisenmann).
3 or 4 long inflected whistles much like a human whistle (Marshall). A clear 2-note call (Rowley).
A snorting "churr" or nasal roll. Also a low, harsh, frog-like 'crecking' "churr" (Slud).
A fine, sharp, very rapid trill (Skutch). A high thin "tsiss"; other hisslike notes (Slud).
A series of sharp descending "squee"'s (Slud).
Song, "pwik-wik-wik-wik-wik-wik-wik-wik"; rises and speeds in middle, then slows somewhat (Slud).
An accelerating series of hoots, suggesting a trogon; often terminated by a nasal snarl (Eisenmann).
A rapid, accelerating roll or rattle, "kuk-kuk-kuk-uk-uk-uk-k-k-k-kkkkkkk", ending with an emphatic "wek" (RTP").
Resembles that of Barred Antshrike (Land).
Song, a measured series of "tswit"'s, intensifying, then falling. Call notes, "switsit" or "weesawisst" (Slud).
Song excellent, suggests certain antshrikes, but higher-pitched, faster: "hee, hee, hee-hee-hee-heeheeheehee". Call, a nasal "nyoot, nyoot" (Eisenmann).
Song, "t'weet t'weet t'weet, t'weet weet weet weet weet", in very low soft notes (Skutch). Call, a nasal, whining "nyeeah"; also a sharp "pseeyt" (Eisenmann).
Song, 6 weak ascending notes, followed by a falling rattle: "chee chee chee chee chee chee chr'r'r'r'r'r" (Skutch). Calls, "wit-wit; tit-tit; cheet, cheet, etc." (Eisenmann).
Song, 5-8 piping whistles rising irregularly in pitch, "pu, pu, pipipee" and "pu, peh, pi'pipipeepee" (Eisenmann).
Song, about 8 loud, rich "cheep"'s, the last few speeded up; suggests Dusky Antbird (Slud).
A rapid series of mellow whistles on an even pitch, starting with 1 deliberate note: "whew, hew-hew-hew-hew-hew-hew-hew-hew" (RTP).
A hollow, repeated whistle, accelerating, then slowing: "cow, cow, cow-cow-cowcowcowcow, cow" (Skutch).
A prolonged "wip-pip-pipürürürürürr-prürr" (Slud).
Male in display flicks wings and gives a rough, flat buzz (*Bronx cheer* or *raspberry*). Also light "tsit" notes. When leaving perch, male makes a dry snap (RTP).
A mournful, whistled "teoo-ho", the "teoo" slurred, "ho" lower (RTP).
In display dance, wing-snapping, terminating in a short buzz (Land).
A 3-part whistle, pensive and restrained - 1st part ascending, 2nd very short, 3rd ascending (Skutch). "Ho-wee'-pee" (Smith).
In flight, males make a sound intermediate between a rapid tinkle and a rattle (Skutch).
A musical "weeba weeba weeba weeba" (Chalif). A fly-catcherlike "wheet, wheet - wheet - wheeto, wheeto" (RTP).
A loud, clear, deliberate "tee', deh" (almost half second between notes); sometimes "tee'-dee-deh" (Eisenmann).
A minor-keyed 2-note *wolf whistle*. Also a sad "weep" (Slud). An emphatic mournful *so-dear* (Eisenmann).
A loud, emphatic whistled "choowee'oo", sometimes "whee'oo" or "pee'a" or "whee'oo" (Eisenmann).
Song, a loud whistled trill, "tee-dee-dee-dee-dee-dee-dee". Call, "tew-dee-dee" (Eisenmann).
Song, 6 or 7 quick liquid notes, each higher and weaker; sometimes at same pitch (Chalif). A rhythmic tittering series, "teet-teet-teet-teet-teet-teet" (Eisenmann).
Song, a sweet repetitious, 2- or 3-note whistle "sir-piti, sir-piti", etc., with rising inflection (RTP).
A thin 2-syllabled whistle, "swee-at" (Chalif).
Grunting notes. A dry  "quert-quert" (Sutton). A nasal "quet, quet, quet", varied to "quit, quit, quit" (Eisenmann).
Call, a soft rattle; also a nasal "wuz wuz" or "swaz-waz" (Chalif). Notes less grunty than last species.
A slightly phoebelike "p-p-pit-zee" or "pit-a-zee"; elaborated during male's butterfly like hovering display flight.
A pebbly "krrrrrr"; a metallic "zlit"; a clicking sound produced by bill.
A low nasal "queer" or "chi-queer" or "ki-dear"; also an excited "ki-ki-ki-dear, ki-dear, ki-dear", etc.
Shrill bickering calls; a sharp "whit" or "whit-ker-whit".

T. m. couchii, a high nasal, slurred "queer" or "chi-queer" or "preer", resembling notes of Cassin's Kingbird but higher. Also "preer-tiwichew". A long-drawn "gereeeeeeer", suggesting a distant Pauraque. Voice of the more widespread Cen. American for (T. m. chloronitis) is high-pitched, rapid twittering "piririreeree"; als a loud clear "seet-teet-teet".
"Brrr-zee" or "purr-eet".
A rising and falling "swee-el", followed by "dididi" on level pitch. A partly trilled, complaining "wee'-yee" with an added "piririree".
A high penetrating "kee-zee'-ik! Kee-zee'-ik!" given by both male and female, often in duet.
"Si sip sip seyf" (rising on "seeyf"); "bap-bap-bap-bap", ending with "seeyf". A semiwhistled "chee'oo-reweep" or "wee'-a-roweep" often introduced by a "chup".
A rough, rasping "khrrrrr"; also a loud repeated "chirrup", suggestive of House Sparrow. "Kee'rrrik", vaguely suggesting Belted Kingfisher's rattle.
An excited "chee' cheechee' cheechee' cheechee'". A loud harsh "kree'yoo"; also a rapid explosie "kee'yoo-kyi-kyi-kyi-kee".
A loud "kis-ka-deer" or "ki-deer"; also "dzhee" or "queee". "Geep career, geep, geep career".
A loud whistled "wheeeep!" (rising inflection); a rolling "prrrrret!". Also "whoit-whoit-whoit".
"Pwit"; also a rolling "chi-beer" or "prit-wherr". "Ka-brick"; also "ha-whip" and "ha-wheer".
A clear, penetarting, whistled "peer"; suggests voice of Dusky-capped Flycatcher, but higher, less plaintive.
A sharp "whit", a short "prrrr", and a rolling throaty "purreeer". Voice stronger than Ash-throated Flycatcher's.
Call, a long whistled "wheeeeee" rising in pitch; also a shorter call rising, then dropping.
A mournful whistle, slurring down, "peeur". A whistled "wheeeww" and "wheeeep", sometimes slurred.
Plaintive, suggesting Dusky-capped Flycatcher. Also a low bubbling or rolling "prrrreep".
Plaintive song, "pee-ur" and "pee-a-wee".
Nasal song "peeyee" or "peeeer".
A burred and slightly trilled "preeee"; a repeated "swee'rrip"; a "wheerrt" or "prrreet".
Song, a thin plaintive whistle, "ho-say", "re-ah" or "ho-say, ma-re-ah" (*José María*).
"Che che che che tse tse tse tse". A fast piping "peepeepeepeepeepeepee", and a plaintive, rapidly given "turee-turee".
Voice, a spiritless "chur-wee".
Voice, a rising "spit-chee!" or a thin "peet".
Not recognizable in field except by voice, a sneezy "fitz-bew"; may call in winter.
Not separable in field except by voice; this species sings "zwee-bee'-o" or "fee-bee'-o".
A sharp "buzzt". Song, an explosive, but not loud, "pseeyp" or "kzeeyip".
Voice, "che-bek'".
Dawn song (sometimes heard all day), 3 thin notes: "pseet-trip-seet!". Arrangement varies.
Dawn song, "seee seee chit", sometimes "see chit see"; call "tseeent" or "psink".
"Chicky-whew" (Lusk); "chee-lick" (Brandt).
Song, "ra-reee-e-e-e-reechoo"; "twheeyu, tr-r-r-eet-yu".
An excited "pic-pic-pweer" or "pic-pic-piweer".
A thin "tsee'oo-tee" or "seeoo-bzew". A high thin "chee'-twit".
Note, a sharp "psit". Song, 5 high, sharp notes followed by about 5 warbled notes. Also "cheu cheu cheu cheu" in a pleasant voice.
A loud, clear hollow-sounding whistle; also a higher, sharper, wiry note, repeated many times.
A nasal or reedy "tidit" or "itarit". A frequently repeated buzzy, 2-noted call.
A thin hissing whistle, insistent; suggests lisping call of Cedar Waxwing; "ss-ss-ss-ss".
Note, a weak, harsh, sputtering whistle.
"Ziziup, ziziup", etc., repeated 3-5 times. A resonant trill, "trrrrr", repeated at intervals. Also a short "srrrr, atsip"; a serie of high "tick" notes.
Call, "tip-trrrr"; also "turp"; "trrrp-trrp". A rattling trill, "trrrrrrii".
A short trilled whistle, "wwwwwwwww", given very softly; bird will respond to imitation.
A noisy "pweer" or "preeup". Also "preeup preeup whi preeup", repeated insistently. A harsh grating "kreeo" or "kreeo wee kreeo"; also a burred "freeee".
A harsh "je eyup whe whe yup". "Che-eup", often followed by "wi-wi-eup".
A burred, drawled "peweelike" "peeee-err" and a "peeoo",varied to "wheeoo" and "whee".
Note, a buzzy "cheez" or "cheez weez".
Call note, a thin "peeee-yuk" or "squee-up". Also a series of fine gentle notes, "ee, ee, ee, ee", increasing in volume toward middle of series.
A frequently uttered, semiwhistled "peeee yick" or "chee-yip"; also a short trill.
A series of 3-5 "dee"'s, of about same pitch.
Exceedingly loud and harsh, seeming to come from a bird 3 times its size.
Song, a monotonously repeated "twick-twick-twick", etc. (3 per second), or a slower "tsyick-tsyick-tsyick".
"Chi-chi" or "jir jir jir".
A note that sounds like "zweep".
A musical "chrrrr". Song, a warbling, rather musical "churrr churrrche churrr", etc.
A clear "weet" or "cheweet"; a loud accented "chu, chu". Song, a series of squeaks blending into a complex melodic warble; ending in double-toned notes.
Birds of the Gulf slope utter a surprisingly low, hoarse "craw" or "khurrr". Birds of the Pacific slope have a higher voice; a shrill "creow".
Noisy; a variety of jaylike sounds; a harsh reiterated "grah" or "khrah"; also a querulous, downward-slurring "kew, kew, kew", or "kyoo, kyoo, kyoo, kyoo", etc.; bubbling and stuttering sounds.
Similar to Black-throated Magpie Jay's.
Similar to that of Blue Jay of N. America but more asal; a harsh *thief! thief!*. An exchited "jhay! jhay jhay", etc., higher in pitch than Blue Jay.
Highly variable; most common basic call, "rak" (varied to "ruk", "rook", "tuk", or "pik"); also a low-intensity, nasal "aaagh" and a bell-like "ped-el" or "pid-it".
A rapid "cheh cheh cheh cheh"; alsoo a slower "cleep, cleep, cleep", etc.; a dry throaty rattle; also other calls.
A loud excited 'spinking', almost ringing "peenk peenk peenk peenk"; also a harsh "aaaa".
Suggests Scrub Jay; a rapid scolding "kwesh-kwesh-kwesh"; a soft querulous "shrreee".
A doubly inflected, harsh, nasal, querulous "perzheeup", singly or in groups. Not loud.
Rough rasping notes "kwesh - kwesh". Also a harsh "check-check-check-check" and a rasping "shreek" or "shrink".
A rough, querulous "wink? wink?" or "zhenk?".
Similar to Gray-breasted Jay's, more varied.
A loud "shook-shook-shook" or "shack-shack-shack" or "wheck-wek - wek - wek" or "kewsh kwesh kwesh", etc.
Harsh chattering, similar to Band-backed Wren's.
Suggests a muted jay, "raha, raha, raha, raha". "Tsu-ka, tsu-ka", etc.
Song, a jerky, chanting "howdit howdiwit howdiwit howdiwit"; also a repetitious "chi-i-up" 4-6 times.
A low monotonous "chuh-chuh-chuh-chuh", etc., or "chug-chug-chug-chug-chug", on 1 pitch. Unbirdlike.
Song series more bisyllabic than that of Cactus Wren; a dry, rollicking "chortle-chortle-chortle".
A 2- or 3-syllabled whistled phrase, repeated usually 3 times in a rollicking chant. Variable.
4 whistled notes, repeated 3-5 times. A screechy trisyllabic "chin-cheer-gwee", repeated 3 times, apparently in duet by 2 birds ("chin-cheer", then a lower answering "gwee"). "Cheen'-chiriguee'"
A succession of repetitious whistles on various pitch levels: "prrrrrr, chechecheche, wit-wit-wit-wit-wit"; or "wee, whe-whewhe, chur-chur, choochoochoochoo" etc.
Song, a repetitious series beginning and ending with a higher note: "twee-chachalahlahlahlahlahlah-twee". A rhythmic series of 'hooting' notes starting and ending with a higher-pitched "whit!".
A rising "whee", followed by a descending and accelerating "whee whi chou chou chou chou" (3-5 "chou"'s).
Song variable. One version suggests White-eyed Vireo but more elaborate, "wheet-we-wi-we'yu-you". An ascending buzz or trill; also a repetitious chant, "swee-purpiyou, swee-purpiyou, swee-purpiyou".
Song variable; typically a thin trill, prefaced by 1 or 2 high burry notes, "swee, swee, cheeeeeeee". May suggest Song Sparrow.
Song similar in pattern to other races of T. aedon.
Song strongly resembles bubbling or gurgling song of eastern populations of Northern House-Wren; also a loud, rapid musical "chwee-chwee-chwee-chwee-chwee".
Loud and nasal; suggests Southern House-Wren but is said to lack cheerful vitality.
Song, clear whistled phrases, repeated *cheery-cheery-bee, cheery-cheery-bee* etc.. "Churry-churry-cheeer" etc., and also "chwee-teew-teew".
A variety of ringing whistled phrases; a phrase may be repeated over and over before changing: "too-teeoo-weet'", etc.; "weetee, weetoo", etc.; "wee-loo-weechee", etc.
Musical, rhythmic tinkling and bubbling; softly given, ventriloquial.
Song, a varied chant, "tew, tew, tew, tew" or "chr-wee, chr-we, chr-wee" or "che-poo, che-poo, che-poo", etc. Call, a loud dry trill on 1 pitch; also a clear "ti-keer".
A gushing cadence of clear curved notes tripping down the scale, sometimes picking up at the end: "te-you, te-you, te-you tew tew tew tew" or "tee tee tee tee tew tew tew teew".
A sharp "peenk", often repeated.
An often endless series of single whistled notes, each well separated and higher or lower than the next, the key seemingly picked at random.
Notes and phrases of song similar to other thrashers; some pairing as in Brown Thrasher's. Call, "too-ree".
Musical thrasherlike phrases, paired or in threes.
Note, a sharp liquid "whit-wheet!" like a human whistle of attention. Song, a musical series of ntes and phrases, almost grosbeaklike in quality. Not much repetition.
Song, varied phrases suggestive of Northern Mockingbird but lower in pitch, less repetitious.
Similar to Blue Mockingbird's.
Song similar to Northern Mockingbird's but more leisurely, not so loud; less repetition of phrases or none. Predominant phrases are "churr", "chweee", and "chwee'oo".
Song, typical American Robin-like phrases, caroling.
Typical robinlike phrases.

A splendid singer; lively, somewhat repetitious phrases (like a thrasher's) that follow one another in varying sequence; often "whoa" or "whoa-ah-ah" in midst of song. Characteristic call, a froglike nasal croak, "yenk" or "urnk"; also a screechy "dzee'-yoo".
Song, similar to but mellower than American Robin's. Call note, "meoo" or "meow"; this often repeated.

Song, very inferior for a Turdus of the 'robin' group; hurried and monotonous with repetitions of same note and few changes in pitch. Calls, "cack-cack-cack"; "kick-kick", etc. Also a mournful "ooooooreee".
Similar to White-throated Robin's in repetition of phrases, but louder, even more thrasherlike.
Soft churring notes and a nasal "wheer".
Call note, "weenk" or "wenk". Song suggests cranking up of an old-time motor car; it starts with "wenk, wenk", then catches and takes off at a fast pace with flutelike nottes, etc. A fine singer.

One of the world's finest bird singers. 'Makes all other thrushes sound like amateurs' (Fisher). A succession of penetrating piccolo-like whistles of great virtuosity, varying in pitch, often ending on a loose trill.
Rich liquid phrases very suggestive of Wood Thrush but less loud and full.
Song suggestive of Hermit Thrush in quality and form. Call notes, a high-pitched "seent" and a low "twaa".
Resembles that of next species but thinner, less musical, less varied. Call nasal, suggesting Gray Catbird.
Song has pattern of Wood Thrush's and quality of Hermit Thrush's. 1-3 flutelike "eeoo-lay" phrases, followed by a much higher phrase.

Emphatic phrases, rather like those of White-eyed Vireo, often ending with a "chick" or "we-chik". Song may be interpreted as "diver-chi-doski"; also "cher-che-witzee, witzchee witzchewezi-wezi", etc.
Note, a thin peevish "zpee" or "chee". Song, a thin, squeaky, wheezy series of notes, easily overlooked.
Song, a slow trill, high and thin at outset, fuller and slower toward end.
Note, a thin harsh "chee", repeated 2-3 times, or "pee-ee-ee" (Blue-gray usually gives single note).
A trill, "ti-eeeeeeeeeeeeeee", seeming to rise toward end. A soft trilled whistle on same key. Also a rougher trill, dropping in pitch.
Note, a soft low "wurp". Song, a week, casual warble, wheezy and disconnected.
Call note, "chelp" or "kelp". A 2-note call, 2nd note higher and accented.

A short, pleasing warbled phrase, repeated at intervals, then changing to another phrase, again repeated. A rising "witu witu wichu", dropping on last syllable. Also *to-wish-to-we-you*. Also "cheeee che chrr", succeeding notes lower and faster.
A repetitious chant, "tew-tew-tew-tew" on same pitch, repeated at intervals. Suggests Tufted Titmouse, a repetitious *peter-peter-peter-peter*.
Suggests White-eyed Vireo's in character.
A loud repetitious "che-che-che-che-che", etc., or "jeer-jeer-jeer-jeer", etc.
Song, a rapid, rather high "chu-chu-chu-chu-chu-chu-chu-chu" on 1 pitch.
Song similar to Red-eyed Vireo's but phrases shorter; longer pauses between phrases.
Song much like Red-eyed Vireo's but phrases more abrupt. Phrases consist of 2 or 3 ntes.
Song warbled as in Warbling Vireo, but shorter, less varied: "cheerooroowee'chee-chee'weerooweeche-cheereechee"; also "twe'cheeweechee", thrice repeated.
Song, 3-5 ntes, suggesting White-eyed Vireo, emphasis on 3rd or 4th note.
A constantly uttered "nya-nya" and a more nasal vireo-nine "weng". Song, an ascending trill followed by a single lower-pitched note.
Song resembles a singe repeated phrase of Red-eyed Vireo, but higher-pitched; phrases more widely spaced. Usually a 3-note phrase repeated: "tsitseeweet" and "itsacheet" sometimes "tsiweet".
A sharp "tswe". Song, a simple, deliberate and protracted "tsip-tsip-chaa-tsip-tsip-tsic-cha", etc.. Note, a weak, nasal "chaa", suggestive of gnatcatcher.
A loud, strident "tswee tswee". Song a tirelessly repeated "tsip" given rapidly. A short nasal grunt, "uhr".
Song, lisping and wheezy, varying geographically. A rising "sisisisi"; also "wiz wiz wiz sisisisi".
An often repeated song, "tcherrrrrrrrrr", about 1 second in length.
Nearly identical with Northern Parula's song.
Song, in W. Indies, a sprightly "wee-chee-wee-chee-chee-wur" with many variations. More full-voiced than N. American Yellow Warbler.
Song, a buntinglike "twe twe twe weechy weechy wit a twit weechy a weech". Usual song, a number of undistinctive vireolike phrases strung together.
Variations of "chee-a-weep, chee-a-weep, chee-a-weep, chink chink chink chink". Or "chee-a-weep" (4 times), "zeep, zeep".
A buntinglike song.
A clear sweet song similar to Yellow Warbler's.
Song, a repetitious "weeta weeta weeta wee" or "weeta weeta chilp chilp chilp". Note, an unwarblerlike "clee-ip".
Song, a series of rapid notes repeated 5-8 times: "chee chee chee chee chee chee". Also "tsewe, tsewe, tsewe, chee chee chee". Also a rising "whi-cha, whi-cha, whi-cha, whi-cha".
Call note, "tseeng". Song, "we we we we whicha weest". Also "we we whicha".
Note, "p-seet". Song, "cha cha cha see see see cha cha cha see"; "cha"'s on same pitch, "see"'s higher.
Song, about 6 clear whistled notes, first 3 on same pitch, the next higher, the next lower, the last note at original pitch: "twee twee twee twee twee twee".
Song, "wit-ah-witah-weechy".
Note, "tzep". Song rises from beginning and accelerates: "cheap cheap cheap chi-chi-chi-chi"; sometimes order reversed. Song short and canarylike.
Song, "tsit-sit, tseetweet"; also a dry ""chit-cha-chup-chachaweep". Also calls "zeep-zeep" and a rather dry trill "trrrrr".
An unmusical "jiva jiva jiva jura glu glu glom glom glom glu", ending in a rattle. A series of gurgling notes, "plup, plup, plup, plup-loo-u'poo".
Song, during display, sounds like water pouring out of a bottle; 5-7 liquid "glub"'s or "gloob"'s, getting higher and faster. "Khruk, khruk, glug, glug, glug-glug-glugloogloog-kacheer'".
Discordant, creaking: "kruk, kruk, ksh-shee-ah" or, by a stretch of the imagination, "ca-seek-eh" - Spanish pronunciation of 'cacique'.
Harsh notes, usually double: "wahk-wahk" or "wahk-chowh-chowh" (female?). Also whistling notes, perhaps given by male.
A guttural "waird" accompanied by a very high-pitched "weessss" given 3-4 times.
Various excited, shrill, discordant notes, including a high, rapid "kee-kee-kee-kee-kee", etc., or "kik-kik-kik-kik", etc.; a lower blackbird "check, check". Also an upward slurring "ma-ree".

A variety of whistles like *what cheer* (given 2 or 3 times). Also *to weer to weer*; *will you chow-how*; *one-year one-year*. "Chuck, wheeeur chuck, wheeeur"; also a thin down-slurred "cheeurrr, cheeurrr", etc.
Song, a fast-moving outburst of piping whistles, guttural notes; unlike abrupt piping of most orioles. A strident slurred *what-cheer* or "wheer", at or near end.
Song, a series of melodious whistles. Call suggestive of House Sparrow, rather nasal and monotonous.
Song, rich whistles; suggests Western Meadowlark.
Song, throaty notes and piping whistles: "chut chut chut whew whew". Note, a sharp "eek".
A loud clear whistle of 2 phrases, repeated: "chee-wow, chee-wow" or "gee-wow, gee-wow". A loud repetitious chant: "wur-chip-chewoo, wur-chip-chewoo, wur-chip-chewoo", etc.

Song (in Panamá), 6-14 loud clear whistles, moving irregularly up and down scale, giving impression of being off-key. A frequent call is "teea, cheep-cheep-cheep, tee"; 1st and last notes whistled, others nasal.
Song, low whistled notes of human quality, disjointed with halftones; suggests a boy learning to whistle.
A harsh rasping 'fuss' note, "ike-ike-ike". Song, disjointed whistled notes.
Song, a series of rich, piping whistled notes. Note, a low mellow whistled "hew-li".
A series of accented double notes with 1 or 2 piping notes. Note, a sharp "kip"; also a chatter.
A poor vocalist; oriole-like musical chirps; a wrenlike rattle, a rapid, dry meadowlarklike chatter.

Note (in Costa Rica), a mournful, short dovelike "oo", often repeated one or more times; ventriloquial; sometmes given by two birds in duet. Also a short "ek". In Panamá, a fast puppylike "enk-enk-enk-enk".
Call, "chup" or "dyewp". Song, an irregular sputtering or twittering series with some musical undertones. One song suggests complex song of Winter Wren.
Calls, "wee'-chup"; also "weet-tsick" and "tsick-tsick".
A thin, musical 3-syllable whistle at a level pitch; a vireolike "wheet-chichi-chi-chih"; a high-pitched "see-see-see, dewd-see".
A short whistle, rapidly repeated 2 or 3 times, sometimes clear and bell-like.
An unmusical jumble of sharp notes, including a soft trill.
A weak trill (1 second), "tsiriririririririt", weaker and shorter than trill of Chipping Sparrow.
A series of metallic chipping notes.
Song, varied and intricate phrases, but tone weak and squeaky. Suggests one of songs of American Redstart. Calls, "chueep" and "seeee".
A series of strong chips suggesting Chipping Sparrow; very metallic and rapid: "chi-chi-chi", etc., or "chill-chill-chill", etc.. Cll, a long "seeeeeet".
Song, a prolonged but weak warble, seldom heard. Call note, a drawn-out "seep".
Song, loosely connected robin- or vireolike inconsequential phrases. Notes, a confidential "hist", and a throaty "churr".
"Tze-tze-tsweze", or "tswe-twe", or "twsizee".
Song, vireolike with a burr in it. Call note, "purrrrrit". Song with short burry phrases similar to those of Scarlet or Western Tanagers.
Call, "tsupeet-peet"; also "seetseesee".

Song, "chu - cheeah - chu - cheeah - chu - cheaah". "Cheer-cheer-cheer-cheer" or "purtee'-pirtee'-pirtee'-pirtee'"; the 2 types sometimes combined. Short whistled phrases "cheer chur, cheer chur" or "cheer chur-chur".
Song, a sequence of paired notes, rising in pitch with each couplet. A robinlike "chew-chew", given 1-4 times.
Noisy; "stchee", followed by 4 rich descending "chee"'s, ending with several "chee"'s on a level.
A gifted singer. Song sweet and appealing: "whichis whichis whicheery whichis whichu" etc.
Song, wrenlike, 4-noted: "wee, choohoo chyo" or "chee chyo, choyo".
Notes while feeding, thin, grasshopperlike.
Note, "chib". Song, a rapid "chib-che-wab-ah-wab-ah-wab-ah-wab". 1 or 2 deliberat smacking notes followed by a rapid, uneven, grating series, "chack, chack, tch-ch-ch-ch-ch-chur".
Song often suggests some species of robin. *Cheery cheery* answered by *cheer to you*, delivered with falling cadence. Also "trale le-e-le, trale'le-e-le", etc.

Song, "chip, chup chup, oid" ("chip" is sometimes left out; "woid" is drawn out and rises). Also "crrrrr cheechu cheechu cheechuuu"; and "chip weed". A musical "chirp-wheee" (rising) often followed by an uneven "tsur-wewewewe-chew".

A descending whistle, "chi-cha-cha". Cal, a sharp, short "pwtst chirp-chirp-chirp". Song, a musical "churtweet' churtweet' churtweet'" in a leisurely manner. A short buzz followed by a whistled "tweet tweet".
Song, a clear "quink quink quink, quink quink", on 1 pitch: aso a slurred, whistled "what-cheer, what-cheer", etc., thinner and shorter than Cardinal's song.
Song very much like that of a robin. Suggests mellow rising and falling passages of Rose-breasted or Black-headed Grosbeak, but more rapid.
Song (Honduras), a whistled "whreet-whreet-wheet-weet-weet".

Note, "klick" or "klink". Song variable; a loud series of about 7 clear whistled notes (1st low, next 5 starting high and descending, last note high); 4-8 deliberate strong mellow whistles often followed by a softer, rapid, breezy flourish or twitter.
A thin bright finch song, more distinctly phrased and less warbled than Painted Bunting's; notes not so distinctly paired as insongs of Lazuli or Indigo Buntings.
A clear "wheat-cheeweet-cheat" (rising on last note); or "wheat-cheeweet"; or "wheat-cheeweet-cheat-cheat".
Note, "tzzip". Song, an insectlike buzz, "tsi-tsi-tsi-tsi-tsi"; in W. Indies a weak, rapidly uttered trill, like that of a Worm-eating Warbler.

A sweet, loud song; begins on several high repeated notes and drops to several notes on a lower pitc: *sweet sweet sweet, cheer cheer cheer cheer*; often only 2 "cheer"'s. A canarylike song often ending with "chip-chip-chip". Variations include "chee-wee, che-wee, che-wee, wiz-wiz-wiz-wiz" etc.
Calls, a sweet "see'oo" or "sleeoo" and "tse'wee" and "tseeyp". Song, a rapid hurried twittering. Song disordered; very different from patterned song of White-collared Seedeater.
Song, canarylike, tinkling; sometimes ending with "buzz-zee". Also "wheat-wheat-wheat-wheat" etc. (4-7 times) often ending with "chee".
A fine, long-continued, buntinglike song. Call note, "ik" or "ek".
A very short song, "weezit", given as the bird jumps a foot or two above perch and returns.
Notes suggest Horned Lark, "tsi tsip tsi tsip" or "tsi silp tsi silp". In flight adds a "bzzzzzzzzzz".
A clear whistled "soo-sweet, chip chip chip".
Call, a high-pitched "zeet"; song, a series of high-pitched notes.
Song, a slow, very high-pitched thin "ts, ts, ts, ts, ts"; also "tsit, tseedeedsteetseet". Note, "dzeet", also a sharp "tzick".
Song, a series of dry chips on 1 pitch, starting deliberately and accelerating into a rattle.
Song, a series of notes resembling *peter-peter-peter* of Tuftd Titmouse, but trailing off at end.
Note, a metallic "chink". Song, a rapid "chink-chink-ink-ink-ink-ink-ink-ink", on 1 pitch. Often ends in a trill. Sometimes "chilp-chilp-chilp-chilp-chilp-chilp"; other variations.
A rapid series of chirping "chep"'s.
A sibilant note repeated 5-15 times in a series that begins weakly and fades as it ends.
Song, 7-8 short syllables followed by 2 melodic notes.
Variable; "slip-tip-tip" followed by chipping.
An excited song, like 2 birds fighting.
"Wheesk - wheesk, wheesk, wheesk".
A hoarse chipping. Song, "zup-a-tzip-a-tzip-a-tzip-a".
Song, a clear "chip chip chip" and then a short trill on a lower key; 1 or 2 sweet introductory notes and a rapid series of musical chips on 1 pitch.
A loud, penetrating squeaking and chipping.
Song, a bright, accented "chu-we, chip-chip"; also "chi-chip, ti-ti-ti-you".
Song, stuttering and gurgling, 1st part ascending slightly, last notes descending; suggests House-Wren. Note, a nasal "chur, chur, chur" or "dear, dear, dear".
Song, a constant tinkling and 'pitting', sometimes running into a dry rattle.

A cheerful whistled arrangement; one of the most characteristic bird songs of Mid. and S. America, often varying locally. 'Suggests E. Meadowlark'. In Guatemala a typical song consists of 3 whistled notes, the 1st short with a rising inflection, the 2nd longer and dropping, the 3rd like the 1st. In Panamá song somewhat suggests E. Meadowlark "tee'oo tee'a" and variations.
Song musical, unlike trill or other juncos, more complicated; 3-parted, often thus: "chip chip chip, wheedle wheedle, che che che che che".
Call, "beebink" or "bree-bink" or "bre-bruk" or "beet beet". A variation is "bee-bink-beeaw" - 1st 2 notes on te same pitch, 3rd note starting high and sliding down.
Very similar to Pine Siskin's. Calls similar to those of American Goldfinch.
loud, high-pitched trill
mostly silent
cackling
cackling
croaks and growls
deep croak
loud hiss when angry
loud trumpeting
"quack quack"
mostly silent
mostly silent
mainly silent, but male sometimes makes a loud "zeee-zee" call and a low growling
high-pitched "pee-ooo-eee"
high-pitched "pee-uuu"
chattering "kew-kew-kew" when nesting
shrill "ki-ki-ki-ki-ki"
harsh, cackling "kek-rek-rek" when nesting
usually silent
usually silent
call sounds like *go back, go back!*
raucous "ko-kok"
grating "kerrick" call
loud "chuck-chukka-chuck"
loud "kruuuk"
loud "kowk"
loud, high-pitched "peep peep peep"
"klute klute" call when alarmed
"peewit"
"croak"
"cur-lew"
ringing "teeu-tu-tu" alarm call
harsh "keeyar" call
various loud mewing and wailing cries
high-pitched "kee-yaaarr"
like common tern, but higher pitched
harsh "ki-rrric"
shrill "krik-krik"
"kitteewa-aaake"call
growling calls at nest
growling calls at nest
growling calls at nest
cooing calls
five-part call "coo-COO-coo, coo-coo"
three-part "coo-COO-coo"
loud "cuc-koo" in spring
high-pitched shrieks and hissing screams
"twit-twoo" hoot
loud, laughing "klu-klu-klu-klu"
loud "tchick!" call
sharp, high-pitched "zeee"
"vit-vit" call, long twittering song
harsh, screaming screech
"priit" flight call, soft twittering song
"chirrup" call, warbling song
thin whistling call, song is a run of high notes ending with a trill
sharp "chizik" flight call, twittering song
sharp "tswik" flight call
sharp "zit zit" flight call, warbling song
"tic tic" call, sweet song all year round
sharp "tik tik" call, loud, rattling song
shrill "chink chink chink" call and rich song
loud, rattling call, loud song
thin "tsic" call, loud, tuneful song
chattering "chak chack-chak" flight call
soft "seep" flight call
"chirr chirr" call, long, chattering song
sharp "chrrr" alarm call, long, chattering song
harsh "tac" and "cherrr" calls, tuneful song
"tac tac" and "cherr" calls, scratchy song
"chiff-chaff" song
high-pitched "seee" call, "tseedle-dee tseedle-dee" song
thin "zeee" call, soft, warbly song
sharp "huit" call
thin "see" call and churring alarm call
high-pitched "see see" call, with short, hissing trills
thin "see see" call, loud "pee-chew, pee-chew" song
lots of different songs, all with a two-note pattern, including *tea-cher, tea-cher*
loud "dueet-dueet", also "pee-pee-pee-pee" trill
thin "tsee tsee" call, very high-pitched trilling sound
loud screech
loud rattling sound
deep, cawing "kraaa kraaa"
grating croaks
sharp "jack jack" and higher-pitched "kyow"
deep, "kronk kronk" croak
complicated song with rattles and whistles, copies other birds' calls
chirps and chirrups
loud "chink-chink" call and rattling song
loud twittering trill followed by long "dzeeeeeee"
simple "twit-a-twit" flight call, long, twittering song
"tzeeuu" or "tzuee" call, twittering song
Various calls, including a threatening hiss. In flight the wings make a unique rhythmic 'chuffing' sound.
With practice the higher-pitched, more yelping voice of Bewick's can be distinguished.
Flocks give a slightly muted cackling chorus.
More honking than Pink-footed Goose, and lacking its squeaky "wink-wink" notes.
Flocks give a cackling chorus, generally higher-pitched and more musical than other geese, in which it is possible to pick out clear, high "wink-wink" notes.
A harsh cackling similar to a farmyard goose (this is the ancestor of most domestic breeds).
Flocks give a loud honking with clear, well-spaced notes.
A gruff honking.
Flocks give a chorus of low, throaty "krrrs".
A variety of harsh honking and quacking notes.
Thin whistles, often given by male in fligh whilst chasing female, and a hoarse "k-k-k-k-krrr, krrr, krrr".
Rather silent.
A clipping "chuck-chuck-chuk-chuk".
Pure, thin whistled "pee" and more quacking "ak, ak".
Male gives a soft, nasal "kreep", female gives the classic "quak", often in a 'laughing' series: "quak, quak, quak-quak-quak-quak".
Call a mellow "proop".
Drake gives a loud and shrill, whistled "pee-oow" or "p'pee-oow".
Drakes have a distinctive display call, a dry, wooden rattle, "k-r-r-r-r-r-r-eet, k-r-r-r-r-r-r-eet....".
Call a nervous, slightly tremulous, whistled "cree".
Generally silent.
In display male Tufted Duck gives a series of rapid bubbling notes, female has growling call.
Generally silent.
Courting male has wonderful, rolling and rather pigeon-like "aa-ooow, aa-ooow..." given as it throws its head back.
Call "ah-oowa-lip", vaguely goose-like, given in chorus by displaying males in late winter.
Displaying male throws head back and gives a rapid quack. In flight the wings produce a loud musical whistle, especially in males.
Usually silent.
Usually silent.
Harsh "krak-krak-krak..." in display.
Quail call is a liquid "quip-ip-ip" (*wet my lips*), often given at night.
Corncrake's is a rasping "crex-crex-crex..." (hence scientific name), like fingernails run across a comb, and it also often calls at night.
A loud "krrrr-k-k-k-k-k", *go-back, go-back...*
A dry, croaking rattle (like stick pulled rapidly across slats of picket fence).
Capercaillie's song is quiet throaty clicks followed by a noise like a cork being popped.
Lekking Black Grouse give far-carrying, eerie, bubbling moan, "oodle-u, oodle-u, woooo, woooo, oodle-u...", intermixed with harsh hisses.
Call a single crowing "kook" or "kru-kook", accelerating into a cackle in flight.
A single, prolonged grating "kree'eet", often given early in the morning and evening.
Calls frequently, a rhythmic chicken-like "kuk'kuk-kacha".
Guttural croaks and chatters.
Loud, often prolonged, whinnying trill that rises and falls in volume and sometimes also in pitch.
Flight call on breeding grounds a cackling "cak cak". Song a goose-like honking and tremulous wailing. Silent in winter.
A croaking "gak-gak-gak" at nest.
In breeding colonies at night gives bizzare hoarse wailing.
A hoarse "aar-r-r" at breeding colonies.
Grunting at colonies.
Deep, harsh calls at colonies.
Generally silent except at breeding colonies, when both make croaking and grunting noises.
Generally silent except at breeding colonies, when both make croaking and grunting noises.
Song of male a very low-pitched "wump", recalling the sound made by blowing over the neck of a bottle, this 'booming' can be heard for up to 5km on still nights.
Flight call a harsh "frank".
A yelping, whistled "yip-yip-yip".
A plaintive, slightly nasal "keeoow" (recalling a squeaky toy).
Rough-legged Buzzard has a far-carrying "peee-oooo" call, recalling Common Buzzard.
Honey-buzzard is generally silent except in breeding season.
Various shrill, drawn-out whistles.
In display gives squeaky, Lapwing-like "wee-it...wee-it..."
During aerial courtship display the male gives a squeaky, nasal "keh-keh-keh-keh".
In aerial display male gives a rapid, squeaky "chik-ik-ik-ik...".
A very loud, screaming "ki-ki-ki-ki..."
Sharp, staccato "ki'ki'ki'ki'kik".
Mostly silent.
A shrill, throaty "khee-khee-khee".
Call a shrill "kii-kii-kii-kii..." Only vocal on breeding grounds.
A sharp, clear "kiau-kiau....".
A quarrelsome, piercing "klee-klee-klee", each note rising in pitch.
Varied pig-like squeals and grunts, also an unassuming "kip, kip, kip...".
Very varied, calls include a mellow, full, explosive "trork".
Call a full "kook" and shriller "kit" (given in chorus), also a clipped "tink", like metal on stone.
Call a shrill "k'leep", often given in chorus by several birds. Song a repeated "tee-teeoo..., tee-teeoo..." given in circling display flight, with exaggerated slow wingbeats.
Call a shrill, yelping "quip quip quip....".
Song, often given at night, a repeated "krrrr-ee, krrrr-ee...", with the first note harsh and trilling, the second a shrill whistle; this, and most other calls, are distinctly Curlew-like.
Call purring, song a repeated "phip phip phip phip...".
Call a single "teeu". Song a repeated "tree-up, tree-up...", given in wavering display flight.
Call a clearly disyllabic "too-ip". Song a rapidly repeated whistle, "quiddu-quiddu...", given in low, stiff-winged display flight.
Call a sad "pee". Song plaintive whistles given in butterfly-like display flight.
Call a characteristic plaintive, three-note whistle, "tu-loo-ee".
Call a high, nasal "tow-ip" (hence 'peewit'). Song "klep-toowit, klip klip, tooo-ow-wit", given in a rolling and tumbling display flight.
Virtually mute.
Flight call a harsh "scree". Song a mixture of calls and prolonged reedy trilling.
In flight Little Stint gives a sharp "tit".
Curlew Sandpiper a chirpy "chirrup".
Call a soft, nasal "knut"; also a querulous "quee-quee" in alarm.
Call a sharp "quick"
Flight call a conversational "quit".
Flight call "tiuw" and a distinctive chattering "kuk-a-kuk-kuk".
When roding gives a thin "tissik" interspersed with a low grunting "wark-wark-wark" that is only audible as it passes close overhead.

Call when flushed an abrupt harsh "scaap". Song, often given from a prominent perch, a repeated "chip-er chip-er...". In 'drumming' display flight the modified outer tail feathers make a low throbbing as the bird periodically dives downwards.
Flight call "wicka-wicka".
Flight call a full but squeaky "kwik-kwik".
In flight gives a very distinctive, soft but penetrating "ti-ti-i-ti-ti-ti-ti".
Call a haunting whistled "courlee". Song a beautiful bubbling trill given in flight display.
In flight Green Sandpipers gives a shrill, loud, ringing, "kluw-ee, kluw-ee-eet....", (...)
(...) and Wood Sandpiper a flat, whistled "chiff-if-if".
Call a ringing, high-pitched "swee-weewee-wee", falling slightly in pitch.
Flight call a very distinctive 2-note "chew-wit".
Call a mournful, whistled "teu-lu, teu-luu...". Song "tu-tu-tu-tu..." given for prolonged periods of flight.
Call a loud, ringing "tew-tew-tew".
Calls mewing, recalling Kittiwake.
Call a rising, nasal "keeah".
Calls include a scolding "krreearr" and sharp "kek, kek".
Gives the familiar 'laughing' display call.
As Herring Gull but deeper and throatier.
Deeper, fuller and gruffer than Herring Gull.
Calls high-pitched, shrill or mewing.
A nasal "k-kitt-i-waake" at breeding colonies.
Both usually silent; flight call of Little Gull a short hard "kek-kekkek" call.
Both usually silent; flight call of Black Tern is a harsh "klit" or "klee".
As Common Tern but higher and more nasal.
Call a sharp "kip" and harsh "keee-arrrr".
Flight call a grating "kirreet, kirreet...".
Calls include distinctive sharp, squeaky "kreet, kreet...".
At colonies a rumbling "aarr".
Gives a deep "urrr" at colonies, but rather silent.
Displaying male gives a thin pipit-like squeak.
Various grunting calls given from the nesting burrow.
A deep, gentle purring "turrrr, turrrr...".
Calls frequently, a three-note phrase: "who-hooo-ho", repeated several times; also gives a single harsh purring "kurrr".
Call a repeated soft, two-note phrase: "oow-AH, oow-AH, oow-AH..." becoming more insistent with as the call goes on.
The familiar "oow-oooh, oow-oooh...".
Song a five-note phrase: *who cooks for-you, oh...*, repeated 3-5 times.
Call a squawking "kree, kree-kree-kree, kree-kree...".
Song unmistakable, female gives a bubbling trill.
Relatively quiet. Song an unpleasant, drawn-out grating shriek. Young in the nest give a variety of hisses.

Call a sharp yelping "kyow", falling in pitch, in alarm a rapid series of querulous notes: "chi, chi, chi-chi". Song a simple, plaintive, upwardly inflected hoot (recalling a Curlew), repeated every 5-10 seconds "coo-ee...coo-ee...".

Calls infrequently in winter and early spring, the commonest call a squeaky "kewick". Song a drawn-out hoot followed by a pause and then a rapid series of notes and another hoot: "hoo-wooh... ho, ho-wo-woo-wooh"; the female gives a hoarser and more wailing version. The combination of call and song, cobbled together in folklore, gives the familiar "tuwit, tuwoo".
Song a rapid, muffled "bo boo boo-boo-boo..." given in a circling display flight.

Call a full, throaty "cu-wick", often given in flight. Song a rapid reel (so fast that individual notes can barely be made out), with frequent changes in pitch. Birds sing for long periods from a perch on a tree top or dead limb and the song often ends with a slower, winding down "tow-tow-tow-tow-tow". Males also clap their wings together in flight to make a snapping noise.
A loud, prolonged and shrill ringing scream, often given in chorus.
Call a shrill, penetrating whistle: "zee" or "zee-tee", often given in flight (louder and more piercing than similar call of Dunnock).

Call "kik", as Great Spotted Woodpecker but weaker. Spring song shrill, squeaky "kee-kee-kee-kee-kee...". In early spring also drums in a very similar fashion to Great Spotted Woodpecker, but each drum-roll softer and longer, at 1.2-1.8 seconds; often gives two drum-rolls in rapid succession.

Call a sharp "kik", sometimes given in slow series. No song, rather in Jan-Jun 'drums' by rapidly beating its bill against a tree to produce a buzzing rattle, 0.4-0.8 seconds long, so fast that individual strikes cannot be distinguished. Pitch and timbre of drumming depends upon type of tree, which acts as a sounding board.

Call a loud, manic series of 10-20 notes: "kle-kle-kle-kle...", delivered rapidly but deliberately and falling slightly in pitch towards the end; this call gives it the old country name 'yaffle'. Rarely drums.

Usually sings while circling slowly 100-150m above ground. Each phrase is a series of repeated notes, starting hesitantly but growing in volume and often falling in pitch: "ti, ti, ti, tuwi-tuwi-tuwi-tuwi-tuwi-TUWI-TUWI-TUWI..."; after a brief pause a slightly different, phrase is given, etc. Call a mellow "tit-lwee".
Call a musical "tsirrup" or "tsiroeet". Sings for prolonged periods while flying high in the sky, a continuous and varied outpouring of notes.
Song a delightful twittering, often given while sitting on wires.
Distinctive rasping "ree-ree-reep-eep", draws attention to its presence.
Call a stony "prrit, prri-it". Song a jumbled warble given near the nest.

Very like Meadow Pipit. Call a single sharp "phist" (Meadow Pipit typically gives several notes), alarm a nervous "tsip". Song a repletion of simple notes, slightly fuller and more metallic than Meadow Pipit but similarly given as it flies up from ground and then 'parachutes' back down.

Meadow Pipit is very vocal, flight call a thin "see seet", in alarm a nervous "stit". Song a series of simple notes, often given as it flies up from ground and then 'parachutes' down, e.g. "chi chi chi su su su su sisisisi tuu tuu tuu".
Tree Pipit calls less often, a single hoarse "spiz". Song rich, varied and Canary-like, given from a tree top or in a parachuting display flight that starts and ends on an elevated perch.
Call a loud, shrill "tsweep". Song merely the repetition of 2-3 notes, a shrill "tsree-ree".
Call "tiz-zik", like Pied Wagtail, but sharper, often followed by single "zik" notes as it flies away. Song a simple "tsi-tsi-tsi" and canary-like warblings.
Flight call a sharp "chis-zik", also gives a more musical "tsu-wee". Song twittering.
Call a rapid, sibilant trill "sililililili...", often given in chorus.
Flight call a sharp, penetrating "stik". Song a slow croaky warble.
Call a loud "chak-chak-ak", sometimes extended into a rattle, also a more buzzing "trrrrrrrrrrrr". Song, given from cover, a loud, fast warbling and trilling, lasting 3-6 seconds.
Call a sharp, penetrating "stiih". Song a sweet whistled ditty, varying little between individuals, "tiddle-iddle-lu-wi, tiddle-iddle-lu-wi-lu-weet". Usually sings from an exposed perch.

Call a sharp "tic", and in alarm a very high-pitched, hissing "tseee". Song beautiful 'wistful' and melodic, with no two verses the same. Sings all year, autumn song being the most melancholy. Sometimes sings at night.
Common Redstart's call is a whistled "huweet", often followed by "chik-chik"; song a throaty warbler, often incorporating a repeated note or rattle followed by a variety of terminal phrases.
Black Redstart's song is a mixture of whistled rattles and strange hissing or fizzing notes.

Call a Chaffinch-like "heep" and bizarre croaking "errrr". Song rich, full and powerful, composed of phrases 2-seconds long with equally long gaps between them. Each phrase comprises impressive rattles and trills interspersed with a slower, pure whistled crescendo: "tu-tu-tu-tu-tu...". Sings by day as well as by night, but most persistent between midnight and dawn. Song period short, mid Apr-May, with little song later in summer.
Call a piping "hip", often combined with "tak-tak". Song a short, fast, rich but scratchy warble with distinct pauses between phrases.
Call a high-pitched "vist", often followed by a hard "chak-chak". Song short, like abbreviated Dunnock, sometimes given in brief song flight.
Call a piping "hip", often combined with a hard "chak-chak". Song a short, scratchy warble, sometimes given in flight.
Call "chack-chack-chack" - rather like Fieldfare. Song loud, 'wild' and rather simple, with repeated phrases like a Song Thrush.
A characteristic, loud "shack-shack, shakshakshak...", usually given in flight.
A high-pitched but full "seehp". This call can often be heard on autumn nights as migrants arrive from Europe for the winter.

A single "sip". Song a series of strident whistled phrases, each repeated 2-4 times, e.g. "tui-tui-tui, titi-titi, didyu-didyu-didyu...", and each bird may use over 100 different phrases. Higher-pitched than Blackbird, sweeter than Mistle Thrush, the repetition is characteristic.

Loud, far-carrying song given in late winter and early spring, structure like Blackbird's song but phrases shorter, harsher and wilder. Often sings during inclement weather leading to old country name of 'Stormcock'. Call a distinctive dry rattle given in flight, recalling wooden football rattle.
Song slow, rich and melodic, without repetition. In alarm or at dusk gives a loud "pik, pik, pik...", which can become an explosive rattle when flushed.
Grasshopper Warbler has an insect-like, mechanical reeling, lasting up to a minute at a time.
Cetti's Warbler gives a sudden, loud outburst: "che-che, pi, CHEWEEE-CHEWEE-CHEWEE".
Call a harsh "churrr". Song a rapid series of grating phrases, each repeated 2-3 times: "churr-churr-churr, chipit-chipit, che-che-che, chidi-chidi...".

Call a grating "trrrr" and hard "tak". Song an 'angry' mass of harsh grating notes with occasional sweet whistled crescendos, faster than Reed Warbler and lacking the monotonous rhythm. Song sometimes given in flight.

Call an undistinguished and nervous "che". Song comprises fast, rambling phrases, 3-8 seconds long, some notes full and fruity (recalling Blackbird in tone), often given for prolonged periods with brief pauses between each phrase. Overall rather unvaried, always lacking the high sweet notes of Blackcap. Usually sings from dense cover and more often heard than seen.

Call a hard "tak". Song initially a rambling chattering (rather like Garden Warbler), but each phrase typically ends with a crescendo of high, beautifully sweet, whistled notes. Sometimes gives several phrases without the sweet terminal notes and then very easy to confuse with Garden Warbler, but always eventually produces characteristic pure whistles. There are usually also significant gaps between each song phrase, unlike the near-continuous warbling of Garden Warbler.
Call a distinctive "vedd-vedd-vedd", in alarm a harsh "charrr". Song a short, scratchy warble, varying little from bird to bird. Usually sings from an exposed perched or in short, showy song flight.
Call a hard "tak". Song a quiet, undistinguished warble followed by a loud, very characteristic machine gun-like rattle: ... "cha-cha-cha-cha-cha". Usually sings from deep cover.

Song a fast, scratchy and rather tuneless phrase, varying little in pitch and with just a few sweet notes; it is rather like Common Whitethroat's, but less structured. Call a harsh "chairr, chairr", again like Common Whitethroat (or distant, muffled Jay).

Call a melancholy "piu", recalling Bullfinch. Song has two variants. Commonest is stuttering series of sharp, loud "zip" notes that accelerates into a very fast shivering trill, its whole body shaking; often sings in short gliding song flight.
